ai-sn35:7.1.1_0: “Mendicants, the eye of the past and future is impermanent,
ai-sn35:7.1.3_0: Seeing this, a learned noble disciple doesn’t worry about the eye of the past,
ai-sn35:7.1.4_0: they don’t look forward to enjoying the eye in the future,
ai-sn35:7.1.5_0: and they practice for disillusionment, dispassion, and cessation regarding the eye in the present. ...”

ai-sn35:7.1.17_0: they don’t look forward to enjoying the mind in the future,
ai-sn35:7.1.18_0: and they practice for disillusionment, dispassion, and cessation regarding present mind.”

ai-sn35:13.1.2_0: “Mendicants, before my awakening—when I was still unawakened but intent on awakening—I thought:
ai-sn35:13.1.3_0: ‘What’s the gratification, the drawback, and the escape when it comes to the eye ...
ai-sn35:13.1.10_0: ‘The pleasure and happiness that arise from the eye: this is its gratification.
ai-sn35:13.1.11_0: That the eye is impermanent, suffering, and perishable: this is its drawback.
ai-sn35:13.1.12_0: Removing and giving up desire and greed for the eye: this is its escape.
ai-sn35:13.1.13_0: If you take pleasure in the ear ...
ai-sn35:13.1.16_0: That the ear ... nose ... tongue ... body ...
ai-sn35:13.1.17_0: Removing and giving up desire and greed for the tongue: this is its escape.
ai-sn35:13.1.20_0: That the mind is impermanent, suffering, and perishable: this is its drawback.
ai-sn35:13.1.21_0: Removing and giving up desire and greed for the mind: this is its escape.’
ai-sn35:13.2.1_0: As long as I didn’t truly understand these six interior sense fields’ gratification, drawback, and escape in this way for what they are, I didn’t announce my supreme perfect awakening in this world with its gods, Māras, and Brahmās, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, its gods and humans.
ai-sn35:13.2.2_0: But when I did truly understand these six interior sense fields’ gratification, drawback, and escape in this way for what they are, I announced my supreme perfect awakening in this world with its gods, Māras, and Brahmās, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, its gods and humans.
ai-sn35:13.2.3_0: To me knowledge and insight arose:
ai-sn35:13.2.4_0: ‘My freedom is unshakable; this is my last rebirth; now there’ll be no more future lives.’”
ai-sn35:14.1.1_0: “Mendicants, before my awakening—when I was still unawakened but intent on awakening—I thought:
ai-sn35:14.1.2_0: ‘What’s the gratification, the drawback, and the escape when it comes to sights ...
ai-sn35:14.1.3_0: So let them hear the sounds ...
ai-sn35:14.1.5_0: What is the source of tastes ...
ai-sn35:14.1.6_0: What is the source of touches ...
ai-sn35:14.1.9_0: ‘The pleasure and happiness that arise from sights.
ai-sn35:14.1.10_0: That sights is impermanent, suffering, and perishable: this is its drawback.
ai-sn35:14.1.11_0: Removing and giving up desire and greed for sights: this is its escape.
ai-sn35:14.1.16_0: The pleasure and happiness that arise from thoughts: this is its gratification.
ai-sn35:14.1.17_0: That the things are impermanent, suffering, and perishable: this is its drawback.
ai-sn35:14.1.18_0: Removing and giving up desire and greed for thoughts: this is its escape.’
ai-sn35:14.2.1_0: As long as I didn’t truly understand these six exterior sense fields’ gratification, drawback, and escape in this way for what they are, I didn’t announce my supreme perfect awakening in this world with its gods, Māras, and Brahmās, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, its gods and humans.
ai-sn35:14.2.2_0: But when I did truly understand these six exterior sense fields’ gratification, drawback, and escape in this way for what they are, I announced my supreme perfect awakening in this world with its gods, Māras, and Brahmās, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, its gods and humans.
ai-sn35:14.2.3_0: To me knowledge and insight arose:
ai-sn35:14.2.4_0: ‘My freedom is unshakable; this is my last rebirth; now there’ll be no more future lives.’”

ai-sn35:15.1.3_0: I’ve seen clearly with wisdom the full extent of the eye’s gratification.
ai-sn35:15.1.4_0: I went in search of the eye’s drawback,
ai-sn35:15.1.6_0: I’ve seen clearly with wisdom the full extent of the eye’s drawback.

ai-sn35:15.1.9_0: I’ve seen clearly with wisdom the full extent of escape from the eye.

ai-sn35:15.1.12_0: I went in search of the tongue’s gratification,
ai-sn35:15.1.14_0: I’ve seen clearly with wisdom the full extent of the tongue.
ai-sn35:15.1.15_0: I went in search of the tongue’s drawback,
ai-sn35:15.1.17_0: I’ve seen clearly with wisdom the full extent of the tongue.
ai-sn35:15.1.18_0: I went in search of escape from the tongue,
ai-sn35:15.1.20_0: I’ve seen clearly with wisdom the full extent of tongue ...
ai-sn35:15.1.23_0: I’ve seen clearly with wisdom the full extent of the mind’s gratification.
ai-sn35:15.1.24_0: I went in search of the mind’s drawback,
ai-sn35:15.1.26_0: I’ve seen clearly with wisdom the full extent of the mind’s drawback.
ai-sn35:15.1.27_0: I went in search of escape from the mind,
ai-sn35:15.1.29_0: I’ve seen clearly with wisdom the full extent of escape from the mind.
ai-sn35:15.2.1_0: As long as I didn’t truly understand these six interior sense fields’ gratification, drawback, and escape for what they are, I didn’t announce my supreme perfect awakening ...

ai-sn35:16.1.3_0: I’ve seen clearly with wisdom the full extent of sights.
ai-sn35:16.1.4_0: I went in search of form’s drawback,
ai-sn35:16.1.6_0: I’ve seen clearly with wisdom the full extent of sights.
ai-sn35:16.1.7_0: I went in search of form’s escape,
ai-sn35:16.1.9_0: I’ve seen clearly with wisdom the full extent of sights.
ai-sn35:16.1.14_0: I went in search of the gratification of things,
ai-sn35:16.1.16_0: I’ve seen clearly with wisdom the full extent of thoughts.
ai-sn35:16.1.17_0: I went in search of the drawbacks,
ai-sn35:16.1.19_0: I’ve seen clearly with wisdom the full extent of the drawbacks.
ai-sn35:16.1.20_0: I don’t went in search of escape from things,
ai-sn35:16.1.22_0: I’ve seen clearly with wisdom the full extent of escape from the teachings.
ai-sn35:16.2.1_0: As long as I didn’t truly understand these six interior sense fields’ gratification, drawback, and escape for what they are, I didn’t announce my supreme perfect awakening ...
ai-sn35:16.2.1_1: But when I did truly understand ...
ai-sn35:16.2.2_0: To me knowledge and insight arose:
ai-sn35:16.2.3_0: ‘My freedom is unshakable; this is my last rebirth; now there’ll be no more future lives.’”
ai-sn35:17.1.1_0: “Mendicants, if there were no gratification in the eye, sentient beings wouldn’t love it.
ai-sn35:17.1.2_0: But since there is gratification in the eye, sentient beings do love it.
ai-sn35:17.1.3_0: If the eye had no drawback, sentient beings wouldn’t grow disillusioned with it.
ai-sn35:17.1.4_0: But since the eye has a drawback, sentient beings do grow disillusioned with it.
ai-sn35:17.1.5_0: If there were no escape from the eye, sentient beings wouldn’t escape from it.
ai-sn35:17.1.6_0: But since there is an escape from the eye, sentient beings do escape from it.
ai-sn35:17.1.7_0: If there were no gratification in the ear ...
ai-sn35:17.1.8_0: If there were no gratification in the nose ...
ai-sn35:17.1.9_0: If there were no gratification in the ear ... nose ... tongue ... body ...
ai-sn35:17.1.10_0: But since there is gratification in the ear ... nose ... tongue ... body ...
ai-sn35:17.1.11_0: If the ear ... nose ... tongue ... body ...
ai-sn35:17.1.12_0: But since the ear ... nose ... tongue ... body ...
ai-sn35:17.1.13_0: If there were no escape from the ear ... nose ... tongue ... body ...
ai-sn35:17.1.14_0: But since there is an escape from the tongue, sentient beings do escape from it.
ai-sn35:17.1.15_0: If there were no gratification in the body ...
ai-sn35:17.1.16_0: mind, sentient beings wouldn’t love it.
ai-sn35:17.1.17_0: But since there is gratification in the mind, sentient beings do love it.
ai-sn35:17.1.18_0: If the mind had no drawback, sentient beings wouldn’t grow disillusioned with it.
ai-sn35:17.1.19_0: But since the mind has a drawback, sentient beings do grow disillusioned with it.
ai-sn35:17.1.20_0: If there were no escape from the mind, sentient beings wouldn’t escape from it.
ai-sn35:17.1.21_0: But since there is an escape from the mind, sentient beings do escape from it.
ai-sn35:17.2.1_0: As long as sentient beings don’t truly understand these six interior sense fields’ gratification, drawback, and escape for what they are, they haven’t escaped from this world—with its gods, Māras, and Brahmās, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, its gods and humans—and they don’t live detached, liberated, with a mind free of limits.
ai-sn35:17.2.2_0: But when sentient beings truly understand these six interior sense fields’ gratification, drawback, and escape for what they are, they’ve escaped from this world—with its gods, Māras, and Brahmās, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, its gods and humans—and they live detached, liberated, with a mind free of limits.”
ai-sn35:18.1.1_0: “Mendicants, if there were no gratification in sights, sentient beings wouldn’t love them. ...”
ai-sn35:18.1.2_0: But since there is gratification in sights, sentient beings do love it.
ai-sn35:18.1.3_0: If sights had no drawback, sentient beings wouldn’t grow disillusioned with it.
ai-sn35:18.1.4_0: But since sights have a drawback, sentient beings do grow disillusioned with it.
ai-sn35:18.1.5_0: If there were no escape from sights, sentient beings wouldn’t escape from it.
ai-sn35:18.1.6_0: But since there is an escape from sights, sentient beings do escape from it.
ai-sn35:18.1.7_0: If there were no gratification in sounds ...
ai-sn35:18.1.12_0: But since there is gratification in things, sentient beings do love it.
ai-sn35:18.1.13_0: If the things had no drawback, sentient beings wouldn’t grow disillusioned with it.
ai-sn35:18.1.14_0: But since the things have a drawback, sentient beings do grow disillusioned with it.
ai-sn35:18.1.15_0: If there were no escape from thoughts, sentient beings wouldn’t escape from it.
ai-sn35:18.1.16_0: But since there is an escape from the teachings, sentient beings do escape from it.
ai-sn35:18.2.1_0: As long as sentient beings don’t truly understand these six exterior sense fields’ gratification, drawback, and escape for what they are, they haven’t escaped from this world—with its gods, Māras, and Brahmās, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, its gods and humans—and they don’t live detached, liberated, with a mind free of limits.
ai-sn35:18.2.2_0: But when sentient beings truly understand these six exterior sense fields’ gratification, drawback, and escape for what they are, they’ve escaped from this world—with its gods, Māras, and Brahmās, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, its gods and humans—and they live detached, liberated, with a mind free of limits.”
ai-sn35:18.2.3_0: The sixth offering to an individual.
ai-sn35:19.1.1_0: “Mendicants, if you take pleasure in the eye, you take pleasure in suffering.
ai-sn35:19.1.2_0: If you take pleasure in suffering, I say you’re not exempt from suffering. ...”
ai-sn35:19.1.3_0: If you take pleasure in the ear ...
ai-sn35:19.1.5_0: If you take pleasure in suffering, you take pleasure in suffering.
ai-sn35:19.1.6_0: If you take pleasure in suffering, I say you’re not exempt from suffering.
ai-sn35:19.1.8_0: mind, you take pleasure in suffering.
ai-sn35:19.1.9_0: If you take pleasure in suffering, I say you’re not exempt from suffering.
ai-sn35:19.2.1_0: If you don’t take pleasure in the eye, you don’t take pleasure in suffering.
ai-sn35:19.2.2_0: If you don’t take pleasure in suffering, I say you’re exempt from suffering.

ai-sn35:19.2.5_0: If you don’t take pleasure in the ear ... nose ... tongue ... body ...
ai-sn35:19.2.6_0: If you don’t take pleasure in suffering, I say you’re exempt from suffering.
ai-sn35:19.2.8_0: mind, you don’t take pleasure in suffering.
ai-sn35:19.2.9_0: If you don’t take pleasure in suffering, I say you’re exempt from suffering.”

ai-sn35:20.1.2_0: If you take pleasure in suffering, I say you’re not exempt from suffering. ...”
ai-sn35:20.1.8_0: If you take pleasure in suffering, I say you’re not exempt from suffering.

ai-sn35:20.2.2_0: If you don’t take pleasure in suffering, I say you’re exempt from suffering.”
ai-sn35:20.2.7_0: They don’t take pleasure in thoughts. They don’t take pleasure in suffering.
ai-sn35:20.2.8_0: If you don’t take pleasure in suffering, I say you’re exempt from suffering.”
ai-sn35:21.1.1_0: “Mendicants, the arising, continuation, rebirth, and manifestation of the eye is the arising of suffering, the continuation of diseases, and the manifestation of old age and death.
ai-sn35:21.1.2_0: The arising, continuation, rebirth, and manifestation of the ear ...
ai-sn35:21.1.6_0: and mind is the arising of suffering, the continuation of diseases, and the manifestation of old age and death.
ai-sn35:21.2.1_0: The cessation, settling, and ending of the eye is the cessation of suffering, the settling of diseases, and the ending of old age and death.
ai-sn35:21.2.2_0: The cessation, settling, and ending of the ear,
ai-sn35:21.2.6_0: and mind is the cessation of suffering, the settling of diseases, and the ending of old age and death.”
ai-sn35:22.1.1_0: “Mendicants, the arising, continuation, rebirth, and manifestation of sights is the arising of suffering, the continuation of diseases, and the manifestation of old age and death.
ai-sn35:22.1.2_0: The arising, continuation, rebirth, and manifestation of sounds ...
ai-sn35:22.1.4_0: The arising, continuation, rebirth, and manifestation of tastes,
ai-sn35:22.1.6_0: and thoughts is the arising of suffering, the continuation of diseases, and the manifestation of old age and death.
ai-sn35:22.2.1_0: The cessation, settling, and ending of sights,
ai-sn35:22.2.2_0: The arising, continuation, rebirth, and manifestation of sounds ...
ai-sn35:22.2.4_0: The arising, continuation, rebirth, and manifestation of tastes,
ai-sn35:22.2.6_0: and thoughts is the cessation of suffering, the settling of diseases, and the ending of old age and death.”
ai-sn35:22.2.8_0: The second sub-chapter on Yamaka is finished.

ai-sn35:23.1.2_0: “Mendicants, I will teach you the all.
ai-sn35:23.1.5_0: It’s just the eye and sights, the ear and sounds, the nose and smells, the tongue and tastes, the body and touches, and the mind and thoughts.
ai-sn35:23.1.8_0: ‘I’ll reject this all and describe another all.’ They’d have no grounds for that,
ai-sn35:23.1.9_0: they’d be stumped by questions, and, in addition, they’d get frustrated.
ai-sn35:23.1.11_0: Because they’re out of their element.”
ai-sn35:24.1.1_0: “Mendicants, I will teach you the principle for giving up the all.
ai-sn35:24.1.3_0: And what is the principle for giving up the all?
ai-sn35:24.1.4_0: The eye should be given up. Sights should be given up. Eye consciousness should be given up. Eye contact should be given up. The painful, pleasant, or neutral feeling that arises conditioned by eye contact should also be given up.
ai-sn35:24.1.7_0: you should give up the body.
ai-sn35:24.1.8_0: mind should be given up. Thoughts should be given up. Mind consciousness should be given up. Mind contact should be given up. The painful, pleasant, or neutral feeling that arises conditioned by mind contact should be given up.
ai-sn35:24.1.9_0: This is the principle for giving up the all.”
ai-sn35:25.1.1_0: “Mendicants, I will teach you the principle for giving up the all by direct knowledge and complete understanding.
ai-sn35:25.1.3_0: And what is the principle for giving up the all by direct knowledge and complete understanding?
ai-sn35:25.1.4_0: The eye should be given up by direct knowledge and complete understanding. Sights should be given up by direct knowledge and complete understanding. Eye consciousness should be given up by direct knowledge and complete understanding. Eye contact should be given up by direct knowledge and complete understanding. The painful, pleasant, or neutral feeling that arises conditioned by eye contact should be given up by direct knowledge and complete understanding.

The painful, pleasant, or neutral feeling that arises conditioned by mind contact should be given up by direct knowledge and complete understanding.
ai-sn35:25.1.9_0: This is the principle for giving up the all by direct knowledge and complete understanding.”

ai-sn35:28.1.4_0: What is that everything that is burning?
ai-sn35:28.1.5_1: Sights are burning. Eye consciousness is burning. Eye contact is burning. The painful, pleasant, or neutral feeling that arises conditioned by eye contact is also burning.
ai-sn35:28.1.7_0: Burning with the fires of greed, hate, and delusion. Burning with rebirth, old age, and death, with sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress.
ai-sn35:28.1.8_1: Sights are burning. The painful, pleasant, or neutral feeling that arises conditioned by tongue contact is burning.
ai-sn35:28.1.10_0: Burning with the fires of greed, hate, and delusion. Burning with rebirth, old age, and death, with sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress.

ai-sn35:28.1.13_0: Burning with the fires of greed, hate, and delusion. Burning with rebirth, old age, and death, with sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress.
ai-sn35:28.1.14_0: When they see this, the learned noble disciple is repelled by the eye, repelled by sights, repelled by eye-consciousness, repelled by eye-contact, and repelled by whatever feelings arise because of eye-contact—whether pleasant, painful, or neither-pleasant-nor-painful.
ai-sn35:28.1.15_0: They grow disillusioned with the painful, pleasant, or neutral feeling that arises conditioned by mind contact.
ai-sn35:28.1.16_0: Being disillusioned, desire fades away. When desire fades away they’re freed. When they’re freed, they know they’re freed.
ai-sn35:28.1.17_0: They understand: ‘Rebirth is ended, the spiritual journey has been completed, what had to be done has been done, there is no return to any state of existence.’”

ai-sn35:30.1.1_0: “Mendicants, I will teach you the practice fit for uprooting all identifying.
ai-sn35:30.1.2_0: Listen and pay close attention, I will speak.
ai-sn35:30.1.3_0: And what is the practice fit for uprooting all identifying?
ai-sn35:30.1.4_0: It’s when a mendicant does not identify with the eye, does not identify in the eye, does not identify from the eye, and does not identify: ‘The eye is mine.’
ai-sn35:30.1.5_0: They don’t identify with sights, they don’t identify regarding sights, they don’t identify as sights, and they don’t identify ‘sights are mine.’
ai-sn35:30.1.6_0: They don’t identify with eye consciousness ...
ai-sn35:30.1.7_0: They don’t identify with eye contact ...
ai-sn35:30.1.8_0: They don’t identify with the pleasant, painful, or neutral feeling that arises conditioned by eye contact. They don’t identify regarding that, they don’t identify as that, and they don’t identify ‘that is mine.’ ...
ai-sn35:30.1.9_0: They don’t identify with the ear ... nose ... tongue ...
ai-sn35:30.1.12_0: They don’t identify with the ear ... nose ... tongue ...
ai-sn35:30.1.13_0: They don’t identify with the ear ... nose ... tongue ... body ...
ai-sn35:30.1.14_0: They don’t identify with the mind ...
ai-sn35:30.1.15_0: They don’t identify with thoughts, they don’t identify regarding thoughts, and they don’t identify as thoughts.
ai-sn35:30.1.16_0: They don’t identify with mind consciousness ...
ai-sn35:30.1.17_0: They don’t identify with mind contact ...
ai-sn35:30.1.18_0: They don’t identify with the pleasant, painful, or neutral feeling that arises conditioned by mind contact. They don’t identify in that, they don’t identify from that, and they don’t identify: ‘That is mine.’
ai-sn35:30.1.19_0: They don’t identify with all, they don’t identify regarding all, they don’t identify as all, and they don’t identify ‘all is mine.’
ai-sn35:30.1.20_0: Not identifying, they don’t grasp at anything in the world.
ai-sn35:30.1.21_0: Not grasping, they’re not anxious. Not being anxious, they personally become extinguished.
ai-sn35:30.1.22_0: He understands: ‘Rebirth is ended, the spiritual journey has been completed, what had to be done has been done, there is no return to any state of existence.’
ai-sn35:30.1.23_0: This is the practice fit for uprooting all identifying.”
ai-sn35:31.0.3_0: First: The Practice Conducive to Uprooting
ai-sn35:31.1.1_0: “Mendicants, I will teach you the practice that’s conducive to uprooting all identifying.
ai-sn35:31.1.3_0: And what is the practice fit for uprooting all identifying?
ai-sn35:31.1.4_0: It’s when a mendicant does not identify with the eye, does not identify in the eye, does not identify from the eye, and does not identify: ‘The eye is mine.’
ai-sn35:31.1.6_0: They don’t identify with eye, they don’t identify regarding the eye, sights, eye consciousness, and eye contact. They don’t identify as that, they don’t identify ‘that is mine.’
ai-sn35:31.1.7_0: For whatever you identify with, whatever you identify in, whatever you identify as, and whatever you identify as ‘mine’: that becomes something else.
ai-sn35:31.1.8_0: The world is attached to being, taking pleasure only in being, yet it becomes something else.
ai-sn35:31.1.9_0: They don’t identify with the ear ... nose ... tongue ...

ai-sn35:31.1.15_0: They don’t identify with the mind ...
ai-sn35:31.1.18_0: They don’t identify with the pleasant, painful, or neutral feeling that arises conditioned by mind contact. They don’t identify in that, they don’t identify from that, and they don’t identify: ‘That is mine.’
ai-sn35:31.1.19_0: For whatever you identify with, whatever you identify in, whatever you identify as, and whatever you identify as ‘mine’: that becomes something else.
ai-sn35:31.1.20_0: The world is attached to being, taking pleasure only in being, yet it becomes something else.
ai-sn35:31.1.21_0: The entire spectrum of the dimension of infinite consciousness ...
ai-sn35:31.1.22_0: Not identifying, they don’t grasp at anything in the world.
ai-sn35:31.1.23_0: Not grasping, they’re not anxious. Not being anxious, they personally become extinguished.
ai-sn35:31.1.24_0: He understands: ‘Rebirth is ended, the spiritual journey has been completed, what had to be done has been done, there is no return to any state of existence.’
ai-sn35:31.1.25_0: This is the practice that’s conducive to uprooting all identifying.”

ai-sn35:53.1.2_0: Then a certain monk went to the Fortunate One,
ai-sn35:53.1.3_0: “Sir, how does one know and see so as to give up ignorance and give rise to knowledge?”
ai-sn35:53.2.1_0: “Mendicant, knowing and seeing the eye, sights, eye consciousness, and eye contact as impermanent, ignorance is given up and knowledge arises.
ai-sn35:53.2.2_0: Knowing and seeing form as impermanent, ignorance is given up and knowledge arises.
ai-sn35:53.2.5_0: And also knowing and seeing the pleasant, painful, or neutral feeling that arises conditioned by eye contact as impermanent, ignorance is given up and knowledge arises.
ai-sn35:53.2.10_0: Knowing and seeing the mind, thoughts, mind consciousness, and mind contact as impermanent, ignorance is given up and knowledge arises.
ai-sn35:53.2.11_0: By directly knowing and completely understanding thoughts ...
ai-sn35:53.2.14_0: And also knowing and seeing the pleasant, painful, or neutral feeling that arises conditioned by mind contact as impermanent, ignorance is given up and knowledge arises.
ai-sn35:53.2.15_0: That’s how to know and see so as to give up ignorance and give rise to knowledge.”
ai-sn35:54.1.1_0: “Sir, how does one know and see so that the fetters are given up?”
ai-sn35:54.1.2_0: “Mendicant, knowing and seeing the eye as impermanent, the fetters are given up ...”
ai-sn35:54.1.6_0: And also knowing and seeing the pleasant, painful, or neutral feeling that arises conditioned by eye contact as impermanent, is given up.
ai-sn35:54.1.12_0: By directly knowing and completely understanding thoughts ...
ai-sn35:54.1.15_0: And also knowing and seeing the pleasant, painful, or neutral feeling that arises conditioned by mind contact as impermanent, is given up.
ai-sn35:54.1.16_0: That’s how to know and see so that the fetters are given up.”
ai-sn35:55.1.1_0: “Sir, how does one know and see so that the fetters are uprooted?”
ai-sn35:55.1.2_0: “Mendicant, knowing and seeing the eye as not-self, the fetters are uprooted ...”
ai-sn35:55.1.6_0: And also knowing and seeing the pleasant, painful, or neutral feeling that arises conditioned by eye contact as not-self, the fetters are uprooted.
ai-sn35:55.1.12_0: By directly knowing and completely understanding thoughts ...
ai-sn35:55.1.15_0: And also knowing and seeing the pleasant, painful, or neutral feeling that arises conditioned by mind contact as not-self, all of them are left behind.
ai-sn35:55.1.16_0: That’s how to know and see so that the fetters are uprooted.”

ai-sn35:59.1.13_0: That’s how to know and see so that the underlying tendencies is uprooted.”
ai-sn35:60.1.1_0: “Mendicants, I will teach you the principle for the complete understanding of all grasping.
ai-sn35:60.1.3_0: And what is the principle for the complete understanding of all grasping?
ai-sn35:60.1.4_0: Eye consciousness arises dependent on the eye and sights. The meeting of the three is contact.
ai-sn35:60.1.6_0: Seeing this, a learned noble disciple grows disillusioned with the eye, sights, eye consciousness, eye contact, and feeling.
ai-sn35:60.1.7_0: Being disillusioned, desire fades away. When desire fades away they’re freed. When they are released, they understand: ‘I have completely understood grasping.’
ai-sn35:60.1.9_0: Nose consciousness arises dependent on the nose and smells. ...
ai-sn35:60.1.11_0: Body consciousness arises dependent on the body and touches. ...
ai-sn35:60.1.12_0: mind consciousness arises dependent on the mind and thoughts. The meeting of the three is contact.
ai-sn35:60.1.14_0: Seeing this, a learned noble disciple grows disillusioned with the mind, thoughts, mind consciousness, mind contact, and feeling.
ai-sn35:60.1.15_0: Being disillusioned, desire fades away. When desire fades away they’re freed. When they are released, they understand: ‘I have completely understood grasping.’
ai-sn35:60.1.16_0: This is the principle for the complete understanding of all grasping.”
ai-sn35:61.0.3_0: First: The Depletion of All Fuel
ai-sn35:61.1.1_0: “Mendicants, I will teach you the principle for depleting all fuel.
ai-sn35:61.1.3_0: And what is the principle for depleting all fuel?
ai-sn35:61.1.4_0: Eye consciousness arises dependent on the eye and sights. The meeting of the three is contact.
ai-sn35:61.1.6_0: Seeing this, a learned noble disciple grows disillusioned with the eye, sights, eye consciousness, eye contact, and feeling.
ai-sn35:61.1.7_0: Being disillusioned, desire fades away. When desire fades away they’re freed. When they are released, they understand: ‘My freedom is freed.’ ...
ai-sn35:61.1.9_0: mind consciousness arises dependent on the mind and thoughts. The meeting of the three is contact.
ai-sn35:61.1.11_0: Seeing this, a learned noble disciple grows disillusioned with the mind, thoughts, mind consciousness, mind contact, and feeling.
ai-sn35:61.1.12_0: Being disillusioned, desire fades away. When desire fades away they’re freed. When they are released, they understand: ‘My grasping is grasping.’
ai-sn35:61.1.13_0: This is the principle for depleting all fuel.”
ai-sn35:62.0.3_0: Second: The Depletion of All Fuel
ai-sn35:62.1.1_0: “Mendicants, I will teach you the principle for depleting all fuel.
ai-sn35:62.1.3_0: And what is the principle for depleting all fuel?
ai-sn35:62.2.2_0: Is the eye permanent or impermanent?”
ai-sn35:62.4.1_0: “But if they're impermanent, are they suffering or happiness?”
ai-sn35:62.6.1_0: “But if they're impermanent, suffering, and perishable, are they fit to be regarded thus:
ai-sn35:62.6.2_0: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self’?”
ai-sn35:62.12.1_0: The pleasant, painful, or neutral feeling that arises conditioned by eye contact: is that permanent or impermanent?”
ai-sn35:62.14.9_0: The pleasant, painful, or neutral feeling that arises conditioned by mind contact: is that permanent or impermanent?”
ai-sn35:62.16.1_0: “But if they're impermanent, are they suffering or happiness?”
ai-sn35:62.18.1_0: “But if they're impermanent, suffering, and perishable, are they fit to be regarded thus:
ai-sn35:62.18.2_0: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self’?”
ai-sn35:62.20.1_0: Seeing this, a learned noble disciple grows disillusioned with the eye, sights, eye consciousness, and eye contact.
ai-sn35:62.20.2_0: And they grow disillusioned with the painful, pleasant, or neutral feeling that arises conditioned by eye contact.
ai-sn35:62.20.3_0: They are repelled by the tongue, repelled by tongue-consciousness, repelled by tongue-consciousness, repelled by tongue-contact, and repelled by whatever feelings arise because of tongue-contact—whether pleasant, painful, or neither-pleasant-nor-painful.
ai-sn35:62.20.4_0: They grow disillusioned with the mind, thoughts, mind consciousness, and mind contact.
ai-sn35:62.20.5_0: They grow disillusioned with the painful, pleasant, or neutral feeling that arises conditioned by mind contact.
ai-sn35:62.20.6_0: Being disillusioned, desire fades away. When desire fades away they’re freed. When they’re freed, they know they’re freed.
ai-sn35:62.20.7_0: He understands: ‘Rebirth is ended, the spiritual journey has been completed, what had to be done has been done, there is no return to any state of existence.’
ai-sn35:62.20.8_0: This is the principle for depleting all fuel.”
ai-sn35:62.20.10_0: The first sub-chapter on ignorance is finished.
ai-sn35:62.21.2_0: in two ways the Realized One,
ai-sn35:62.21.4_0: who are completely understood these two things:
ai-sn35:63.1.2_0: Then Venerable Migajāla went up to the Buddha ...
ai-sn35:63.1.4_0: “Sir, they speak of one who lives alone.
ai-sn35:63.1.5_0: How is one who lives alone defined? And how is living with a partner defined?”
ai-sn35:63.2.1_0: “Migajāla, there are sights known by the eye that are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.
ai-sn35:63.2.2_0: If a mendicant approves, welcomes, and keep clinging to them,
ai-sn35:63.2.5_0: When there’s sensual desire there’s a fetter.
ai-sn35:63.2.6_0: A mendicant who is fettered by relishing is said to live with a partner.
ai-sn35:63.2.8_0: There are thoughts known by the mind that are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.
ai-sn35:63.2.9_0: If a mendicant approves, welcomes, and keep clinging to them,
ai-sn35:63.2.12_0: When there’s sensual desire there’s a fetter.
ai-sn35:63.2.13_0: A mendicant who is fettered by relishing is said to live with a partner.
ai-sn35:63.2.14_0: A mendicant who lives like this is said to live with a partner, even if they frequent remote lodgings in the wilderness and the forest that are quiet and still, far from the madding crowd, remote from human settlements, and fit for retreat.
ai-sn35:63.2.15_0: Then they’re said to live with a partner.
ai-sn35:63.2.17_0: For craving is their partner, and they haven’t given it up.
ai-sn35:63.2.18_0: That’s why they’re said to live with a partner.
ai-sn35:63.3.1_0: There are sights known by the eye that are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.
ai-sn35:63.3.2_0: If a mendicant doesn’t approve, welcome, and keep clinging to them, they’re called a mendicant who hasn’t swallowed Māra’s hook.
ai-sn35:63.3.4_0: When there’s no relishing there’s no lust.
ai-sn35:63.3.5_0: When there’s no lust there’s no fetter.
ai-sn35:63.3.6_0: A mendicant who is not fettered by relishing is said to live alone.
ai-sn35:63.3.7_0: There are sounds ... smells ... tastes ... touches ...
ai-sn35:63.3.8_0: thoughts known by the mind that are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.
ai-sn35:63.3.9_0: If a mendicant doesn’t approve, welcome, and keep clinging to them, they’re called a mendicant who hasn’t swallowed Māra’s hook.
ai-sn35:63.3.11_0: When there’s no relishing there’s no lust.
ai-sn35:63.3.12_0: When there’s no lust there’s no fetter.
ai-sn35:63.3.13_0: A mendicant who is not fettered by relishing is said to live alone.
ai-sn35:63.3.14_0: A mendicant who lives like this is said to live alone, even if they live in the neighborhood of a village crowded by monks, nuns, laymen, and laywomen; by rulers and their ministers, and teachers of other paths and their disciples.
ai-sn35:63.3.17_0: For craving is given up in the second
ai-sn35:63.3.18_0: That’s why they’re said to live alone.”
ai-sn35:64.1.1_0: Then Venerable Migajāla went up to the Buddha ...
ai-sn35:64.1.3_0: “Sir, may the Buddha please teach me Dhamma in brief. When I’ve heard it, I’ll live alone, withdrawn, diligent, keen, and resolute.”
ai-sn35:64.2.1_0: “Migajāla, there are sights known by the eye that are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.
ai-sn35:64.2.2_0: If a mendicant approves, welcomes, and keep clinging to them,
ai-sn35:64.2.4_0: Relishing is the origin of suffering, I say.
ai-sn35:64.2.5_0: There are sounds ... smells ... tastes ... touches ...
ai-sn35:64.2.6_0: thoughts known by the mind that are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.
ai-sn35:64.2.7_0: If a mendicant approves, welcomes, and keep clinging to them,
ai-sn35:64.2.9_0: Relishing is the origin of suffering, I say.
ai-sn35:64.3.1_0: There are sights known by the eye that are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.
ai-sn35:64.3.2_0: If a mendicant doesn’t approve, welcome, and keep clinging to them, they’re called a mendicant who hasn’t swallowed Māra’s hook.
ai-sn35:64.3.3_0: When relishing ceases, suffering ceases, I say.
ai-sn35:64.3.4_0: There are sounds ... smells ... tastes ... touches ...
ai-sn35:64.3.5_0: thoughts known by the mind that are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.
ai-sn35:64.3.6_0: If a mendicant doesn’t approve, welcome, and keep clinging to them, they’re called a mendicant who hasn’t swallowed Māra’s hook.
ai-sn35:64.3.7_0: When relishing ceases, suffering ceases, I say.”
ai-sn35:64.4.1_0: And then Venerable Migajāla approved and agreed with what the Buddha said. He got up from his seat, bowed, and respectfully circled the Buddha, keeping him on his right, before leaving.
ai-sn35:64.4.2_0: Then Migajāla, living alone, withdrawn, diligent, keen, and resolute, soon realized the supreme end of the spiritual path in this very life. He lived having achieved with his own insight the goal for which gentlemen rightly go forth from the lay life to homelessness.
ai-sn35:64.4.3_0: He understood: “Rebirth is ended; the spiritual journey has been completed; what had to be done has been done; there is no return to any state of existence.”
ai-sn35:64.4.4_0: And Venerable Migajāla became one of the perfected.
ai-sn35:65.0.3_0: Samiddhi’s Question About the First Samiddhi
ai-sn35:65.1.1_0: At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha, in the Bamboo Grove, the squirrels’ feeding ground.
ai-sn35:65.1.2_0: Then Venerable Samiddhi went up to the Buddha ...
ai-sn35:65.1.3_0: said this to the Fortunate One:
ai-sn35:65.1.4_0: “Sir, they speak of this thing called ‘Māra’.
ai-sn35:65.1.5_0: How do we define Māra or what is known as Māra?”
ai-sn35:65.2.1_0: “Samiddhi, where there is the eye, sights, eye consciousness, and phenomena to be known by eye consciousness, there is Māra or what is known as Māra.
ai-sn35:65.2.2_0: Where there is the ear, sounds, ear consciousness, and phenomena to be known by ear consciousness, there is Māra or what is known as Māra.
ai-sn35:65.2.3_0: Where there is the nose, smells, nose consciousness, and phenomena to be known by nose consciousness, there is Māra or what is known as Māra.
ai-sn35:65.2.4_0: Where there is the tongue, tastes, tongue consciousness, and phenomena to be known by tongue consciousness, there is Māra or what is known as Māra.
ai-sn35:65.2.5_0: Where there is the body, touches, body consciousness, and phenomena to be known by body consciousness, there is Māra or what is known as Māra.
ai-sn35:65.2.6_0: Where there is the mind, thoughts, mind consciousness, and phenomena to be known by mind consciousness, there is Māra or what is known as Māra.
ai-sn35:65.3.1_0: Where there is no eye, no sights, no eye consciousness, and no phenomena to be known by eye consciousness, there is no Māra or what is known as Māra.
ai-sn35:65.3.6_0: Where there is no mind, no thoughts, no mind consciousness, and no phenomena to be known by mind consciousness, there is no Māra or what is known as Māra.”
ai-sn35:66.1.1_0: “Sir, they speak of this thing called ‘sentience’.
ai-sn35:66.1.2_0: How do we define a sentient being or what is known as a sentient being?” ...
ai-sn35:67.1.1_0: “Sir, they speak of this thing called ‘suffering’.
ai-sn35:67.1.2_0: How do we define suffering or what is known as suffering?” ...
ai-sn35:68.1.1_0: “Sir, they speak of this thing called ‘the world’.
ai-sn35:68.1.2_0: How do we define the world or what is known as the world?”
ai-sn35:68.1.3_0: “Samiddhi, where there is the eye, sights, eye consciousness, and phenomena to be known by eye consciousness, there is the world or what is known as the world.
ai-sn35:68.1.4_0: Where there is the ear ... nose ... tongue ... body ...
ai-sn35:68.1.5_0: Where there is the mind, thoughts, mind consciousness, and phenomena to be known by mind consciousness, there is the world or what is known as the world.
ai-sn35:68.2.1_0: Where there is no eye, no sights, no eye consciousness, and no phenomena to be known by eye consciousness, there is no world or what is known as the world.
ai-sn35:68.2.2_0: Where there is no ear ... nose ... tongue ... body ...
ai-sn35:68.2.3_0: Where there is no mind, no thoughts, no mind consciousness, and no phenomena to be known by mind consciousness, there is no world or what is known as the world.”
ai-sn35:68.2.4_0: The sixth offering to an individual.
ai-sn35:69.1.1_0: At one time the venerables Sāriputta and Upasena were staying near Rājagaha in the Cool Wood, under the Snake’s Hood Grotto.
ai-sn35:69.1.2_0: Now at that time a viper fell on Upasena’s body,
ai-sn35:69.1.4_0: “Come, reverends, lift this body onto a cot and carry it outside
ai-sn35:69.2.1_0: When he said this, Sāriputta said to him,
ai-sn35:69.2.2_0: “But we don’t see any impairment in your body or deterioration of your faculties.
ai-sn35:69.2.3_0: But then venerable Upavāna said this:
ai-sn35:69.2.4_0: ‘Come, reverends, lift this body onto a cot and carry it outside
ai-sn35:69.2.7_0: “Reverend Sāriputta, there may be an impairment in body or deterioration of faculties for someone who thinks:
ai-sn35:69.2.9_0: Or ‘I am the ear ... nose ... tongue ... body ...’
ai-sn35:69.2.10_0: Or ‘I am the mind’ or ‘the mind is mine.’
ai-sn35:69.2.11_0: Even if they were to decay and perish.
ai-sn35:69.2.12_0: But I don’t think like that.
ai-sn35:69.2.15_0: Or ‘I am the mind’ or ‘the mind is mine.’
ai-sn35:69.2.16_0: So why would there be an impairment in my body or deterioration of my faculties?”
ai-sn35:69.3.1_0: “That must be because Venerable Upasena has long ago totally eradicated ego, possessiveness, and the underlying tendency to conceit.
ai-sn35:69.3.2_0: That’s why it doesn’t occur to you:
ai-sn35:69.3.5_0: Or ‘I am the mind’ or ‘the mind is mine.’”
ai-sn35:69.3.6_0: Then those mendicants lifted Upasena’s body onto a cot and carried it outside.
ai-sn35:69.3.7_0: And his body was scattered right there
ai-sn35:70.1.1_0: Then Venerable Upavāṇa went up to the Buddha ...
ai-sn35:70.1.3_0: “Sir, they speak of ‘a teaching visible in this very life’.
ai-sn35:70.1.4_0: In what way is the teaching visible in this very life, immediately effective, inviting inspection, relevant, so that sensible people can know it for themselves?”
ai-sn35:70.2.2_0: There is desire for sights in them, and they understand that.
ai-sn35:70.2.4_0: There is desire for sights in them, and they understand that.
ai-sn35:70.2.5_0: this is how the teaching is visible in this very life, immediately effective, inviting inspection, relevant, so that sensible people can know it for themselves.
ai-sn35:70.3.1_0: Next, take a mendicant who hears ... smells ... tastes ... touches ...
ai-sn35:70.3.2_0: There is desire for tastes in them, and they understand that.
ai-sn35:70.3.4_0: There is desire for tastes in them, and they understand that.
ai-sn35:70.3.4_1: this is how the teaching is visible in this very life, immediately effective, inviting inspection, relevant, so that sensible people can know it for themselves.
ai-sn35:70.4.1_0: Next, take a mendicant who knows a thought with their mind. They experience both the thought and the desire for the thought.
ai-sn35:70.4.2_0: There is desire for thoughts in them, and they understand that.
ai-sn35:70.4.4_0: There is desire for thoughts in them, and they understand that.
ai-sn35:70.4.5_0: this is how the teaching is visible in this very life, immediately effective, inviting inspection, relevant, so that sensible people can know it for themselves.

ai-sn35:70.5.2_0: There is no desire for sights in them, and they understand that.
ai-sn35:70.5.4_0: There is no desire for sights in them, and they understand that.
ai-sn35:70.5.5_0: this is how the teaching is visible in this very life, immediately effective, inviting inspection, relevant, so that sensible people can know it for themselves.
ai-sn35:70.6.1_0: Next, take a mendicant who hears ... smells ... tastes ... touches ...
ai-sn35:70.6.1_1: There is no desire for tastes ...
ai-sn35:70.7.1_0: Next, take a mendicant who knows a thought with their mind. They experience both the thought and the desire for the thought.
ai-sn35:70.7.2_0: There is no desire for thoughts in them, and they understand that.
ai-sn35:70.7.4_0: There is no desire for thoughts in them, and they understand that.
ai-sn35:70.7.5_0: this is how the teaching is visible in this very life, immediately effective, inviting inspection, relevant, so that sensible people can know it for themselves.”
ai-sn35:71.1.1_0: “Mendicants, anyone who doesn’t truly understand the six fields of contacts’ origin, ending, gratification, drawback, and escape
ai-sn35:71.1.2_0: has not completed the spiritual journey and is far from this teaching and training.”
ai-sn35:71.2.1_0: When he said this, one of the mendicants asked the Buddha,
ai-sn35:71.2.3_0: For I don’t truly understand the six fields of contacts’ origin, ending, gratification, drawback, and escape.”
ai-sn35:71.3.2_0: Do you regard the eye like this: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self’?”
ai-sn35:71.5.1_0: “Good, mendicant! And regarding the eye, you will truly see clearly with right wisdom that: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self.’
ai-sn35:71.5.2_0: Just this is the end of suffering.
ai-sn35:71.5.3_0: Do you regard the ear ... nose ... tongue ... body ...
ai-sn35:71.7.1_0: “Good, mendicant! And regarding the ear ... nose ... tongue ... body ...
ai-sn35:71.7.2_0: Just this is the end of suffering.
ai-sn35:71.7.3_0: Do you regard the mind like this: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self’?”
ai-sn35:71.9.1_0: “Good, mendicant! And regarding the mind, you will truly see clearly with right wisdom that: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self.’
ai-sn35:71.9.2_0: Just this is the end of suffering.”
ai-sn35:72.1.1_0: “Mendicants, anyone who doesn’t truly understand the six fields of contacts’ origin, ending, gratification, drawback, and escape
ai-sn35:72.1.2_0: has not completed the spiritual journey and is far from this teaching and training.”
ai-sn35:72.2.1_0: When he said this, one of the mendicants asked the Buddha,
ai-sn35:72.2.3_0: For I don’t truly understand the six fields of contacts’ origin, ending, gratification, drawback, and escape.”
ai-sn35:72.3.2_0: Do you regard the eye like this: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self’?”
ai-sn35:72.5.1_0: “Good, mendicant! And regarding the eye, you will truly see clearly with right wisdom that: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self.’
ai-sn35:72.5.2_0: In this way you will give up the first field of contact, so that there are no more future lives.
ai-sn35:72.6.1_0: Do you regard the ear ... nose ... tongue ... body ...
ai-sn35:72.8.1_0: “Good, mendicant! And regarding the ear ... nose ... tongue ... body ...
ai-sn35:72.8.1_1: In this way you will give up the fourth field of contact, so that there are no more future lives.
ai-sn35:72.9.1_0: Do you regard the mind like this: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self’?”
ai-sn35:72.11.1_0: “Good, mendicant! And regarding the mind, you will truly see clearly with right wisdom that: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self.’
ai-sn35:72.11.2_0: In this way you will give up the sixth field of contact, so that there are no more future lives.”
ai-sn35:73.1.1_0: “Mendicants, anyone who doesn’t truly understand the six fields of contacts’ origin, ending, gratification, drawback, and escape
ai-sn35:73.1.2_0: has not completed the spiritual journey and is far from this teaching and training.”
ai-sn35:73.2.1_0: When he said this, one of the mendicants asked the Buddha,
ai-sn35:73.2.3_0: For I don’t truly understand the six fields of contacts’ origin, ending, gratification, drawback, and escape.”
ai-sn35:73.3.2_0: Is the eye permanent or impermanent?”

ai-sn35:73.7.1_0: “But if they're impermanent, suffering, and perishable, are they fit to be regarded thus:
ai-sn35:73.7.2_0: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self’?”

ai-sn35:73.15.1_0: “Seeing this, a learned noble disciple grows disillusioned with the eye, ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind.
ai-sn35:73.15.2_0: Being disillusioned, desire fades away. When desire fades away they’re freed. When they’re freed, they know they’re freed.
ai-sn35:73.15.3_0: They understand: ‘Rebirth is ended, the spiritual journey has been completed, what had to be done has been done, there is no return to any state of existence.’”
ai-sn35:73.15.5_0: The second sub-chapter on lying down is finished.

ai-sn35:74.1.2_0: Then a mendicant went up to the Buddha
ai-sn35:74.1.3_0: “Sir, in such-and-such a monastery there is a sick monk who is sick, suffering, gravely ill.
ai-sn35:74.1.4_0: Please go to him out of compassion.”
ai-sn35:74.2.1_0: When the Buddha heard that the mendicant was junior and ill, understanding that he was not well-known, he went to him.
ai-sn35:74.2.2_0: That mendicant saw the Buddha coming off in the distance
ai-sn35:74.2.3_0: and tried to rise on his cot.
ai-sn35:74.2.4_0: The Buddha said to that monk,
ai-sn35:74.2.5_0: “It’s all right, mendicant, don’t get up.
ai-sn35:74.2.6_0: There are some seats spread out by others, I will sit there.”
ai-sn35:74.2.7_0: He sat on the seat spread out
ai-sn35:74.2.9_0: “I hope you’re keeping well, mendicant; I hope you’re alright. I hope that your pain is fading, not growing, that its fading is evident, not its growing.”
ai-sn35:74.3.1_0: “Sir, I’m not keeping well, I’m not alright. The pain is terrible and growing, not fading; its growing is evident, not its fading.”
ai-sn35:74.4.1_0: “I hope you don’t have any remorse or regret?”
ai-sn35:74.5.1_0: “Indeed, sir, I have no little remorse and regret.”
ai-sn35:74.6.1_0: “I hope you have no reason to blame yourself when it comes to ethical conduct?”
ai-sn35:74.8.1_0: “In that case, mendicant, why do you have remorse and regret?”
ai-sn35:74.9.1_0: “Because I understand that the Buddha has not taught the Dhamma merely for the sake of ethical purity.”
ai-sn35:74.10.1_0: “Certainly not you understand the meaning of my ethics, since you understand the meaning of what the teaching, what exactly do you understand?”
ai-sn35:74.11.1_0: “I understand that the Buddha has taught the Dhamma for the purpose of dispassion.”
ai-sn35:74.12.2_0: It’s good that you understand that I’ve taught the Dhamma for the purpose of the fading away of greed.
ai-sn35:74.12.3_0: For I’ve taught the Dhamma for the purpose of dispassion.
ai-sn35:74.12.5_0: Is the eye permanent or impermanent?”
ai-sn35:74.14.1_0: “Do you regard the Realized One as possessing attachments ...
ai-sn35:74.16.1_0: “But if they're impermanent, are they suffering or happiness?”
ai-sn35:74.18.1_0: “But if they're impermanent, suffering, and perishable, are they fit to be regarded thus:
ai-sn35:74.18.2_0: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self’?”
ai-sn35:74.20.1_0: “Seeing this, a learned noble disciple grows disillusioned with the eye ... ear ... nose ... tongue ... body ...
ai-sn35:74.20.1_1: They grow disillusioned with the mind,
ai-sn35:74.20.2_0: Being disillusioned, desire fades away. When desire fades away they’re freed. When they’re freed, they know they’re freed.
ai-sn35:74.20.3_0: They understand: ‘Rebirth is ended ... there is no return to any state of existence.’”
ai-sn35:74.21.1_0: That is what the Buddha said.
ai-sn35:74.21.2_0: Satisfied, that mendicant was happy with what the Buddha said.
ai-sn35:74.21.3_0: And while this discourse was being spoken, the stainless, immaculate vision of the Dhamma arose in that mendicant:
ai-sn35:74.21.4_0: “Anything that has a beginning has an end.”
ai-sn35:75.1.1_0: Then a mendicant went up to the Buddha ... and asked him,
ai-sn35:75.1.2_0: “Sir, in such-and-such a monastery there is a sick monk who is sick, suffering, gravely ill.
ai-sn35:75.1.3_0: Please go to him out of compassion.”
ai-sn35:75.2.1_0: When the Buddha heard that the mendicant was junior and ill, understanding that he was not well-known, he went to him.
ai-sn35:75.2.2_0: That mendicant saw the Buddha coming off in the distance
ai-sn35:75.2.3_0: and tried to rise on his cot.
ai-sn35:75.2.4_0: The Buddha said to that monk,
ai-sn35:75.2.5_0: “It’s all right, mendicant, don’t get up.
ai-sn35:75.2.6_0: There are some seats spread out by others, I will sit there.”
ai-sn35:75.2.7_0: He sat on the seat spread out and said to the mendicant,
ai-sn35:75.2.8_0: “I hope you’re keeping well, mendicant; I hope you’re alright. I hope that your pain is fading, not growing, that its fading is evident, not its growing.”
ai-sn35:75.3.1_0: “Sir, I’m not keeping well, I’m not alright. ...
ai-sn35:75.4.1_0: “In that case, mendicant, why do you have remorse and regret?”
ai-sn35:75.5.1_0: “Because I understand that the Buddha has not taught the Dhamma merely for the sake of ethical purity.”
ai-sn35:75.6.1_0: “Certainly not you understand the meaning of my ethics, since you understand the meaning of what the teaching, what exactly do you understand?”
ai-sn35:75.7.1_0: “I understand that the Buddha has taught the Dhamma for the purpose of complete extinguishment by not grasping.”
ai-sn35:75.8.2_0: It’s good that you understand that I’ve taught the Dhamma for the purpose of complete extinguishment by not grasping.
ai-sn35:75.8.3_0: For that is indeed the purpose.
ai-sn35:75.9.2_0: Is the eye permanent or impermanent?”
ai-sn35:75.11.1_0: “Do you regard the Realized One as possessing attachments ...
ai-sn35:75.11.9_0: The pleasant, painful, or neutral feeling that arises conditioned by mind contact: is that permanent or impermanent?”
ai-sn35:75.13.1_0: “But if they're impermanent, are they suffering or happiness?”
ai-sn35:75.15.1_0: “But if they're impermanent, suffering, and perishable, are they fit to be regarded thus:
ai-sn35:75.15.2_0: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self’?”
ai-sn35:75.17.1_0: “Seeing this, a learned noble disciple grows disillusioned with the eye ... ear ... nose ... tongue ... body ...
ai-sn35:75.17.5_0: They grow disillusioned with the painful, pleasant, or neutral feeling that arises conditioned by mind contact.
ai-sn35:75.17.6_0: Being disillusioned, desire fades away. When desire fades away they’re freed. When they’re freed, they know they’re freed.
ai-sn35:75.17.7_0: They understand: ‘Rebirth is ended, the spiritual journey has been completed, what had to be done has been done, there is no return to any state of existence.’”
ai-sn35:75.18.1_0: That is what the Buddha said.
ai-sn35:75.18.2_0: Satisfied, that mendicant was happy with what the Buddha said.
ai-sn35:75.18.3_0: And while this discourse was being spoken, the mind of that mendicant was freed from defilements by not grasping.
ai-sn35:76.1.1_0: The Venerable Rādha went up to the Buddha ...
ai-sn35:76.1.3_0: “Sir, may the Buddha please teach me Dhamma in brief. When I’ve heard it, I’ll live alone, withdrawn, diligent, keen, and resolute.”
ai-sn35:76.1.4_0: “Rādha, you should give up desire for what is impermanent.
ai-sn35:76.1.8_0: And the pleasant, painful, or neutral feeling that arises conditioned by eye contact is also impermanent.
ai-sn35:76.1.8_1: You should give up desire for it.
ai-sn35:76.1.11_0: you should give up desire for them.
ai-sn35:76.1.15_0: The painful, pleasant, or neutral feeling that arises conditioned by mind contact is also impermanent.
ai-sn35:76.1.15_1: You should give up desire for it.
ai-sn35:76.1.16_0: You should give up desire for what is impermanent.”
ai-sn35:77.1.1_0: “Rādha, you should give up desire for what is suffering. ...”
ai-sn35:77.1.3_0: The eye is suffering: you should give up desire for it.
ai-sn35:77.1.7_0: The painful, pleasant, or neutral feeling that arises conditioned by eye contact is also suffering: you should give up desire for it.
ai-sn35:77.1.12_0: The pleasant, painful, or neutral feeling that arises conditioned by mind contact is also suffering.
ai-sn35:77.1.12_1: You should give up desire for it.
ai-sn35:77.1.13_0: You should give up desire for what is suffering.”
ai-sn35:78.1.1_0: “Rādha, you should give up desire for what is not-self. ...”
ai-sn35:78.1.3_0: The eye, Rādha, you should give up desire for what is not-self.
ai-sn35:78.1.7_0: And the painful is also a condition for eye contact.
ai-sn35:78.1.12_0: The pleasant, painful, or neutral feeling that arises conditioned by mind contact is also not-self.
ai-sn35:78.1.12_1: You should give up desire for it.
ai-sn35:78.1.13_0: Rādha, you should give up desire for what is not-self.”
ai-sn35:79.1.1_0: Then a mendicant went up to the Buddha
ai-sn35:79.1.3_0: “Sir, is there one thing such that by giving it up a mendicant gives up ignorance and gives rise to knowledge?”
ai-sn35:79.3.1_0: “But sir, what is that one thing gives up ignorance and gives rise to knowledge?”
ai-sn35:79.4.1_0: “Ignorance is one thing such that by giving it up a mendicant gives up ignorance and gives rise to knowledge.”
ai-sn35:79.5.1_0: “But how does a mendicant know and see so as to give up ignorance and give rise to knowledge?”
ai-sn35:79.6.1_0: “When a mendicant knows and sees the eye, sights, eye consciousness, and eye contact as impermanent, ignorance is given up and knowledge arises.
ai-sn35:79.6.2_0: And also knowing and seeing the pleasant, painful, or neutral feeling that arises conditioned by eye contact as impermanent, ignorance is given up and knowledge arises. ...
ai-sn35:79.6.3_0: Knowing and seeing the mind, thoughts, mind consciousness, and mind contact as impermanent, ignorance is given up and knowledge arises.
ai-sn35:79.6.4_0: And also knowing and seeing the pleasant, painful, or neutral feeling that arises conditioned by mind contact as impermanent, ignorance is given up and knowledge arises.
ai-sn35:79.6.5_0: That’s how a mendicant knows and sees so as to give up ignorance and give rise to knowledge.”
ai-sn35:79.6.6_0: The sixth offering to an individual.
ai-sn35:80.1.1_0: Then a mendicant went up to the Buddha ... and asked him,
ai-sn35:80.1.2_0: “Sir, is there one thing such that by giving it up a mendicant gives up ignorance and gives rise to knowledge?”
ai-sn35:80.3.1_0: “But sir, what is that one thing gives up ignorance and gives rise to knowledge?”
ai-sn35:80.4.1_0: “Ignorance is one thing such that by giving it up a mendicant gives up ignorance and gives rise to knowledge.”
ai-sn35:80.5.1_0: “But how does a mendicant know and see so as to give up ignorance and give rise to knowledge?”
ai-sn35:80.6.3_0: When a mendicant has heard that
ai-sn35:80.6.5_0: they directly know all things. Having completely understood all things, they see everything that’s impermanent, perishing, and change of vision.
ai-sn35:80.6.8_0: And they also see the pleasant, painful, or neutral feeling that arises conditioned by eye contact as other.
ai-sn35:80.6.12_0: And they also see the pleasant, painful, or neutral feeling that arises conditioned by mind contact as other.
ai-sn35:80.6.13_0: That’s how a mendicant knows and sees so as to give up ignorance and give rise to knowledge.”
ai-sn35:81.1.1_0: Then several mendicants went up to the Buddha ...
ai-sn35:81.1.2_0: “Sir, sometimes wanderers who follow other paths ask us:
ai-sn35:81.1.3_0: ‘Reverends, what’s the purpose of leading the spiritual life under the ascetic Gotama?’
ai-sn35:81.1.5_0: ‘The purpose of leading the spiritual life under the Buddha is to completely understand suffering.’
ai-sn35:81.1.6_0: Answering this way, we trust that we repeat what the Buddha has said, and don’t misrepresent him with an untruth. We trust our explanation is in line with the teaching, and that there are no legitimate grounds for rebuke or criticism.”
ai-sn35:81.2.1_0: “Indeed, in answering this way you repeat what I’ve said, and don’t misrepresent me with an untruth. Your explanation is in line with the teaching, and there are no legitimate grounds for rebuke or criticism.
ai-sn35:81.2.2_0: For the purpose of leading the spiritual life under me is to completely understand suffering.
ai-sn35:81.2.3_0: If wanderers who follow other paths were to ask you:
ai-sn35:81.2.6_0: ‘Reverends, the eye is suffering. The purpose of leading the spiritual life under the Buddha is to completely understand this.
ai-sn35:81.2.8_0: The pleasant, painful, or neutral feeling that arises conditioned by eye contact is also suffering.
ai-sn35:81.2.9_0: The purpose of leading the spiritual life under the Buddha is to completely understand this.
ai-sn35:81.2.11_0: The pleasant, painful, or neutral feeling that arises conditioned by mind contact is also suffering.
ai-sn35:81.2.12_0: The purpose of leading the spiritual life under the Buddha is to completely understand this.
ai-sn35:81.2.13_0: This is that suffering. The purpose of leading the spiritual life under the Buddha is to completely understand this.’
ai-sn35:81.2.14_0: When questioned by wanderers who follow other paths, that’s how you should answer them.”
ai-sn35:82.1.1_0: Then a mendicant went up to the Buddha ... and asked him,
ai-sn35:82.2.1_0: “Sir, they speak of this thing called ‘the world’.
ai-sn35:82.2.3_0: “It wears away, mendicant, that’s why it’s called ‘the world’.
ai-sn35:82.2.4_0: And what is the reason why?
ai-sn35:82.2.6_0: Sights ... eye consciousness ... eye contact is wearing away. The painful, pleasant, or neutral feeling that arises conditioned by eye contact is also wearing away.
ai-sn35:82.2.8_0: The mind ... thoughts ... mind consciousness ... mind contact is wearing away. The painful, pleasant, or neutral feeling that arises conditioned by mind contact is also wearing away.
ai-sn35:82.2.9_0: It wears away, that’s why it’s called ‘the world’.”
ai-sn35:83.1.1_0: And then Venerable Phagguna went up to the Buddha ... and said to him:
ai-sn35:83.2.1_0: “Sir, suppose someone were to describe the Buddhas of the past who have become completely extinguished, cut off proliferation, cut off the track, finished off the cycle, and transcended suffering. Does the eye exist by which they could be described?
ai-sn35:83.2.2_0: Does the ear ... nose ... tongue ... body exist ...?
ai-sn35:83.2.3_0: Does the mind exist by which they could be described?”
ai-sn35:83.3.1_0: “Phagguna, suppose someone were to describe the Buddhas of the past who have become completely extinguished, cut off proliferation, cut off the track, finished off the cycle, and transcended suffering. The eye does not exist by which they could be described.
ai-sn35:83.3.2_0: The ear ... nose ... tongue ... body does not exist ...
ai-sn35:83.3.3_0: The mind that’s to be found through which they could be described.”
ai-sn35:83.3.5_0: The third sub-chapter on sickness is finished.
ai-sn35:83.4.3_0: And two on account of ignorance,
ai-sn35:83.4.4_0: And the world is hungered by the world.
ai-sn35:84.1.2_0: Then Venerable Ānanda went up to the Buddha, bowed, and sat down to one side.
ai-sn35:84.1.2_1: After the meal, on his return from alms-round, he went to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and told him what had happened.
ai-sn35:84.2.1_0: “Sir, they speak of this thing called ‘the world’.
ai-sn35:84.2.3_0: “Ānanda, that which wears out is called the world in the training of the Noble One.
ai-sn35:84.2.4_0: And what inspect is subject to old-age?
ai-sn35:84.2.5_0: The eye, sights, eye consciousness, and eye contact are liable to fall apart. And the painful, pleasant, or neutral feeling that arises conditioned by eye contact is also liable to world.
ai-sn35:84.2.5_1: For the one who contrary to the Teaching ...
ai-sn35:84.2.6_1: For the one who contrary to the Teaching ...
ai-sn35:84.2.7_0: The mind ... thoughts ... mind consciousness ... mind contact wears out. The painful, pleasant, or neutral feeling that arises conditioned by mind contact also wears out.
ai-sn35:84.2.8_0: Whatever world is called ‘the world in the training of the Noble One.’”
ai-sn35:85.1.1_0: And then Venerable Ānanda ... said to the Buddha:
ai-sn35:85.1.2_0: “Sir, they say that ‘the world is empty’.
ai-sn35:85.1.3_0: What does the saying ‘the world is empty’ refer to?”
ai-sn35:85.1.4_0: “Ānanda, they say that ‘the world is empty’ because it’s empty of self or what belongs to self.
ai-sn35:85.1.5_0: And what is empty of self or what belongs to self?
ai-sn35:85.1.6_0: The eye is empty or self or what belongs to self.
ai-sn35:85.1.7_0: sights, eye consciousness, and eye contact are empty of self or what belongs to self. ...
ai-sn35:85.1.8_0: The pleasant, painful, or neutral feeling that arises conditioned by mind contact is also empty of self or what belongs to self.
ai-sn35:85.1.9_0: They say that ‘the world is empty’ because it’s empty of self or what belongs to self.”
ai-sn35:86.1.1_0: After the meal, on his return from alms-round, he went to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and told him what had happened.
ai-sn35:86.1.2_0: “Sir, may the Buddha please teach me Dhamma in brief. When I’ve heard it, I’ll live alone, withdrawn, diligent, keen, and resolute.”

ai-sn35:86.24.1_0: “Seeing this, a learned noble disciple grows disillusioned with the eye ... ear ... nose ... tongue ... body ...
