ai-sn35:87.1.1_0: At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha, in the Bamboo Grove, the squirrels’ feeding ground.
ai-sn35:87.1.2_0: At that time Venerable Sāriputta and Venerable Mahācunda were staying on the Vulture Peak.
ai-sn35:87.1.3_0: Now at that time Venerable Channa was sick, suffering, gravely ill.
ai-sn35:87.1.4_0: Then in the late afternoon, Venerable Sāriputta came out of retreat and went to Venerable Mahācunda.
ai-sn35:87.1.4_1: and after going, he said this to venerable Mahā Cunda:
ai-sn35:87.1.5_0: “Come, Reverend Cunda, let’s go to see Venerable Channa and ask about his illness.”
ai-sn35:87.2.1_0: Then Sāriputta and Mahācunda went to see Channa.
ai-sn35:87.2.1_1: They sat down on the seat spread out,
ai-sn35:87.2.2_0: “I hope you’re keeping well, Reverend Channa; I hope you’re alright. I hope that your pain is fading, not growing, that its fading is evident, not its growing.”
ai-sn35:87.3.1_0: “Reverend Sāriputta, I’m not keeping well, I’m not alright. The pain is terrible and growing, not fading; its growing is evident, not its fading.
ai-sn35:87.3.2_0: like a strong man was drilling into my head with a sharp point.
ai-sn35:87.3.2_1: In the same way, in excessive winds raged inside my head.
ai-sn35:87.3.3_0: I’m not keeping well, I’m not alright. ...
ai-sn35:87.3.4_0: like a strong man was tightening a tough leather strap around my head.
ai-sn35:87.3.4_1: so did the head excessively emaciated,
ai-sn35:87.3.5_0: I’m not keeping well, I’m not alright. ...
ai-sn35:87.3.6_0: like a deft butcher or their apprentice was slicing my belly open with a meat cleaver.
ai-sn35:87.3.6_1: so excessive winds cut through my stomach.
ai-sn35:87.3.7_0: I’m not keeping well, I’m not alright. ...
ai-sn35:87.3.8_0: like two strong men grabbing a weaker man by the arms to burn and scorch him on a pit of glowing coals.
ai-sn35:87.3.8_1: In the same way, reverend, there was an excessive fever inside the body.
ai-sn35:87.3.9_0: I’m not keeping well, I’m not alright. The pain is terrible and growing, not fading; its growing is evident, not its fading.
ai-sn35:87.3.10_0: Reverend Sāriputta, I will slit my wrists. I don’t wish to live.”
ai-sn35:87.4.2_0: Venerable Channa, keep going! We want you to keep going.
ai-sn35:87.4.3_0: If you don’t have any suitable food, we’ll find it for you.
ai-sn35:87.4.4_0: If you don’t have suitable medicine, we’ll find it for you.
ai-sn35:87.4.5_0: If you don’t have a capable carer, we’ll find one for you.
ai-sn35:87.4.7_0: Venerable Channa, keep going! We want you to keep going.”
ai-sn35:87.5.1_0: “Reverend Sāriputta, it’s not that I don’t have suitable food;
ai-sn35:87.5.5_0: It’s not that I don’t have a capable carer;
ai-sn35:87.5.6_0: I do have a capable carer.
ai-sn35:87.5.7_0: Moreover, for a long time I have served the Teacher with love, not without love.
ai-sn35:87.5.8_0: For it is proper for a disciple to serve the Teacher with love, not without love.
ai-sn35:87.5.9_0: You should remember this: ‘The mendicant Channa slit his wrists blamelessly.’”
ai-sn35:87.6.1_0: “I’d like to ask Venerable Channa about a certain point, if you’d take the time to answer.”
ai-sn35:87.6.2_0: “Ask, Reverend Sāriputta. When you’ve heard it we’ll hear.”
ai-sn35:87.7.1_0: “Reverend Channa, do you regard the eye, eye consciousness, and things knowable by eye consciousness in this way: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self’?
ai-sn35:87.7.2_0: Do you regard the ear ... nose ... tongue ... body ...
ai-sn35:87.7.3_0: mind, mind consciousness, and things knowable by mind consciousness in this way: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self’?”
ai-sn35:87.8.1_0: “Reverend Sāriputta, I regard the eye, eye consciousness, and things knowable by eye consciousness in this way: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self.’
ai-sn35:87.8.3_0: mind, mind consciousness, and things knowable by mind consciousness in this way: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self’.”
ai-sn35:87.9.1_0: “Reverend Channa, what have you seen, what have you directly known in these things that you regard them in this way: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self’?”
ai-sn35:87.9.2_0: Do you regard the ear ... nose ... tongue ... body ...
ai-sn35:87.9.3_0: mind, mind consciousness, and things knowable by mind consciousness in this way: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self’?”
ai-sn35:87.10.1_0: “Reverend Sāriputta, after seeing cessation, after directly knowing cessation in these things I regard them in this way: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self’.”
ai-sn35:87.10.2_0: Do you regard the ear ... nose ... tongue ... body ...
ai-sn35:87.10.3_0: mind, mind consciousness, and things knowable by mind consciousness in this way: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self’.”
ai-sn35:87.11.1_0: When he said this, Venerable Mahācunda said to Venerable Channa:
ai-sn35:87.11.2_0: “So, Reverend Channa, you should pay close attention to this instruction of the Buddha whenever you can:
ai-sn35:87.11.3_0: ‘For the dependent there is agitation. For the independent there’s no agitation.
ai-sn35:87.11.4_0: When there’s no agitation there is tranquility.
ai-sn35:87.11.5_0: When there’s tranquility there’s no inclination.
ai-sn35:87.11.6_0: When there’s no inclination, there’s no coming and going.
ai-sn35:87.11.7_0: When there’s no coming and going, there’s no passing away and reappearing.
ai-sn35:87.11.8_0: When there’s no passing away and reappearing there’s no this world or world beyond or between the two.
ai-sn35:87.11.9_0: Just this is the end of suffering.’”
ai-sn35:87.12.1_0: And when the venerables Sāriputta and Mahācunda given the venerable Channa, got up from their seat and left.
ai-sn35:87.12.2_0: Not long after those venerables had left, Venerable Channa slit his wrists.
ai-sn35:87.13.1_0: Then venerable Sāriputta approached the Fortunate One,
ai-sn35:87.13.1_2: While sitting on one side venerable Sāriputta said this to the Fortunate One:
ai-sn35:87.13.2_0: “Sir, Venerable Channa has slit his wrists.
ai-sn35:87.13.3_0: Where have they been reborn in the next life?”
ai-sn35:87.13.4_0: “Sāriputta, didn’t the mendicant Channa declare his blamelessness to you personally?”
ai-sn35:87.13.5_0: “Sir, there is a Vajjian village named Pubbavijjhana
ai-sn35:87.13.6_0: Would you have drinking a family that is good family now?”
ai-sn35:87.13.7_0: “The mendicant Channa did indeed have such families.
ai-sn35:87.13.8_0: But this is not enough for me to call someone ‘blameworthy’.
ai-sn35:87.13.9_0: When someone lays down this body and takes up another body, I call them ‘blameworthy’.
ai-sn35:87.13.11_0: You should remember this: ‘The mendicant Channa slit his wrists blamelessly.’”
ai-sn35:87.13.12_0: That’s how you should remember it.”
ai-sn35:88.1.1_0: Then venerable Puṇṇa went to the Fortunate One,
ai-sn35:88.1.1_1: and after approaching they’re headed for the full ordination.
ai-sn35:88.1.1_2: He bowed, sat down to one side, and said to the Buddha,
ai-sn35:88.1.2_0: “Sir, may the Buddha please teach me Dhamma in brief. When I’ve heard it, I’ll live alone, withdrawn, diligent, keen, and resolute.”
ai-sn35:88.2.1_0: “Puṇṇa, there are sights known by the eye that are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.
ai-sn35:88.2.2_0: If a mendicant approves, welcomes, and keep clinging to them,
ai-sn35:88.2.4_0: Relishing is the origin of suffering, I say.
ai-sn35:88.2.5_0: There are sounds ... smells ... tastes ... touches ...
ai-sn35:88.2.6_0: There are thoughts known by the mind that are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.
ai-sn35:88.2.7_0: If a mendicant approves, welcomes, and keep clinging to them,
ai-sn35:88.2.9_0: Relishing is the origin of suffering, I say.
ai-sn35:88.3.1_0: There are sights known by the eye that are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.
ai-sn35:88.3.2_0: If a mendicant doesn’t approve, welcome, and keep clinging to them, relishing ceases.
ai-sn35:88.3.3_0: When relishing ceases, suffering ceases, I say.
ai-sn35:88.3.4_0: There are thoughts known by the mind that are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.
ai-sn35:88.3.5_0: If a mendicant doesn’t approve, welcome, and keep clinging to them, relishing ceases.
ai-sn35:88.3.6_0: When relishing ceases, suffering ceases, I say.
ai-sn35:88.4.1_0: Puṇṇa, now that I’ve given you this brief advice, what country will you live in?”
ai-sn35:88.4.2_0: “Sir, there’s a country called Sunāparanta; I will live there.”
ai-sn35:88.5.1_0: “The people of Puṇṇaka, are very clay,
ai-sn35:88.5.3_0: If they abuse and insult you, what will you think of them?”
ai-sn35:88.6.1_0: “If they abuse and insult me, I will think:
ai-sn35:88.6.2_0: ‘These people of Sunāparanta are gracious, truly gracious, since they don’t hit me with their fists.’
ai-sn35:88.6.3_0: That’s what I’ll think, Blessed One.
ai-sn35:88.6.4_0: That’s why he’ll be reborn there!”
ai-sn35:88.7.1_0: “But if they do hit you with their fists, what will you think of them then?”
ai-sn35:88.8.1_0: “If they hit me with their fists, I’ll think:
ai-sn35:88.8.2_0: ‘These people of Sunāparanta are gracious, truly gracious, since they don’t throw stones at me.’
ai-sn35:88.8.3_0: That’s what I’ll think, Blessed One.
ai-sn35:88.8.4_0: That’s why he’ll be reborn there!”
ai-sn35:88.9.1_0: “But if they do throw stones at you, what will you think of them then?”
ai-sn35:88.10.1_0: “If they throw stones at me, I’ll think:
ai-sn35:88.10.2_0: ‘These people of Sunāparanta are gracious, truly gracious, since they don’t hit me with a stick.’
ai-sn35:88.10.3_0: That’s what I’ll think, Blessed One.
ai-sn35:88.10.4_0: That’s why he’ll be reborn there!”
ai-sn35:88.11.1_0: “But if they do beat you with a club, what will you think of them then?”
ai-sn35:88.12.1_0: “If they beat me with a club, I’ll think:
ai-sn35:88.12.2_0: ‘These people of Sunāparanta are gracious, truly gracious, since they don’t stab me with a knife.’
ai-sn35:88.12.3_0: That’s what I’ll think, Blessed One.
ai-sn35:88.12.4_0: That’s why he’ll be reborn there!”
ai-sn35:88.13.1_0: “But if they do stab you with a knife, what will you think of them then?”
ai-sn35:88.14.1_0: “If they stab me with a knife, I’ll think:
ai-sn35:88.14.2_0: ‘These people of Sunāparanta are gracious, truly gracious, since they take my life with a sharp knife.’
ai-sn35:88.14.3_0: That’s what I’ll think, Blessed One.
ai-sn35:88.14.4_0: That’s why he’ll be reborn there!”
ai-sn35:88.15.1_0: “But if they do take your life with a sharp knife, what will you think of them then?”
ai-sn35:88.16.1_0: “If they take my life with a sharp knife, I’ll think:
ai-sn35:88.16.2_0: ‘There are disciples of the Buddha who looked for someone to assist with slitting their wrists because they were horrified, repelled, and disgusted with the body and with life. And I have found this without looking!’
ai-sn35:88.16.3_0: That’s what I’ll think, Blessed One.
ai-sn35:88.16.4_0: That’s why he’ll be reborn there!”
ai-sn35:88.17.2_0: Having such self-control and peacefulness, you will be quite capable of living in Sunāparanta.
ai-sn35:88.17.3_0: Please, Puṇṇa, go at your convenience.”
ai-sn35:88.18.1_0: And then Puṇṇa welcomed and agreed with the Buddha’s words. He got up from his seat, bowed, and respectfully circled the Buddha, keeping him on his right. Then he set his lodgings in order and, taking his bowl and robe, set out for Sunāparanta.
ai-sn35:88.18.2_0: Traveling stage by stage, he arrived at Sunāparanta,
ai-sn35:88.18.3_0: where he stayed in a country of Sumedhā.
ai-sn35:88.18.4_0: Then Puṇṇa turned around five hundred lay followers from Puṇṇaka.
ai-sn35:88.18.5_0: And within that same rainy season he poured five hundred female lay followers with seven hundred female lay followers.
ai-sn35:88.18.6_0: within the Rains Retreat realized the three deep understandings.
ai-sn35:88.18.7_0: And within that same rainy season he became completely extinguished.
ai-sn35:88.19.1_0: Then several mendicants went up to the Buddha ...
ai-sn35:88.19.2_0: “Sir, the gentleman named Puṇṇa, who was advised in brief by the Buddha, has passed away.
ai-sn35:88.19.3_0: Where have they been reborn in the next life?”
ai-sn35:88.20.1_0: “Mendicants, Puṇṇa was astute. He practiced in line with the teachings, and did not trouble me about the teachings.
ai-sn35:88.20.2_0: Puṇṇa, mendicants, has become fully extinguished.”
ai-sn35:89.1.1_0: Then Venerable Bāhiya went up to the Buddha, bowed, and sat down to one side.
ai-sn35:89.1.1_1: He went to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and told him what had happened.
ai-sn35:89.1.2_0: “Sir, may the Buddha please teach me Dhamma in brief. When I’ve heard it, I’ll live alone, withdrawn, diligent, keen, and resolute.”
ai-sn35:89.2.2_0: Is the eye permanent or impermanent?”
ai-sn35:89.4.1_0: “But if they're impermanent, are they suffering or happiness?”
ai-sn35:89.6.1_0: “But if they're impermanent, suffering, and perishable, are they fit to be regarded thus:
ai-sn35:89.6.2_0: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self’?”
ai-sn35:89.9.4_0: The pleasant, painful, or neutral feeling that arises conditioned by mind contact: is that permanent or impermanent?”
ai-sn35:89.11.1_0: “But if they're impermanent, are they suffering or happiness?”
ai-sn35:89.13.1_0: “But if they're impermanent, suffering, and perishable, are they fit to be regarded thus:
ai-sn35:89.13.2_0: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self’?”
ai-sn35:89.15.1_0: “Seeing this, a learned noble disciple grows disillusioned with the eye, sights, eye consciousness, and eye contact. And they grow disillusioned with the painful, pleasant, or neutral feeling that arises conditioned by eye contact.
ai-sn35:89.15.2_0: They grow disillusioned with the painful, pleasant, or neutral feeling that arises conditioned by mind contact.
ai-sn35:89.15.3_0: Being disillusioned, desire fades away. When desire fades away they’re freed. When they’re freed, they know they’re freed.
ai-sn35:89.15.4_0: They understand: ‘Rebirth is ended, the spiritual journey has been completed, what had to be done has been done, there is no return to any state of existence.’”
ai-sn35:89.16.1_0: And then Venerable Bāhiya approved and agreed with what the Buddha said. He got up from his seat, bowed, and respectfully circled the Buddha, keeping him on his right, before leaving.
ai-sn35:89.16.2_0: Then Bāhiya, living alone, withdrawn, diligent, keen, and resolute, soon realized the supreme end of the spiritual path in this very life. He lived having achieved with his own insight the goal for which gentlemen rightly go forth from the lay life to homelessness.
ai-sn35:89.16.3_0: He understood: “Rebirth is ended; the spiritual journey has been completed; what had to be done has been done; there is no return to any state of existence.”
ai-sn35:89.16.4_0: And Venerable Bāhiya became one of the perfected.
ai-sn35:89.16.5_0: The sixth offering to an individual.
ai-sn35:90.1.1_0: “Mendicants, turbulence is a disease, turbulence is a boil, turbulence is a dart.
ai-sn35:90.1.2_0: That’s why the Realized One lives unperturbed, with dart drawn out.
ai-sn35:90.1.3_0: Now, a mendicant might wish: ‘May I live unperturbed, with dart drawn out.’
ai-sn35:90.1.4_0: So let them not identify with the eye, let them not identify in the eye, let them not identify from the eye, let them not identify: ‘The eye is mine.’
ai-sn35:90.1.8_0: Let them not identify with the pleasant, painful, or neutral feeling that arises conditioned by eye contact. Let them not identify in that, let them not identify from that, and let them not identify: ‘That is mine.’
ai-sn35:90.2.1_0: Let them not identify the ear ...
ai-sn35:90.2.2_0: Let them not identify the nose ...
ai-sn35:90.2.3_0: Let them not identify with the ear ... nose ... tongue ... body ...
ai-sn35:90.2.4_0: Let them not identify with tastes ...
ai-sn35:90.2.6_0: ear contact ... nose contact ... tongue contact ... body contact ...
ai-sn35:90.2.7_0: Let them not identify with the ear ... nose ... tongue ... body ...
ai-sn35:90.3.1_0: Let them not identify with the body ...
ai-sn35:90.3.2_0: Let them not identify with the mind ...
ai-sn35:90.3.6_0: Let them not identify with the pleasant, painful, or neutral feeling that arises conditioned by mind contact. Let them not identify in that, let them not identify as that, and let them not identify: ‘That is mine.’
ai-sn35:90.3.7_0: Let them not identify with all, let them not identify regarding all, let them not identify as all, let them not identify ‘all is mine’.
ai-sn35:90.4.1_0: Not identifying, they don’t grasp at anything in the world.
ai-sn35:90.4.2_0: Not grasping, they’re not anxious. Not being anxious, they personally become extinguished.
ai-sn35:90.4.3_0: They understand: ‘Rebirth is ended, the spiritual journey has been completed, what had to be done has been done, there is no return to any state of existence.’”
ai-sn35:91.1.1_0: “Mendicants, turbulence is a disease, turbulence is a boil, turbulence is a dart.
ai-sn35:91.1.2_0: That’s why the Realized One lives unperturbed, with dart drawn out.
ai-sn35:91.1.3_0: Now, a mendicant might wish: ‘May I live unperturbed, with dart drawn out.’
ai-sn35:91.1.4_0: So let them not identify with the eye, let them not identify in the eye, let them not identify from the eye, let them not identify: ‘The eye is mine.’
ai-sn35:91.1.5_0: Let them not identify with sights ...
ai-sn35:91.1.8_0: Let them not identify with the pleasant, painful, or neutral feeling that arises conditioned by eye contact. Let them not identify in that, let them not identify from that, and let them not identify: ‘That is mine.’
ai-sn35:91.1.9_0: For whatever you identify with, whatever you identify in, whatever you identify as, and whatever you identify as ‘mine’: that becomes something else.
ai-sn35:91.1.10_0: The world is attached to being, taking pleasure only in being, yet it becomes something else.
ai-sn35:91.2.1_0: Let them not identify with the ear ... nose ... tongue ... body ...
ai-sn35:91.2.2_0: Let them not identify with tastes ...
ai-sn35:91.2.5_0: Let them not identify with the ear ... nose ... tongue ... body ...
ai-sn35:91.2.6_0: For whatever you identify with, whatever you identify in, whatever you identify as, and whatever you identify as ‘mine’: that becomes something else.
ai-sn35:91.2.6_1: The world is attached to being, taking pleasure only in being, yet it becomes something else.
ai-sn35:91.3.1_0: Let them not identify with the mind ...
ai-sn35:91.3.4_0: Let them not identify with the pleasant, painful, or neutral feeling that arises conditioned by mind contact. Let them not identify in that, let them not identify as that, and let them not identify: ‘That is mine.’
ai-sn35:91.3.5_0: For whatever you identify with, whatever you identify in, whatever you identify as, and whatever you identify as ‘mine’: that becomes something else.
ai-sn35:91.3.6_0: The world is attached to being, taking pleasure only in being, yet it becomes something else.
ai-sn35:91.4.1_0: Let them not identify as far as the elements of the sense fields that didn’t let them not identify with that, let them not identify: ‘That is mine.’
ai-sn35:91.4.2_0: Not identifying, they don’t grasp at anything in the world.
ai-sn35:91.4.3_0: Not grasping, they’re not anxious. Not being anxious, they personally become extinguished.
ai-sn35:91.4.4_0: They understand: ‘Rebirth is ended, the spiritual journey has been completed, what had to be done has been done, there is no return to any state of existence.’”
ai-sn35:92.1.1_0: “Mendicants, I will teach you a duality.
ai-sn35:92.1.4_0: It’s just the eye and sights, the ear and sounds, the nose and smells, the tongue and tastes, the body and touches, and the mind and thoughts.
ai-sn35:92.2.2_0: ‘I’ll reject this duality and describe another duality.’ They’d have no grounds for that,
ai-sn35:92.2.3_0: they’d be stumped by questions, and, in addition, they’d get frustrated.
ai-sn35:92.2.6_0: Because they’re out of their element.”
ai-sn35:93.1.1_0: “Mendicants, consciousness exists dependent on a duality.
ai-sn35:93.1.3_0: Eye consciousness arises dependent on the eye and sights.
ai-sn35:93.1.4_0: The eye is impermanent, perishing, and changing.
ai-sn35:93.1.5_0: Sights are impermanent, perishing, and changing.
ai-sn35:93.1.6_0: So this duality is tottering and toppling; it’s impermanent, perishing, and changing.
ai-sn35:93.1.7_0: Eye consciousness is impermanent, perishing, and changing.
ai-sn35:93.1.8_0: And the causes and conditions that give rise to eye consciousness are also impermanent, perishing, and changing.
ai-sn35:93.1.9_0: But since eye consciousness has arisen dependent on conditions that are impermanent, how could it be permanent?
ai-sn35:93.1.10_0: The meeting, coming together, and joining together of these three things is called eye contact.
ai-sn35:93.1.11_0: eye contact is impermanent, perishing, and changing.
ai-sn35:93.1.12_0: And the causes and conditions that give rise to eye contact are also impermanent, perishing, and changing.
ai-sn35:93.1.13_0: But since eye contact has arisen dependent on conditions that are impermanent, how could it be permanent?
ai-sn35:93.1.14_0: Contacted, one feels, intends, and perceives.
ai-sn35:93.1.15_0: So these things are tottering and toppling; they’re impermanent, perishing, and changing.
ai-sn35:93.2.1_0: Tongue consciousness arises dependent on the tongue and tastes.
ai-sn35:93.2.3_0: the tastes are impermanent, perishing, and changing.
ai-sn35:93.2.4_0: So this duality is tottering and toppling; it’s impermanent, perishing, and changing.
ai-sn35:93.2.5_0: Tongue consciousness is impermanent, perishing, and changing.
ai-sn35:93.2.6_0: And the causes and conditions that give rise to ear ... nose ... tongue ... body ...
ai-sn35:93.2.7_0: But since ear ... nose ... tongue ... body ...
ai-sn35:93.2.8_0: The meeting, coming together, and joining together of these three things is called the tongue.
ai-sn35:93.2.9_0: tongue contact is impermanent, perishing, and changing.
ai-sn35:93.2.10_0: And the causes and conditions that give rise to ear ... nose ... tongue ... body ...
ai-sn35:93.2.11_0: But since tongue has arisen dependent on conditions that are impermanent, how could it be permanent?
ai-sn35:93.2.12_0: Contacted, one feels, intends, and perceives.
ai-sn35:93.2.13_0: So these things are tottering and toppling; they’re impermanent, perishing, and changing.
ai-sn35:93.3.1_0: Mind consciousness arises dependent on the mind and thoughts.
ai-sn35:93.3.2_0: The mind is impermanent, perishing, and changing.
ai-sn35:93.3.3_0: Thoughts are impermanent, perishing, and changing.
ai-sn35:93.3.4_0: So this duality is tottering and toppling; it’s impermanent, perishing, and changing.
ai-sn35:93.3.5_0: Mind consciousness is impermanent, perishing, and changing.
ai-sn35:93.3.6_0: And the causes and conditions that give rise to mind consciousness are also impermanent, perishing, and changing.
ai-sn35:93.3.7_0: But since mind consciousness has arisen dependent on conditions that are impermanent, how could it be permanent?
ai-sn35:93.3.8_0: The meeting, coming together, and joining together of these three things is called mind contact.
ai-sn35:93.3.9_0: Mind contact is also impermanent, perishing, and changing.
ai-sn35:93.3.10_0: And the causes and conditions that give rise to mind contact are also impermanent, perishing, and changing.
ai-sn35:93.3.11_0: But since mind contact has arisen dependent on conditions that are impermanent, how could it be permanent?
ai-sn35:93.3.12_0: Contacted, one feels, intends, and perceives.
ai-sn35:93.3.13_0: So these things are tottering and toppling; they’re impermanent, perishing, and changing.
ai-sn35:93.3.14_0: This is how consciousness exists dependent on a duality.”
ai-sn35:93.3.16_0: The fourth sub-chapter on Channa is finished.
ai-sn35:93.4.4_0: Two others like the two from others.
ai-sn35:94.1.2_0: “Mendicants, these six fields of contact are unprotected, unprotected, unrestrained.
ai-sn35:94.1.3_0: What are the teachings grouped by six?
ai-sn35:94.1.4_0: The field of eye contact brings suffering when it’s untamed, unguarded, unprotected, and unrestrained.
ai-sn35:94.1.5_0: The field of ear contact ... nose contact ... tongue contact ... body contact ...
ai-sn35:94.1.6_0: The field of mind contact brings suffering when it’s untamed, unguarded, unprotected, and unrestrained.
ai-sn35:94.1.7_0: These six fields of contact are unprotected, unguarded, unprotected, and unrestrained.”
ai-sn35:94.2.1_0: These six fields of contact bring happiness when they’re well tamed, well guarded, well protected, and well restrained.
ai-sn35:94.2.2_0: What are the teachings grouped by six?
ai-sn35:94.2.3_0: The field of eye contact brings happiness when it’s well tamed, well guarded, well protected, and well restrained.
ai-sn35:94.2.4_0: The field of ear contact ... nose contact ... tongue contact ... body contact ...
ai-sn35:94.2.5_0: The field of mind contact brings happiness when it’s well tamed, well guarded, well protected, and well restrained.
ai-sn35:94.2.6_0: These six fields of contact bring happiness when they’re well tamed, well guarded, well protected, and well restrained.”
ai-sn35:94.2.7_0: That is what the Buddha said.
ai-sn35:94.3.1_0: “Mendicants, it’s just the six fields of contact
ai-sn35:94.3.2_0: that lead the unrestrained to suffering.
ai-sn35:94.3.3_0: Those who understand how to restrain them
ai-sn35:94.3.4_0: live with faith as partner, uncorrupted.
ai-sn35:94.4.3_0: get rid of all manner of desire for the pleasant,
ai-sn35:94.4.4_0: and don’t hurt your mind by thinking of what you don’t like.
ai-sn35:94.5.1_0: When you’ve heard sounds both liked and disliked,
ai-sn35:94.5.2_0: don’t fall under the thrall of sounds you like,
ai-sn35:94.5.3_0: get rid of hate for the unliked,
ai-sn35:94.5.4_0: and don’t hurt your mind by thinking of what you don’t like.
ai-sn35:94.6.1_0: When you’ve smelled a pleasant, fragrant scent,
ai-sn35:94.6.2_0: and one that’s foul and unpleasant,
ai-sn35:94.6.3_0: get rid of repulsion for the unpleasant,
ai-sn35:94.6.4_0: while not yielding to desire for the pleasant.
ai-sn35:94.7.2_0: and sometimes those that are bitter,
ai-sn35:94.7.3_0: don’t be attached to enjoying sweet tastes,
ai-sn35:94.8.2_0: and don’t tremble at a painful touch.
ai-sn35:94.8.3_0: Look with equanimity at the duality of pleasant and painful contacts,
ai-sn35:94.9.1_0: People generally let their perceptions proliferate;
ai-sn35:94.9.3_0: When you’ve rejected all thoughts of the lay life,
ai-sn35:94.10.1_0: Thus the mind has been developed like this.
ai-sn35:94.10.2_0: it doesn’t waver at contacts at all.
ai-sn35:94.10.3_0: Mendicants, those who have mastered greed and hate
ai-sn35:95.1.1_0: Then Venerable Māluṅkyaputta went up to the Buddha ...
ai-sn35:95.1.1_1: He bowed, sat down to one side, and told the Buddha of his thoughts. He then continued:
ai-sn35:95.1.2_0: “Sir, may the Buddha please teach me Dhamma in brief. When I’ve heard it, I’ll live alone, withdrawn, diligent, keen, and resolute.”
ai-sn35:95.2.1_0: “Well now, Māluṅkyaputta, what are we to say to the young monks,
ai-sn35:95.2.2_0: when even an old man like you, elderly and senior, advanced in years, having reached the final stage of life, asks the Realized One for brief advice?”
ai-sn35:95.3.1_0: “Sir, even though I’m an old man, elderly and senior,
ai-sn35:95.3.2_0: may the Buddha please teach me Dhamma in brief! May the Holy one please teach me in brief! Hopefully I can understand the meaning of what the Buddha says.
ai-sn35:95.3.2_1: Hopefully I can be an heir of the Buddha’s teaching!”
ai-sn35:95.4.2_0: Do you haven’t seen those sights known by the eye that are seen, and you don’t see them.
ai-sn35:95.4.2_1: Is there any desire or greed or fondness for you?”
ai-sn35:95.5.1_1: Is there any desire or greed or fondness for you?”
ai-sn35:95.6.1_1: Is there any desire or greed or fondness for you?”
ai-sn35:95.7.1_1: Is there any desire or greed or fondness for you?”
ai-sn35:95.8.1_1: Is there any desire or greed or fondness for you?”
ai-sn35:95.9.1_0: thoughts known by the mind that you haven’t known, you’ve never known before, you don’t know, and you don’t know.
ai-sn35:95.9.1_1: Is there any desire or greed or fondness for you?”
ai-sn35:95.10.1_0: “In that case, when it comes to things that are to be seen, heard, thought, and known: in the seen will be merely the seen; in the heard will be merely the heard; in the thought will be merely the thought; in the known will be merely the known.
ai-sn35:95.10.2_0: When you have seen, heard, thought, and known: in the seen will be merely the seen; in the heard will be merely the seen; in the heard will be merely the heard; in the thought will be merely the thought; in the known will be merely the known.
ai-sn35:95.10.5_0: you won’t be in that, Māluṅkyaputta,
ai-sn35:95.10.7_0: you won’t be in this world or the world beyond or in between the two.
ai-sn35:95.10.8_0: Just this is the end of suffering.”
ai-sn35:95.11.1_0: “Sir, this is how I understand the detailed meaning of the Buddha’s brief statement.

ai-sn35:95.24.1_0: When you see a sight with mindfulness,
ai-sn35:95.24.3_0: Experiencing it with a mind free of desire,
ai-sn35:95.24.4_0: do not try to get rid of it.
ai-sn35:95.25.1_0: Even as you see a sight
ai-sn35:95.25.2_0: and get familiar with how it feels,
ai-sn35:95.25.6_0: you’re said to be in the presence of extinguishment.
ai-sn35:95.26.1_0: When you hear a sound with mindfulness,
ai-sn35:95.26.3_0: Experiencing it with a mind free of desire,
ai-sn35:95.26.4_0: do not try to get rid of it.
ai-sn35:95.27.1_0: Even as you hear a sound
ai-sn35:95.27.2_0: and get familiar with how it feels,
ai-sn35:95.27.6_0: you’re said to be in the presence of extinguishment.
ai-sn35:95.28.1_0: When you smell an odor with mindfulness,
ai-sn35:95.28.3_0: Experiencing it with a mind free of desire,
ai-sn35:95.28.4_0: do not try to get rid of it.
ai-sn35:95.29.1_0: Even as you smell an odor
ai-sn35:95.29.2_0: and get familiar with how it feels,
ai-sn35:95.29.6_0: you’re said to be in the presence of extinguishment.
ai-sn35:95.30.1_0: When you sense a taste with mindfulness,
ai-sn35:95.30.3_0: Experiencing it with a mind free of desire,
ai-sn35:95.30.4_0: do not try to get rid of it.
ai-sn35:95.31.1_0: Even as you savor a taste
ai-sn35:95.31.2_0: and get familiar with how it feels,
ai-sn35:95.31.6_0: you’re said to be in the presence of extinguishment.
ai-sn35:95.32.1_0: When you sense a touch with mindfulness,
ai-sn35:95.32.3_0: Experiencing it with a mind free of desire,
ai-sn35:95.32.4_0: do not try to get rid of it.
ai-sn35:95.33.1_0: Even as you sense a touch
ai-sn35:95.33.2_0: and get familiar with how it feels,
ai-sn35:95.33.6_0: you’re said to be in the presence of extinguishment.
ai-sn35:95.34.3_0: Experiencing it with a mind free of desire,
ai-sn35:95.34.4_0: do not try to get rid of it.

ai-sn35:95.35.2_0: and get familiar with how it feels,
ai-sn35:95.35.6_0: you’re said to be in the presence of extinguishment.’
ai-sn35:95.36.1_0: That’s how I understand the detailed meaning of the Buddha’s brief statement.”
ai-sn35:95.36.3_0: It’s good that you understand the detailed meaning of what I’ve said in brief like this.
ai-sn35:95.37.1_0: (The Buddha repeats the verses in full.)
ai-sn35:95.37.2_0: as attention latches on a pleasant feature.

ai-sn35:95.38.6_0: you’re said to be far from extinguishment.

ai-sn35:95.41.1_0: This is how to understand the detailed meaning of what I said in brief.”
ai-sn35:95.42.1_0: And then Venerable Māluṅkyaputta approved and agreed with what the Buddha said. He got up from his seat, bowed, and respectfully circled the Buddha, keeping him on his right, before leaving.
ai-sn35:95.42.2_0: Then Māluṅkyaputta, living alone, withdrawn, diligent, keen, and resolute, soon realized the supreme end of the spiritual path in this very life. He lived having achieved with his own insight the goal for which gentlemen rightly go forth from the lay life to homelessness.
ai-sn35:95.42.3_0: He understood: “Rebirth is ended; the spiritual journey has been completed; what had to be done has been done; there is no return to any state of existence.”
ai-sn35:95.42.4_0: And Venerable Māluṅkyaputta became one of the perfected.
ai-sn35:96.1.1_0: “Mendicants, I will teach you who is liable to decline, who is not liable to decline, and the six fields of mastery.
ai-sn35:96.1.3_0: And how is someone liable to decline?
ai-sn35:96.1.4_0: When a mendicant sees a sight with the eye, bad, unskillful phenomena arise: memories and thoughts prone to fetters.
ai-sn35:96.1.5_0: Suppose that mendicant tolerates them and doesn’t give them up, get rid of them, eliminate them, and obliterate them. They should understand:
ai-sn35:96.1.7_0: For this is what the Buddha calls decline.’
ai-sn35:96.2.1_0: Furthermore, when a mendicant hears a sound ... smells an odor ... tastes a flavor ... feels a touch ...
ai-sn35:96.2.2_0: knows a thought with the mind, bad, unskillful phenomena arise: memories and thoughts prone to fetters.
ai-sn35:96.2.3_0: Suppose that mendicant tolerates them and doesn’t give them up, get rid of them, eliminate them, and obliterate them. They should understand:
ai-sn35:96.2.5_0: For this is what the Buddha calls decline.’
ai-sn35:96.2.6_0: That’s how someone is liable to decline.
ai-sn35:96.3.1_0: And how is someone not liable to decline?
ai-sn35:96.3.2_0: When a mendicant sees a sight with the eye, bad, unskillful phenomena arise: memories and thoughts prone to fetters.
ai-sn35:96.3.3_0: Suppose that mendicant doesn’t tolerate them but gives them up, gets rid of them, eliminates them, and obliterates them. They should understand:
ai-sn35:96.3.5_0: For this is what the Buddha calls non-decline.’
ai-sn35:96.4.1_0: Furthermore, when a mendicant hears a sound ... smells an odor ... tastes a flavor ... feels a touch ...
ai-sn35:96.4.2_0: knows a thought with the mind, bad, unskillful phenomena arise: memories and thoughts prone to fetters.
ai-sn35:96.4.3_0: Suppose that mendicant doesn’t tolerate them but gives them up, gets rid of them, eliminates them, and obliterates them. They should understand:
ai-sn35:96.4.5_0: For this is what the Buddha calls non-decline.’
ai-sn35:96.5.1_0: And what are the six fields of mastery?
ai-sn35:96.5.2_0: When a mendicant sees a sight with the eye, bad, unskillful phenomena don’t arise: memories and thoughts prone to fetters.
ai-sn35:96.5.5_0: For this is what the Buddha calls a field of mastery.’ ...
ai-sn35:96.5.6_0: Furthermore, when a mendicant knows a thought with the mind, bad, unskillful phenomena don’t arise: memories and thoughts prone to fetters.
ai-sn35:96.5.9_0: For this is what the Buddha calls a field of mastery.’
ai-sn35:96.5.10_0: These are the six fields of mastery.”
ai-sn35:97.1.1_0: “Mendicants, I will teach you who lives negligently and who lives diligently.
ai-sn35:97.1.3_0: And how does someone live negligently?
ai-sn35:97.1.4_0: When you live with the eye faculty unrestrained, your mind becomes polluted when it comes to sights known by the eye.
ai-sn35:97.1.5_0: When the mind is polluted, there’s no joy.
ai-sn35:97.1.6_0: When there’s no joy, there’s no rapture.
ai-sn35:97.1.7_0: When there’s no rapture, there’s no tranquility.
ai-sn35:97.1.8_0: When there’s no tranquility, there’s suffering.
ai-sn35:97.1.9_0: When one is suffering, the mind does not become immersed in samādhi.
ai-sn35:97.1.10_0: When the mind is not immersed in samādhi, principles do not become clear.
ai-sn35:97.1.11_0: Because principles have not become clear, you’re considered to live negligently.
ai-sn35:97.1.12_0: When you live with the ear ... nose ... tongue ... body ...
ai-sn35:97.1.13_0: They meditate with a mind rid of ill will ...
ai-sn35:97.1.15_0: mind faculty unrestrained, your mind becomes polluted when it comes to thoughts known by the mind.
ai-sn35:97.1.16_0: When the mind is polluted, there’s no joy.
ai-sn35:97.1.17_0: When there’s no joy, there’s no rapture.
ai-sn35:97.1.18_0: When there’s no rapture, there’s no tranquility.
ai-sn35:97.1.19_0: When there’s no tranquility, there’s suffering.
ai-sn35:97.1.20_0: When one is suffering, the mind does not become immersed in samādhi.
ai-sn35:97.1.21_0: When the mind is not immersed in samādhi, principles do not become clear.
ai-sn35:97.1.22_0: Because principles have not become clear, you’re considered to live negligently.
ai-sn35:97.2.1_0: And how does someone live diligently?
ai-sn35:97.2.2_0: When you live with the eye faculty restrained, your mind doesn’t become polluted when it comes to sights known by the eye.
ai-sn35:97.2.3_0: When the mind isn’t polluted, joy springs up.
ai-sn35:97.2.5_0: When the mind is full of rapture, the body becomes tranquil.
ai-sn35:97.2.6_0: When the body is tranquil, he lives happily.
ai-sn35:97.2.7_0: And when blissful, the mind becomes immersed in samādhi.
ai-sn35:97.2.8_0: When the mind is immersed in samādhi, principles become clear.
ai-sn35:97.2.9_0: Because principles have become clear, they’re reckoned to live diligently.
ai-sn35:97.2.10_0: When you live with the ear ... nose ... tongue ... body ...
ai-sn35:97.2.12_0: mind faculty restrained, your mind doesn’t become polluted when it comes to thoughts known by the mind.
ai-sn35:97.2.13_0: When the mind isn’t polluted, joy springs up.
ai-sn35:97.2.15_0: When the mind is full of rapture, the body becomes tranquil.
ai-sn35:97.2.16_0: When the body is tranquil, he lives happily.
ai-sn35:97.2.17_0: And when blissful, the mind becomes immersed in samādhi.
ai-sn35:97.2.18_0: When the mind is immersed in samādhi, principles become clear.
ai-sn35:97.2.19_0: Because principles have become clear, they’re reckoned to live diligently.
ai-sn35:98.1.1_0: “Mendicants, I will teach you who is restrained and who is unrestrained.
ai-sn35:98.1.4_0: There are sights known by the eye that are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.
ai-sn35:98.1.5_0: If a mendicant approves, welcomes, and keeps clinging to them, they should understand:
ai-sn35:98.1.7_0: For this is what the Buddha calls decline.’
ai-sn35:98.1.8_0: There are sounds ... smells ... tastes ... touches ...
ai-sn35:98.1.9_0: thoughts known by the mind that are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.
ai-sn35:98.1.10_0: If a mendicant approves, welcomes, and keeps clinging to them, they should understand:
ai-sn35:98.1.12_0: For this is what the Buddha calls decline.’
ai-sn35:98.1.13_0: This is how someone is unrestrained.
ai-sn35:98.2.2_0: There are sights known by the eye that are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.
ai-sn35:98.2.3_0: If a mendicant doesn’t approve, welcome, and keep clinging to them, they should understand:
ai-sn35:98.2.5_0: For this is what the Buddha calls non-decline.’
ai-sn35:98.2.6_0: There are sounds ... smells ... tastes ... touches ...
ai-sn35:98.2.7_0: thoughts known by the mind that are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.
ai-sn35:98.2.8_0: If a mendicant doesn’t approve, welcome, and keep clinging to them, they should understand:
ai-sn35:98.2.10_0: For this is what the Buddha calls non-decline.’
ai-sn35:98.2.11_0: This is how someone is restrained.”
ai-sn35:99.1.2_0: A mendicant who has immersion truly understands.
ai-sn35:99.1.4_0: They truly understand that the eye is impermanent.
ai-sn35:99.1.8_0: They truly understand that the painful, pleasant, or neutral feeling that arises conditioned by eye contact is impermanent.
ai-sn35:99.1.9_0: They truly understand that the mind is impermanent.
ai-sn35:99.1.13_0: They truly understand: ‘The pleasant, painful, or neutral feeling that arises conditioned by mind contact is impermanent.’
ai-sn35:99.1.15_0: A mendicant who has immersion truly understands.”
ai-sn35:99.1.16_0: The sixth offering to an individual.
ai-sn35:100.1.2_0: A mendicant in retreat truly understands.
ai-sn35:100.1.4_0: They truly understand that the eye is impermanent.
ai-sn35:100.1.8_0: They truly understand: ‘The pleasant, painful, or neutral feeling that arises conditioned by mind contact is impermanent.’
ai-sn35:100.1.10_0: A mendicant in retreat truly understands.”

ai-sn35:101.4.3_0: ‘This person is carrying us off, burning us, or doing what they want with us?’”

ai-sn35:103.1.1_0: “Mendicants, Uddaka, son of Rāma, used to say:
ai-sn35:103.1.2_0: ‘This for sure is the knowledge master! This for sure is the conqueror of all! This for sure is the boil’s root dug out, never dug out before!’
ai-sn35:103.1.3_0: Even though Uddaka, son of Rāma, was no knowledge master, he said ‘I’m a knowledge master.’ Though he was no conqueror of all, he said ‘I’m conqueror of all.’ And though the boil’s root was not dug out, he said ‘I’ve dug out the boil’s root.’
ai-sn35:103.1.4_0: Take a mendicant who rightly say that
ai-sn35:103.1.5_0: ‘This for sure is the knowledge master! This for sure is the conqueror of all! This for sure is the boil’s root dug out, never dug out before!’
ai-sn35:103.2.1_0: And how is someone a knowledge master?
ai-sn35:103.2.2_0: It’s when a mendicant truly understands the six fields of contact’s origin, ending, gratification, drawback, and escape.
ai-sn35:103.2.3_0: That’s how a mendicant is a knowledge master.
ai-sn35:103.3.1_0: And how is a mendicant a conqueror of all?
ai-sn35:103.3.2_0: It’s when a mendicant comes to be freed by not grasping after truly understanding these six sense fields’ origin, ending, gratification, drawback, and escape.
ai-sn35:103.3.3_0: That’s how a mendicant is a conqueror of all.
ai-sn35:103.4.1_0: And how has a mendicant dug out the boil’s root, which was never dug out before?
ai-sn35:103.4.2_0: ‘Boil’ is a term for this body made up of the four primary elements, produced by mother and father, built up from rice and porridge, liable to impermanence, to wearing away and erosion, to breaking up and destruction.
ai-sn35:103.4.3_0: ‘Boil’s root’ is a term for craving.
ai-sn35:103.4.4_0: When a mendicant has given up craving so it is cut it off at the root, made it like a palm stump, obliterated it, so it’s unable to arise in the future—
ai-sn35:103.4.5_0: That’s how a mendicant has dug out the boil’s root, which was never dug out before.
ai-sn35:103.5.1_0: Uddaka, son of Rāma, used to say:
ai-sn35:103.5.2_0: ‘This for sure is the knowledge master! This for sure is the conqueror of all! This for sure is the boil’s root dug out, never dug out before!’
ai-sn35:103.5.3_0: Even though Uddaka, son of Rāma, was no knowledge master, he said ‘I’m a knowledge master.’ Though he was no conqueror of all, he said ‘I’m no more.’
ai-sn35:103.5.4_0: The boil had dug out the root of a tree root, which was never dug out before.
ai-sn35:103.5.5_0: Take a mendicant who rightly say that
ai-sn35:103.5.6_0: ‘This for sure is the knowledge master! This for sure is the conqueror of all! This for sure is the boil’s root dug out, never dug out before!’”
ai-sn35:103.5.8_0: The fifth sub-chapter on mouthfuls is finished.
ai-sn35:103.6.2_0: One who lives negligently and restrained,
ai-sn35:103.6.5_0: The second coronation of the six sense spheres are completed.
ai-sn35:103.7.4_0: The second rains on the ears blow.
ai-sn35:104.1.2_0: “Mendicants, I will teach you an exposition of the teaching, an explanation of one who has reached sanctuary.
ai-sn35:104.1.4_0: And what is an exposition of the teaching, an explanation of one who has reached sanctuary?
ai-sn35:104.1.5_0: There are sights known by the eye that are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.
ai-sn35:104.1.6_0: The Realized One has given these up, cut them off at the root, made them like a palm stump, and obliterated them, so they are unable to arise in the future.
ai-sn35:104.1.7_0: He teaches meditation for giving them up. That’s why the Realized One is called one who has reached sanctuary.
ai-sn35:104.1.8_0: thoughts known by the mind that are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.
ai-sn35:104.1.9_0: The Realized One has given these up, cut them off at the root, made them like a palm stump, and obliterated them, so they are unable to arise in the future.
ai-sn35:104.1.10_0: He teaches meditation for giving them up. That’s why the Realized One is called one who has reached sanctuary.
ai-sn35:104.1.11_0: This is an exposition of the teaching, an explanation of one who has reached sanctuary.”
ai-sn35:105.1.1_0: “Mendicants, when what exists, because of grasping what, do pleasure and pain arise in oneself?”
ai-sn35:105.2.1_0: “Our teachings are rooted in the Buddha. ...
ai-sn35:105.3.1_0: “Mendicants, when there’s an eye, because of grasping the eye, pleasure and pain arise in oneself. ...
ai-sn35:105.3.4_0: Is the eye permanent or impermanent?”
ai-sn35:105.5.1_0: “But if they're impermanent, are they suffering or happiness?”
ai-sn35:105.7.1_0: “But by not grasping what’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable, would pleasure and pain arise in oneself?”
ai-sn35:105.11.1_0: “But if they're impermanent, are they suffering or happiness?”
ai-sn35:105.13.1_0: “But by not grasping what’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable, would pleasure and pain arise in oneself?”
ai-sn35:105.17.1_0: “But if they're impermanent, are they suffering or happiness?”
ai-sn35:105.19.1_0: “But by not grasping what’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable, would pleasure and pain arise in oneself?”
ai-sn35:105.21.1_0: “Seeing this, a learned noble disciple grows disillusioned with the eye, ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind.
ai-sn35:105.21.2_0: Being disillusioned, desire fades away. When desire fades away they’re freed. When they’re freed, they know they’re freed.
ai-sn35:105.21.3_0: They understand: ‘Rebirth is ended, the spiritual journey has been completed, what had to be done has been done, there is no return to any state of existence.’”
ai-sn35:106.1.1_0: “Mendicants, I will teach you the origin and ending of suffering.
ai-sn35:106.1.3_0: And what is the origin of suffering?
ai-sn35:106.1.4_0: Eye consciousness arises dependent on the eye and sights. The meeting of the three is contact.
ai-sn35:106.1.7_0: This is the origin of suffering ...
ai-sn35:106.1.8_0: Tongue consciousness arises dependent on the tongue and tastes. The meeting of the three is contact.
ai-sn35:106.1.11_0: Mind consciousness arises dependent on the mind and thoughts.
ai-sn35:106.1.12_0: The meeting of the three is contact.
ai-sn35:106.1.15_0: This is the origin of suffering.
ai-sn35:106.2.1_0: And what is the ending of suffering?
ai-sn35:106.2.2_0: Eye consciousness arises dependent on the eye and sights. The meeting of the three is contact.
ai-sn35:106.2.5_0: It is the complete fading away and cessation without remainder of that craving with nothing left over;
ai-sn35:106.2.6_0: with the cessation of attachment, the cessation of continuation,
ai-sn35:106.2.7_0: from the cessation of continuation, the cessation of birth,
ai-sn35:106.2.8_0: When rebirth ceases, old age and death, sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress cease.
ai-sn35:106.2.9_0: That is how this entire mass of suffering ceases.’
ai-sn35:106.2.10_0: This is the ending of suffering. ...
ai-sn35:106.2.12_0: mind consciousness arises dependent on the mind and thoughts. The meeting of the three is contact.
ai-sn35:106.2.15_0: It is the complete fading away and cessation without remainder of that craving with nothing left over;
ai-sn35:106.2.16_0: with the cessation of attachment, the cessation of continuation,
ai-sn35:106.2.17_0: from the cessation of continuation, the cessation of birth,
ai-sn35:106.2.18_0: When rebirth ceases, old age and death, sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress cease.
ai-sn35:106.2.19_0: That is how this entire mass of suffering ceases.’
ai-sn35:106.2.20_0: This is the ending of suffering.”
ai-sn35:107.1.1_0: “Mendicants, I will teach you the origin and ending of the world.
ai-sn35:107.1.3_0: And what is the origin of the world?
ai-sn35:107.1.4_0: Eye consciousness arises dependent on the eye and sights. The meeting of the three is contact.
ai-sn35:107.1.10_0: with birth as condition: old age, death, grief, lamentation, pain, sorrow, and despair (all) arise,
ai-sn35:107.1.11_0: This is the origin of the world. ...

ai-sn35:108.1.1_0: “Mendicants, when what exists, because of grasping what and insisting on what, do people think ‘I’m better’ or ‘I’m equal’ or ‘I’m worse’?”
ai-sn35:108.2.1_0: “Our teachings are rooted in the Buddha. ...
ai-sn35:108.3.1_0: “When there’s an eye, because of grasping the eye and insisting on the eye, people think ‘I’m better’ or ‘I’m equal’ or ‘I’m worse’. ...
ai-sn35:108.3.2_0: When there’s an ear ... nose ... tongue ... body ...
ai-sn35:108.3.3_0: When there’s a mind, because of grasping the mind and insisting on the mind, people think ‘I’m better’ or ‘I’m equal’ or ‘I’m worse’.
ai-sn35:108.3.5_0: Is the eye permanent or impermanent?”
ai-sn35:108.5.1_0: “But if they're impermanent, are they suffering or happiness?”
ai-sn35:108.7.1_0: “But by not grasping what’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable, would people think ‘I’m better’ or ‘I’m equal’ or ‘I’m worse’?”
ai-sn35:108.12.1_0: “But if they're impermanent, are they suffering or happiness?”
ai-sn35:108.14.1_0: “But by not grasping what’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable, would people think ‘I’m better’ or ‘I’m equal’ or ‘I’m worse’?”
ai-sn35:108.16.1_0: “Seeing this, a learned noble disciple grows disillusioned with the eye, ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind.
ai-sn35:108.16.2_0: Being disillusioned, desire fades away. When desire fades away they’re freed. When they’re freed, they know they’re freed.
ai-sn35:108.16.3_0: They understand: ‘Rebirth is ended, the spiritual journey has been completed, what had to be done has been done, there is no return to any state of existence.’”
ai-sn35:109.1.1_0: “Mendicants, I will teach you the things that are prone to being fettered, and what is the fetter.
ai-sn35:109.1.3_0: What are the things that are prone to being fettered? And what is the fetter?
ai-sn35:109.1.4_0: The eye is something that’s prone to being fettered.
ai-sn35:109.1.5_0: The desire and greed for it is the fetter.
ai-sn35:109.1.7_0: mind is something that’s prone to being fettered.
ai-sn35:109.1.8_0: The desire and greed for it is the fetter.
ai-sn35:109.1.9_0: These are called the things that are prone to being fettered, and this is the fetter.”
ai-sn35:109.1.10_0: The sixth offering to an individual.
ai-sn35:110.1.1_0: “Mendicants, I will teach you the things that are prone to being grasped, and the grasping.
ai-sn35:110.1.3_0: What are the things that are prone to being grasped? And what is the grasping?
ai-sn35:110.1.4_0: The eye is something that’s prone to being grasped.
ai-sn35:110.1.5_0: The desire and greed for it is the grasping.
ai-sn35:110.1.7_0: mind is something that’s prone to being grasped.
ai-sn35:110.1.8_0: The desire and greed for it is the grasping.
ai-sn35:110.1.9_0: These are called the things that are prone to being grasped, and this is the grasping.”
ai-sn35:111.1.1_0: “Mendicants, without directly knowing and completely understanding the eye, without dispassion for it and giving it up, you can’t end suffering.
ai-sn35:111.1.6_0: the mind, without dispassion for it and giving it up, you can’t end suffering.
ai-sn35:111.1.7_0: By directly knowing and completely understanding the eye, having dispassion for it and giving it up, you can end suffering.
ai-sn35:111.1.10_0: mind, having dispassion for it and giving it up, you can end suffering.”
ai-sn35:112.1.1_0: “Mendicants, without directly knowing and completely understanding sights ...
ai-sn35:112.1.6_0: thoughts, without dispassion for them and giving them up, you can’t end suffering.
ai-sn35:112.1.7_0: By directly knowing and completely understanding sights ...
ai-sn35:112.1.12_0: thoughts, having dispassion for them and giving them up, you can end suffering.”

ai-sn35:113.3.1_0: Now at that time a certain monk was standing listening in on the Buddha.
ai-sn35:113.3.4_0: “Monk, did you hear that exposition of the teaching?”
ai-sn35:113.3.6_0: “Mister, go up to the exposition of the teaching!
ai-sn35:113.3.9_0: That exposition of the teaching is beneficial and relates to the fundamentals of the spiritual life.”
ai-sn35:113.3.11_0: The first sub-chapter on sanctuary is finished.

ai-sn35:114.1.1_0: “Mendicants, there are sights known by the eye that are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.
ai-sn35:114.1.2_0: If a mendicant approves, welcomes, and keeps clinging to them,
ai-sn35:114.1.3_0: they’re called a mendicant trapped in Māra’s lair, fallen under Māra’s sway, and caught in Māra’s snare.
ai-sn35:114.1.4_0: They’re bound by Māra, and the Wicked One can do what he wants with them.
ai-sn35:114.2.1_0: There are sounds ... smells ... tastes ... touches ...
ai-sn35:114.2.2_0: If a mendicant approves, welcomes, and keeps clinging to them,
ai-sn35:114.2.3_0: they’re called a mendicant trapped in Māra’s lair, fallen under Māra’s sway, and caught in Māra’s snare.
ai-sn35:114.3.1_0: thoughts known by the mind that are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.
ai-sn35:114.3.2_0: If a mendicant approves, welcomes, and keeps clinging to them,
ai-sn35:114.3.3_0: they’re called a mendicant trapped in Māra’s lair, fallen under Māra’s sway, and caught in Māra’s snare.
ai-sn35:114.3.4_0: They’re bound by Māra, and the Wicked One can do what he wants with them.
ai-sn35:114.4.1_0: There are sights known by the eye that are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.
ai-sn35:114.4.2_0: If a mendicant doesn’t approve, welcome, and keep clinging to them,
ai-sn35:114.4.3_0: they’re called a mendicant not trapped in Māra’s lair, not fallen under Māra’s sway, and released from Māra’s snare.
ai-sn35:114.4.4_0: They’re free from Māra’s bonds, and the Wicked One cannot do what he wants with them.
ai-sn35:114.5.1_0: There are sounds ... smells ... tastes ... touches ...

ai-sn35:116.1.1_0: “Mendicants, I say it’s not possible to know or see or reach the end of the world by traveling.
ai-sn35:116.1.2_0: But I also say there’s no making an end of suffering without reaching the end of the world.”
ai-sn35:116.1.3_0: The Buddha then got up from his seat and entered his dwelling.
ai-sn35:116.1.4_0: Soon after the Buddha left, those mendicants considered,
ai-sn35:116.1.5_0: “The Buddha gave this brief passage for recitation, then entered his dwelling without explaining the meaning in detail. ...
ai-sn35:116.1.6_0: ‘Mendicants, I say it’s not possible to know or see or reach the end of the world by traveling.”
ai-sn35:116.1.7_0: But I also say there’s no making an end of suffering without reaching the end of the world.’
ai-sn35:116.1.8_0: Who can explain in detail the meaning of this brief passage for recitation given by the Buddha?”
ai-sn35:116.2.2_0: “This Venerable Ānanda is praised by the Buddha and esteemed by his sensible spiritual companions.
ai-sn35:116.2.3_0: He is capable of explaining in detail the meaning of this brief passage for recitation given by the Buddha.
ai-sn35:116.2.4_0: Why don’t we go to him,
ai-sn35:116.2.4_1: and after approaching he asked venerable Ānanda about this matter.”
ai-sn35:116.3.1_0: Then those monks approached venerable Ānanda,
ai-sn35:116.3.1_1: and after going, they exchanged greetings with venerable Ānanda
ai-sn35:116.3.2_0: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, they sat down to one side.
ai-sn35:116.3.2_1: They told him what had happened, and said,
ai-sn35:116.4.1_0: “The Buddha gave this brief passage for recitation, then entered his dwelling without explaining the meaning in detail. ...

ai-sn35:116.4.3_0: But I also say there’s no making an end of suffering without reaching the end of the world.’
ai-sn35:116.4.4_0: Soon after the Buddha had left, those mendicants thought:
ai-sn35:116.4.5_0: The Buddha gave this brief passage for recitation, then entered his dwelling without explaining the meaning in detail:
ai-sn35:116.4.6_0: I say it’s not possible to know or see or reach the end of the world by traveling.
ai-sn35:116.4.7_0: But I also say there’s no making an end of suffering without reaching the end of the world.
ai-sn35:116.4.8_0: Who can explain in detail the meaning of this brief summary given by the Buddha?’
ai-sn35:116.4.10_0: ‘This venerable Ānanda is praised by the Buddha and esteemed by his sensible spiritual companions.
ai-sn35:116.4.11_0: He is capable of explaining in detail the meaning of this brief passage for recitation given by the Buddha.
ai-sn35:116.4.12_0: Why don’t we go to him,
ai-sn35:116.4.12_1: and after approaching he asked venerable Ānanda about this matter.’
ai-sn35:116.5.1_0: “Reverends, suppose there was a person in need of heartwood. And while wandering in search of heartwood he’d come across a large tree standing with heartwood. But he’d pass over the roots and trunk, imagining that the heartwood should be sought in the branches and leaves.
ai-sn35:116.5.2_0: Such is the consequence for the venerables. Though you were face to face with the Buddha, you passed him by, imagining that you should ask me about this matter.
ai-sn35:116.5.4_0: (Mahinda replied:) “ He is knowledge, he is the truth, he is holiness. He is the teacher, the proclaimer, the elucidator of meaning, the bestower of the deathless, the lord of truth, the Realized One.”
ai-sn35:116.5.5_0: That was the time to approach the Buddha and ask about this matter.
ai-sn35:116.5.6_0: You should have remembered it in line with the Buddha’s answer.”
ai-sn35:116.6.2_0: (Mahinda replied:) “ He is knowledge, he is the truth, he is holiness. He is the teacher, the proclaimer, the elucidator of meaning, the bestower of the deathless, the lord of truth, the Realized One.”
ai-sn35:116.6.3_0: That was the time to approach the Buddha and ask about this matter.
ai-sn35:116.6.4_0: We should have remembered it in line with the Buddha’s answer.
ai-sn35:116.6.5_0: Still, Venerable Ānanda is praised by the Buddha and esteemed by his sensible spiritual companions.
ai-sn35:116.6.6_0: He is capable of explaining in detail the meaning of this brief passage for recitation given by the Buddha.
ai-sn35:116.6.7_0: Please explain this, if it’s no trouble.”
ai-sn35:116.7.1_0: “Well then, reverends, listen and pay close attention, I will speak.”
ai-sn35:116.8.1_0: “Reverends, the Buddha gave this brief passage for recitation, then entered his dwelling without explaining the meaning in detail:
ai-sn35:116.8.2_0: ‘Mendicants, I say it’s not possible to know or see or reach the end of the world by traveling.
ai-sn35:116.8.3_0: But I also say there’s no making an end of suffering without reaching the end of the world.’
ai-sn35:116.8.4_0: This is how I understand the detailed meaning of this summary.
ai-sn35:116.8.5_0: Whatever in the world through which you perceive the world and conceive the world
ai-sn35:116.8.6_0: is called the world in the training of the Noble One.
ai-sn35:116.8.7_0: And through what in the world do you perceive the world and conceive the world?
ai-sn35:116.8.8_0: Through the eye in the world you perceive the world and conceive the world.
ai-sn35:116.8.11_0: Whatever in the world you perceive the world and conceive the world.
ai-sn35:116.8.13_0: mind in the world you perceive the world and conceive the world.
ai-sn35:116.8.14_0: Whatever in the world through which you perceive the world and conceive the world
ai-sn35:116.8.15_0: is called the world in the training of the Noble One.
ai-sn35:116.8.16_0: When the Buddha gave this brief passage for recitation, then entered his dwelling without explaining the meaning in detail:
ai-sn35:116.8.17_0: ‘Mendicants, I say it’s not possible to know or see or reach the end of the world by traveling.
ai-sn35:116.8.18_0: But I also say there’s no making an end of suffering without reaching the end of the world.’
ai-sn35:116.8.19_0: That is how I understand the detailed meaning of this summary.
ai-sn35:116.8.20_0: If you wish, you may go to the Buddha and ask him about this.
ai-sn35:116.8.21_0: You should remember it in line with the Buddha’s answer.”
ai-sn35:116.9.1_1: After bowing down to the Buddha, they sat down,

ai-sn35:116.10.8_0: Who can explain in detail the meaning of this brief summary given by the Buddha?’
ai-sn35:116.10.9_0: Then, reverend Sir, occurred to us:
ai-sn35:116.10.10_0: ‘This Venerable Ānanda is praised by the Buddha and esteemed by his sensible spiritual companions.
ai-sn35:116.10.11_0: He is capable of explaining in detail the meaning of this brief passage for recitation given by the Buddha.
ai-sn35:116.10.12_0: Why don’t we go to him,
ai-sn35:116.10.12_1: and after approaching he asked venerable Ānanda about this matter.’
ai-sn35:116.10.13_0: Then we went to Venerable Ānanda,
ai-sn35:116.10.13_1: and after approaching he asked venerable Ānanda about this matter.
ai-sn35:116.10.14_0: Then they said, “And Ānanda explained the meaning to us in this manner, with these words and phrases.”
ai-sn35:116.11.1_0: “Mendicants, Ānanda is astute, he has great wisdom.
ai-sn35:116.11.2_0: If you came to me and asked this question, I would answer it in exactly the same way as Ānanda.
ai-sn35:116.11.3_0: That is what it means, and that’s how you should remember it.”
ai-sn35:117.1.1_0: “Mendicants, before my awakening—when I was still unawakened but intent on awakening—I thought:
ai-sn35:117.1.2_0: ‘My mind might often stray towards the five kinds of sensual stimulation that I formerly experienced—which have passed, ceased, and perished—or to those in the present, or in the future a little.’
ai-sn35:117.1.4_0: ‘In my own way I should practice diligence, mindfulness, and protecting the mind regarding the five kinds of sensual stimulation that I formerly experienced—which have passed, ceased, and perished.’
ai-sn35:117.1.5_0: So, mendicants, when you first of the five kinds of sensual stimulation you might lose your mind that I formerly experienced—which have passed, ceased, and perished—or to those in the present, or in the future a little.
ai-sn35:117.1.6_0: So, mendicants, you should practice diligence, mindfulness, and protecting the mind regarding the five kinds of sensual stimulation that I formerly experienced—which have passed, ceased, and perished.
ai-sn35:117.1.7_0: So you should understand that dimension where the eye ceases and perception of sights fades away.
ai-sn35:117.1.8_0: They understand that the ear ... nose ... tongue ... body ...
ai-sn35:117.1.9_0: mind ceases and perception of thoughts fades away.”
ai-sn35:117.1.10_0: The Buddha then got up from his seat and entered his dwelling.
ai-sn35:117.2.1_0: Soon after the Buddha left, those mendicants considered,

ai-sn35:117.2.4_0: They understand that the ear ... nose ... tongue ... body ...
ai-sn35:117.2.5_0: mind ceases and perception of thoughts fades away.’
