ai-sn35:117.5.13_0: He is capable of explaining in detail the meaning of this brief passage for recitation given by the Buddha.
ai-sn35:117.5.14_0: Why don’t we go to him,
ai-sn35:117.5.14_1: and after approaching he asked venerable Ānanda about this matter.’
ai-sn35:117.6.1_0: “Reverends, suppose there was a person in need of heartwood. And while wandering in search of heartwood he’d come across a large tree standing with heartwood. ...
ai-sn35:117.6.2_0: Please explain this, if it’s no trouble.”
ai-sn35:117.7.1_0: “Well then, reverends, listen and pay close attention, I will speak.”
ai-sn35:117.8.1_0: “Reverends, the Buddha gave this brief passage for recitation, then entered his dwelling without explaining the meaning in detail:
ai-sn35:117.8.2_0: ‘So you should understand that dimension where the eye ceases and perception of sights fades away. You should understand that dimension where the ear ... nose ... tongue ... body ...
ai-sn35:117.8.3_0: mind ceases and perception of thoughts fades away.’
ai-sn35:117.8.4_0: This is how I understand the detailed meaning of this summary.
ai-sn35:117.8.5_0: The Buddha was referring to the cessation of the six sense fields when he said:
ai-sn35:117.8.6_0: ‘So you should understand that dimension where the eye ceases and perception of sights fades away. You should understand that dimension where the ear ... nose ... tongue ... body ...
ai-sn35:117.8.7_0: mind ceases and perception of thoughts fades away.’
ai-sn35:117.8.8_0: The Buddha gave this brief summary, then entered his dwelling without explaining the meaning in detail.
ai-sn35:117.8.9_0: ‘So you should understand that dimension where the eye ceases and perception of sights fades away. You should understand that dimension where the ear ... nose ... tongue ... body ...
ai-sn35:117.8.10_0: mind ceases and perception of thoughts fades away.’
ai-sn35:117.8.11_0: That is how I understand the detailed meaning of this summary.
ai-sn35:117.8.12_0: If you wish, you may go to the Buddha and ask him about this.
ai-sn35:117.8.13_0: and after approaching you can ask about this matter,
ai-sn35:117.8.14_0: You should remember it in line with the Buddha’s answer.”
ai-sn35:117.9.1_1: After bowing down to the Buddha, they sat down,
ai-sn35:117.10.1_0: “Sir, the Buddha gave this brief passage for recitation, then entered his dwelling without explaining the meaning in detail:
ai-sn35:117.10.2_0: ‘So you should understand that dimension where the eye ceases and perception of sights fades away. You should understand that dimension where the ear ... nose ... tongue ... body ...
ai-sn35:117.10.3_0: They understand that the ear ... nose ... tongue ... body ...
ai-sn35:117.10.4_0: mind ceases without anything left over.’
ai-sn35:117.10.5_0: The Buddha gave this brief passage for recitation, then entered his dwelling without explaining the meaning in detail.
ai-sn35:117.10.6_0: “So you should understand that dimension where the eye ceases and perception of sights fades away. You should understand that dimension where the ear ... nose ... tongue ... body ...
ai-sn35:117.10.7_0: mind ceases and perception of thoughts fades away.”
ai-sn35:117.10.8_0: Who can explain in detail the meaning of this brief summary given by the Buddha?’
ai-sn35:117.10.9_0: Then, reverend Sir, occurred to us:
ai-sn35:117.10.10_0: ‘This Venerable Ānanda is praised by the Buddha and esteemed by his sensible spiritual companions.
ai-sn35:117.10.11_0: He is capable of explaining in detail the meaning of this brief passage for recitation given by the Buddha.
ai-sn35:117.10.12_0: Why don’t we go to him,
ai-sn35:117.10.12_1: and after approaching he asked venerable Ānanda about this matter.’
ai-sn35:117.10.13_0: Then we went to Venerable Ānanda,
ai-sn35:117.10.13_1: and after approaching he asked venerable Ānanda about this matter.
ai-sn35:117.10.14_0: Then they said, “And Ānanda explained the meaning to us in this manner, with these words and phrases.”
ai-sn35:117.11.1_0: “Mendicants, Ānanda is astute, he has great wisdom.
ai-sn35:117.11.2_0: If you came to me and asked this question, I would answer it in exactly the same way as Ānanda.
ai-sn35:117.11.3_0: That is what it means, and that’s how you should remember it.”
ai-sn35:118.1.1_0: At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha, on the Vulture’s Peak Mountain.
ai-sn35:118.1.2_0: Then Sakka, lord of gods, went to the Fortunate One,
ai-sn35:118.1.2_1: and after approaching and worshipping the Fortunate One, he stood on one side.
ai-sn35:118.1.2_2: He bowed, stood to one side, and said to him:
ai-sn35:118.1.3_0: “What is the cause, sir, what is the reason why some sentient beings aren’t fully extinguished in the present life?
ai-sn35:118.1.4_0: What is the cause, sir, what is the reason why some sentient beings are fully extinguished in the present life?”
ai-sn35:118.2.1_0: “Lord of gods, there are sights known by the eye that are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.
ai-sn35:118.2.2_0: If a mendicant approves, welcomes, and keep clinging to them,
ai-sn35:118.2.3_0: their consciousness relies on that and grasps it.
ai-sn35:118.2.4_0: A mendicant with grasping does not become extinguished.
ai-sn35:118.3.1_0: There are sounds ... smells ... tastes ... touches ...
ai-sn35:118.3.2_0: thoughts known by the mind that are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.
ai-sn35:118.3.3_0: If a mendicant approves, welcomes, and keep clinging to them,
ai-sn35:118.3.4_0: their consciousness relies on that and grasps it.
ai-sn35:118.3.5_0: A mendicant with grasping does not become extinguished.
ai-sn35:118.3.6_0: That’s the cause, that’s the reason why some sentient beings aren’t fully extinguished in the present life.
ai-sn35:118.4.1_0: There are sights known by the eye that are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.
ai-sn35:118.4.2_0: If a mendicant doesn’t approve, welcome, and keep clinging to them, they’re called a mendicant who hasn’t swallowed Māra’s hook.
ai-sn35:118.4.3_0: So their consciousness doesn’t rely on that and grasp it.
ai-sn35:118.4.4_0: A mendicant free of grasping becomes extinguished.
ai-sn35:118.5.1_0: There are sounds ... smells ... tastes ... touches ...
ai-sn35:118.5.2_0: thoughts known by the mind that are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.
ai-sn35:118.5.3_0: If a mendicant doesn’t approve, welcome, and keep clinging to them, they’re called a mendicant who hasn’t swallowed Māra’s hook.
ai-sn35:118.5.4_0: So their consciousness doesn’t rely on that and grasp it.
ai-sn35:118.5.5_0: A mendicant free of grasping becomes extinguished.
ai-sn35:118.5.6_0: That’s the cause, that’s the reason why some sentient beings are fully extinguished in the present life.”
ai-sn35:119.1.1_0: At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha, on the Vulture’s Peak Mountain.
ai-sn35:119.1.2_0: Then the fairy Pañcasikha went up to the Buddha.
ai-sn35:119.1.2_1: and after approaching and worshipping the Fortunate One, he stood on one side.
ai-sn35:119.1.2_2: While standing on one side the fairy Pañcasikha said this to the Fortunate One:
ai-sn35:119.1.3_0: “What is the cause, sir, what is the reason why some sentient beings aren’t fully extinguished in the present life?
ai-sn35:119.1.4_0: What is the cause, sir, what is the reason why some sentient beings are fully extinguished in the present life?”
ai-sn35:119.1.5_0: “Pañcasikha, there are sights known by the eye ...
ai-sn35:119.1.6_0: thoughts known by the mind that are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.
ai-sn35:119.1.7_0: If a mendicant approves, welcomes, and keep clinging to them,
ai-sn35:119.1.8_0: their consciousness relies on that and grasps it.
ai-sn35:119.1.9_0: A mendicant with grasping does not become extinguished.
ai-sn35:119.1.10_0: That’s the cause, that’s the reason why some sentient beings aren’t fully extinguished in the present life.
ai-sn35:119.2.1_0: There are sights known by the eye ...
ai-sn35:119.2.2_0: thoughts known by the mind that are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.
ai-sn35:119.2.3_0: If a mendicant doesn’t approve, welcome, and keep clinging to them, their consciousness doesn’t rely on that and grasp it.
ai-sn35:119.2.4_0: A mendicant free of grasping becomes extinguished.
ai-sn35:119.2.5_0: That’s the cause, that’s the reason why some sentient beings are fully extinguished in the present life.”
ai-sn35:119.2.6_0: The sixth offering to an individual.
ai-sn35:120.1.1_0: At one time Venerable Sāriputta was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
ai-sn35:120.1.2_0: Then a certain monk went to venerable Sāriputta,
ai-sn35:120.1.2_1: and after going, he exchanged greetings with him.
ai-sn35:120.1.3_0: and after exchanging courteous talk and greetings, he sat down on one side.
ai-sn35:120.1.4_0: “Reverend Sāriputta, a mendicant who resigns the training and returns to a lesser life.”
ai-sn35:120.2.1_0: “That’s how it is, reverend, when someone doesn’t guard the sense doors, eats too much, and is not committed to wakefulness.
ai-sn35:120.2.2_0: It’s not possible for such a mendicant to maintain the full and pure spiritual life for the rest of their life.
ai-sn35:120.2.3_0: But it is possible for a mendicant to maintain the full and pure spiritual life for the rest of their life if they guard the sense doors, eat in moderation, and are committed to wakefulness.
ai-sn35:120.3.1_0: And how does someone guard the sense doors?
ai-sn35:120.3.2_0: When a mendicant sees a sight with their eyes, they don’t get caught up in the features and details.
ai-sn35:120.3.3_0: If the faculty of sight were left unrestrained, bad unskillful qualities of desire and aversion would become overwhelming. For this reason, they practice restraint, protecting the faculty of sight, and achieving its restraint.
ai-sn35:120.3.4_0: When you hear a sound with your ears ...
ai-sn35:120.3.5_0: When they smell an odor with their nose ...
ai-sn35:120.3.6_0: Tasting a flavor with the tongue ...
ai-sn35:120.3.7_0: Feeling a touch with the body ...
ai-sn35:120.3.8_0: Knowing a thought with their mind, they don’t get caught up in the features and details.
ai-sn35:120.3.9_0: If the faculty of mind were left unrestrained, bad unskillful qualities of desire and aversion would become overwhelming. For this reason, they practice restraint, protecting the faculty of mind, and achieving its restraint.
ai-sn35:120.3.10_0: That’s how someone guards the sense doors.
ai-sn35:120.4.1_0: And how does someone eat in moderation?
ai-sn35:120.4.2_0: It’s when a mendicant reflects properly on the food that they eat:
ai-sn35:120.4.3_0: ‘Not for fun, indulgence, adornment, or decoration, but only to sustain this body, to avoid harm, and to support spiritual practice.
ai-sn35:120.4.3_1: In this way, I shall put an end to old discomfort and not give rise to new discomfort, and I will live blamelessly and at ease.’
ai-sn35:120.4.4_0: That’s how someone eats in moderation.
ai-sn35:120.5.1_0: And how is someone committed to wakefulness?
ai-sn35:120.5.2_0: It’s when a mendicant practices walking and sitting meditation by day, purifying their mind from obstacles.
ai-sn35:120.5.3_0: In the evening, they continue to practice walking and sitting meditation.
ai-sn35:120.5.4_0: In the middle of the night, they lie down in the lion’s posture—on the right side, placing one foot on top of the other—mindful and aware, and focused on the time of getting up.
ai-sn35:120.5.5_0: In the last part of the night, they get up and continue to practice walking and sitting meditation, purifying their mind from obstacles.
ai-sn35:120.5.6_0: That’s how someone is committed to wakefulness.
ai-sn35:120.5.7_0: So you should train like this:
ai-sn35:120.5.8_0: ‘We will guard the sense doors, eat in moderation, and be committed to wakefulness.’
ai-sn35:121.1.1_0: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
ai-sn35:121.1.2_0: Then as the Buddha was in private retreat this thought came to his mind,
ai-sn35:121.1.3_0: “The qualities that ripen in freedom have ripened in Rāhula.
ai-sn35:121.1.4_0: Why don’t I lead him further to the ending of defilements?”
ai-sn35:121.1.5_0: Then the Buddha robed up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, entered Sāvatthī for alms.
ai-sn35:121.1.6_0: After the meal, on his return from alms-round, he addressed Venerable Rāhula,
ai-sn35:121.1.8_0: Let’s go to the Dark Forest for the day’s meditation.”
ai-sn35:121.1.9_0: “Yes, sir,” replied Rāhula. Taking his sitting cloth he followed behind the Buddha.
ai-sn35:121.2.1_0: Now at that time many thousands of deities followed the Buddha, thinking,
ai-sn35:121.2.2_0: “Today the Buddha will lead Rāhula further to the ending of defilements!”
ai-sn35:121.2.3_0: Then the Buddha plunged deep into the Dark Forest and sat at the root of a tree on the seat spread out.
ai-sn35:121.2.4_0: Rāhula bowed to the Buddha and sat down to one side.
ai-sn35:121.3.2_0: Is the eye permanent or impermanent?”
ai-sn35:121.5.1_0: “But if they're impermanent, are they suffering or happiness?”
ai-sn35:121.7.1_0: “But if they're impermanent, suffering, and perishable, are they fit to be regarded thus:
ai-sn35:121.7.2_0: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self’?”
ai-sn35:121.15.1_0: “Anything included in feeling, perception, choices, and consciousness that arises conditioned by eye contact: is that permanent or impermanent?”
ai-sn35:121.17.1_0: “But if they're impermanent, are they suffering or happiness?”
ai-sn35:121.19.1_0: “But if they're impermanent, suffering, and perishable, are they fit to be regarded thus:
ai-sn35:121.19.2_0: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self’?”
ai-sn35:121.27.1_0: “Anything included in feeling, perception, choices, and consciousness that arises conditioned by tongue contact: is that permanent or impermanent?”
ai-sn35:121.29.1_0: “But if they're impermanent, are they suffering or happiness?”
ai-sn35:121.31.1_0: “But if they're impermanent, suffering, and perishable, are they fit to be regarded thus:
ai-sn35:121.31.2_0: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self’?”
ai-sn35:121.35.1_0: “But if they're impermanent, are they suffering or happiness?”
ai-sn35:121.37.1_0: “But if they're impermanent, suffering, and perishable, are they fit to be regarded thus:
ai-sn35:121.37.2_0: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self’?”
ai-sn35:121.45.1_0: “Anything included in feeling, perception, choices, and consciousness that arises conditioned by mind contact: is that permanent or impermanent?”
ai-sn35:121.47.1_0: “But if they're impermanent, are they suffering or happiness?”
ai-sn35:121.49.1_0: “But if they're impermanent, suffering, and perishable, are they fit to be regarded thus:
ai-sn35:121.49.2_0: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self’?”
ai-sn35:121.51.1_0: “Seeing this, a learned noble disciple grows disillusioned with the eye, sights, eye consciousness, and eye contact. And they become disillusioned with anything included in feeling, perception, choices, and consciousness that arises conditioned by eye contact.
ai-sn35:121.51.2_0: They grow disillusioned with the ear ... nose ... tongue ... body ...
ai-sn35:121.52.1_0: They grow disillusioned with the mind, thoughts, mind consciousness, and mind contact. And they grow disillusioned with anything included in feeling, perception, choices, and consciousness that arises conditioned by mind contact.
ai-sn35:121.52.2_0: Being disillusioned, desire fades away. When desire fades away they’re freed. When they’re freed, they know they’re freed.
ai-sn35:121.52.3_0: They understand: ‘Rebirth is ended, the spiritual journey has been completed, what had to be done has been done, there is no return to any state of existence.’”
ai-sn35:121.53.1_0: That is what the Buddha said.
ai-sn35:121.53.2_0: Satisfied, Venerable Rāhula was happy with what the Buddha said.
ai-sn35:121.53.3_0: And while this discourse was being spoken, Rāhula’s mind was freed from defilements by not grasping.
ai-sn35:121.53.4_0: And the stainless, immaculate vision of the Dhamma arose in those thousands of deities:
ai-sn35:121.53.5_0: “Anything that has a beginning has an end.”
ai-sn35:122.1.1_0: “Mendicants, I will teach you the things that are prone to being fettered, and what is the fetter.
ai-sn35:122.1.3_0: What are the things that are prone to being fettered? And what is the fetter?
ai-sn35:122.1.4_0: There are sights known by the eye that are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.
ai-sn35:122.1.5_0: These are called the things that are prone to being fettered.
ai-sn35:122.1.6_0: The desire and greed for it is the fetter.
ai-sn35:122.1.7_0: There are sounds ... smells ... tastes ... touches ...
ai-sn35:122.1.8_0: thoughts known by the mind that are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.
ai-sn35:122.1.9_0: These are called the things that are prone to being fettered.
ai-sn35:122.1.10_0: The desire and greed for them is the fetter.”
ai-sn35:123.1.1_0: “Mendicants, I will teach you the things that are prone to being grasped, and the grasping.
ai-sn35:123.1.3_0: What are the things that are prone to being grasped? And what is the grasping?
ai-sn35:123.1.4_0: There are sights known by the eye that are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.
ai-sn35:123.1.5_0: These are called the things that are prone to being grasped.
ai-sn35:123.1.6_0: The desire and greed for it is the grasping.
ai-sn35:123.1.7_0: There are sounds ... smells ... tastes ... touches ...
ai-sn35:123.1.8_0: thoughts known by the mind that are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.
ai-sn35:123.1.9_0: These are called the things that are prone to being grasped.
ai-sn35:123.1.10_0: The desire and greed for it is the grasping.”
ai-sn35:123.1.12_0: The second sub-chapter on sensual pleasures is finished.
ai-sn35:124.1.1_0: At one time the Buddha was staying near Vesālī, at the Great Wood, in the hall with the peaked roof.
ai-sn35:124.1.2_0: Then Ugga went up to Vesālī,
ai-sn35:124.1.2_1: and after approaching he sat down on one side.
ai-sn35:124.1.3_0: “What is the cause, sir, what is the reason why some sentient beings aren’t fully extinguished in the present life?
ai-sn35:124.1.4_0: What is the cause, sir, what is the reason why some sentient beings are fully extinguished in the present life?”
ai-sn35:124.2.1_0: “Householder, there are sights known by the eye that are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.
ai-sn35:124.2.2_0: If a mendicant approves, welcomes, and keep clinging to them,
ai-sn35:124.2.2_1: their consciousness relies on that and grasps it.
ai-sn35:124.2.3_0: A mendicant with grasping does not become extinguished.
ai-sn35:124.2.4_0: There are sounds ... smells ... tastes ... touches ...
ai-sn35:124.2.5_0: thoughts known by the mind that are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.
ai-sn35:124.2.6_0: If a mendicant approves, welcomes, and keep clinging to them,
ai-sn35:124.2.6_1: their consciousness relies on that and grasps it.
ai-sn35:124.2.7_0: A mendicant with grasping does not become extinguished.
ai-sn35:124.2.8_0: That’s the cause, that’s the reason why some sentient beings aren’t fully extinguished in the present life.
ai-sn35:124.3.1_0: There are sights known by the eye that are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.
ai-sn35:124.3.2_0: If a mendicant doesn’t approve, welcome, and keep clinging to them, they’re called a mendicant who hasn’t swallowed Māra’s hook.
ai-sn35:124.3.2_1: So their consciousness doesn’t rely on that and grasp it.
ai-sn35:124.3.4_0: There are sounds ... smells ... tastes ... touches ...
ai-sn35:124.3.5_0: thoughts known by the mind that are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.
ai-sn35:124.3.6_0: If a mendicant doesn’t approve, welcome, and keep clinging to them, relishing them, and relishing them,
ai-sn35:124.3.7_0: A mendicant free of grasping becomes extinguished.
ai-sn35:124.3.8_0: That’s the cause, that’s the reason why some sentient beings are fully extinguished in the present life.”
ai-sn35:125.1.1_0: At one time the Buddha was staying in the land of the Vajjis at the village of Hatthi.
ai-sn35:125.1.2_0: Then the householder Ugga of Hatthi went up to the Buddha,
ai-sn35:125.1.2_1: and after approaching he sat down on one side.
ai-sn35:125.1.2_2: While sitting on one side the householder Ugga of Hatthi said this to the Fortunate One:
ai-sn35:125.1.3_0: “What is the cause, sir, what is the reason why some sentient beings aren’t fully extinguished in the present life?
ai-sn35:125.1.4_0: What is the cause, sir, what is the reason why some sentient beings are fully extinguished in the present life?”
ai-sn35:125.1.5_0: (This should be told in full as in the previous discourse.)
ai-sn35:125.1.6_0: “That’s the cause, householder, that’s the reason why some sentient beings are fully extinguished in the present life.”
ai-sn35:126.1.1_0: At one time the Buddha was staying near Nālandā in Pāvārika’s mango grove.
ai-sn35:126.1.2_0: Then the householder Upāli went up to the Buddha ...
ai-sn35:126.1.2_1: He got up from his seat, bowed, and respectfully circled him, keeping him on his right. Then he went to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him,
ai-sn35:126.1.3_0: “What is the cause, sir, what is the reason why some sentient beings aren’t fully extinguished in the present life?
ai-sn35:126.1.4_0: What is the cause, sir, what is the reason why some sentient beings are fully extinguished in the present life?”
ai-sn35:126.1.5_0: (This should be told in full as in the previous discourse.)
ai-sn35:126.1.6_0: “That’s the cause, householder, that’s the reason why some sentient beings are fully extinguished in the present life.”
ai-sn35:127.1.1_0: At one time Venerable Piṇḍola Bhāradvāja was staying near Kosambi, in Ghosita’s Monastery.
ai-sn35:127.1.2_0: King Udena then went to his Piṇḍola Bhāradvāja,
ai-sn35:127.1.2_1: and after going, he exchanged greetings with him.
ai-sn35:127.1.3_0: and after exchanging courteous talk and greetings, he sat down on one side.
ai-sn35:127.1.4_0: “Master Bhāradvāja, there are these young monks who are youthful, black-haired, blessed with youth, in the prime of life; and they’ve never played around with sensual pleasures. What is the cause, what is the reason why they practice the full and pure spiritual life as long as they live, maintaining it for a long time?”
ai-sn35:127.1.5_0: “Great king, this has been stated by the Blessed One, who knows and sees, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha:
ai-sn35:127.1.6_0: ‘Please, monks, think of women your mother’s age as your mother. Think of women your sister’s age as your sister. And think of women your daughter’s age as your daughter.’
ai-sn35:127.1.7_0: This is a cause, great king, this is a reason why these young monks practice the full and pure spiritual life as long as they live, maintaining it for a long time.”
ai-sn35:127.2.1_0: “But Master Bhāradvāja, the mind is wanton.
ai-sn35:127.2.2_0: Sometimes thoughts of desire come up even for women your mother’s age, your sister’s age, or your daughter’s age.
ai-sn35:127.2.3_0: Is there another cause, another reason why these young monks live the full and pure spiritual life for their entire life?
ai-sn35:127.3.1_0: “Great king, this has been stated by the Blessed One, who knows and sees, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha:
ai-sn35:127.3.2_0: ‘Please, monks, examine your own body up from the soles of the feet and down from the tips of the hairs, wrapped in skin and full of many kinds of filth.
ai-sn35:127.3.3_0: In this body there is head hair, body hair, nails, teeth, skin, flesh, sinews, bones, bone marrow, kidneys, heart, liver, diaphragm, spleen, lungs, intestines, mesentery, undigested food, feces, bile, phlegm, pus, blood, sweat, fat, tears, grease, saliva, snot, synovial fluid, urine.’
ai-sn35:127.3.4_0: This is also a cause, great king, this is a reason why these young monks live the full and pure spiritual life for their entire life,
ai-sn35:127.3.5_0: “This is easy to do for those mendicants who have developed their physical endurance, ethics, mind, and wisdom.
ai-sn35:127.3.6_0: But those mendicants who have not developed their physical endurance, ethics, mind, and wisdom.
ai-sn35:127.3.7_0: Sometimes I plan to focus on something as ugly, but only its beauty comes to mind.
ai-sn35:127.3.8_0: Is there another cause, another reason why these young monks live the full and pure spiritual life for their entire life? ...
ai-sn35:127.4.1_0: “Great king, this has been stated by the Blessed One, who knows and sees, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha:
ai-sn35:127.4.2_0: ‘Please, monks, live with sense doors guarded.
ai-sn35:127.4.3_0: When you see a sight with your eyes, don’t get caught up in the features and details.
ai-sn35:127.4.4_0: If the faculty of sight were left unrestrained, bad unskillful qualities of desire and aversion would become overwhelming.
ai-sn35:127.4.4_2: practice restraint of the eye faculty.
ai-sn35:127.4.5_0: When you hear a sound with your ears ...
ai-sn35:127.4.6_0: When they smell an odor with their nose ...
ai-sn35:127.4.7_0: Tasting a flavor with the tongue ...
ai-sn35:127.4.8_0: Feeling a touch with the body ...
ai-sn35:127.4.9_0: When they know a thought with their mind, don’t get caught up in the features and details.
ai-sn35:127.4.10_0: If the faculty of mind were left unrestrained, bad unskillful qualities of desire and aversion would become overwhelming.
ai-sn35:127.4.11_0: This is a cause, great king, this is a reason why these young monks practice the full and pure spiritual life as long as they live, maintaining it for a long time.”
ai-sn35:127.5.2_0: How well this was said by the Buddha!
ai-sn35:127.5.3_0: This is the real cause, this is the reason why these young monks practice the full and pure spiritual life as long as they live, maintaining it for a long time.
ai-sn35:127.5.4_0: For sometimes I too enter the harem with unprotected body, speech, mind, mindfulness, and sense faculties. At those times powerful thoughts of desire get the better of me.
ai-sn35:127.5.5_0: But sometimes I enter the harem with protected body, speech, mind, mindfulness, and sense faculties. At those times such thoughts of desire don’t get the better of me.
ai-sn35:127.5.7_0: Just as one might set upright what had been overturned, or reveal what was hidden, or show the way to one who was lost, or bring a lamp into the darkness so that
ai-sn35:127.5.7_1: so that one with eyes might see what’s there—
ai-sn35:127.5.7_2: just so has the Dhamma been made clear by reverend Sir,
ai-sn35:127.5.8_0: I go for refuge to the Buddha, to the teaching, and to the mendicant Saṅgha.
ai-sn35:127.5.9_0: From this day forth, may Master Bhāradvāja remember me as a lay follower who has gone for refuge for life.”
ai-sn35:128.1.1_0: At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha, in the Bamboo Grove, the squirrels’ feeding ground.
ai-sn35:128.1.2_0: Then the householder Soṇa went up to the Buddha.
ai-sn35:128.1.3_0: “What is the cause, sir, what is the reason why some sentient beings aren’t fully extinguished in the present life?
ai-sn35:128.1.4_0: What is the cause, sir, what is the reason why some sentient beings are fully extinguished in the present life?”
ai-sn35:128.1.5_0: (This should be told in full as in the previous discourse.)
ai-sn35:128.1.6_0: That’s the cause, that’s the reason why some sentient beings are fully extinguished in the present life.
ai-sn35:129.1.1_0: At one time Venerable Ānanda was staying near Kosambi, in Ghosita’s Monastery.
ai-sn35:129.1.2_0: Then Ghosita went up to Venerable Ānanda ...
ai-sn35:129.1.3_0: “Sir, Ānanda, they speak of ‘the diversity of elements’.
ai-sn35:129.1.4_0: In what way did the Buddha speak of the diversity of elements?”
ai-sn35:129.1.5_0: “Householder, the eye element is found, as are sights that are agreeable to be disagreeable sights.
ai-sn35:129.1.6_0: There is mind consciousness; and pleasant feeling arises dependent on a contact to be experienced as pleasant.
ai-sn35:129.1.7_0: The eye element is found, as are disagreeable sights, and eye consciousness.
ai-sn35:129.1.8_0: There is mind consciousness; and painful feeling arises dependent on a contact to be experienced as painful.
ai-sn35:129.1.9_0: The eye element is found, as are sights that are a basis for equanimity, and eye consciousness.
ai-sn35:129.1.10_0: Neutral feeling arises dependent on a contact to be experienced as neutral.
ai-sn35:129.1.12_0: There is mind consciousness; and pleasant feeling arises dependent on a contact to be experienced as pleasant.
ai-sn35:129.1.14_0: There is mind consciousness; and painful feeling arises dependent on a contact to be experienced as painful.
ai-sn35:129.1.16_0: Neutral feeling arises dependent on a contact to be experienced as neutral.
ai-sn35:129.1.17_0: mind element is found, as are agreeable thoughts, and mind consciousness.
ai-sn35:129.1.18_0: There is mind consciousness; and pleasant feeling arises dependent on a contact to be experienced as pleasant.
ai-sn35:129.1.19_0: mind element is found, as are disagreeable thoughts, and mind consciousness.
ai-sn35:129.1.20_0: There is mind consciousness; and painful feeling arises dependent on a contact to be experienced as painful.
ai-sn35:129.1.21_0: The mind element is found, as are thoughts that are a basis for equanimity, and mind consciousness.
ai-sn35:129.1.22_0: Neutral feeling arises dependent on a contact to be experienced as neutral.
ai-sn35:129.1.23_0: To this extent the Buddha spoke of the diversity of elements.”
ai-sn35:129.1.24_0: The sixth offering to an individual.
ai-sn35:130.1.1_0: At one time Venerable Mahākaccāna was staying in the land of the Avantis near Kurararaghara on Steep Mountain.
ai-sn35:130.1.2_0: Then the householder Hāliddikāni went up to Venerable Mahākaccāna ...
ai-sn35:130.1.2_1: He bowed, sat down to one side, and said to Mahākaccāna:
ai-sn35:130.1.3_0: “Sir, this was said by the Buddha.
ai-sn35:130.1.4_0: ‘Diversity of elements gives rise to diversity of contacts, and diversity of contacts gives rise to diversity of feelings.’
ai-sn35:130.1.5_0: How does diversity of elements give rise to diversity of contacts,
ai-sn35:130.1.5_1: diversity of contacts gives rise to diversity of feelings.”
ai-sn35:130.1.6_0: “Householder, it’s when a mendicant sees a sight and understands it to be agreeable.
ai-sn35:130.1.7_0: There is mind consciousness; and pleasant feeling arises dependent on a contact to be experienced as pleasant.
ai-sn35:130.1.8_0: Then they see a sight and understand it to be agreeable.
ai-sn35:130.1.9_0: There is mind consciousness; and painful feeling arises dependent on a contact to be experienced as painful.
ai-sn35:130.1.10_0: Then they see a sight and understand it to be a basis for equanimity.
ai-sn35:130.1.11_0: Neutral feeling arises dependent on a contact to be experienced as neutral.
ai-sn35:130.2.1_0: Furthermore, a mendicant hears a sound with the ear ...
ai-sn35:130.2.2_0: When I smelled an odor with my nose ...
ai-sn35:130.2.3_0: tastes a flavor with the tongue ...
ai-sn35:130.2.4_0: feels an agreeable touch with the body ...
ai-sn35:130.2.5_0: knows a thought with the mind and understands it to be agreeable.
ai-sn35:130.2.6_0: There is mind consciousness; and pleasant feeling arises dependent on a contact to be experienced as pleasant.
ai-sn35:130.2.7_0: Then they know a thought and understand it to be disagreeable.
ai-sn35:130.2.8_0: There is mind consciousness; and painful feeling arises dependent on a contact to be experienced as painful.
ai-sn35:130.2.9_0: Then they know a thought and understand it to be a basis for equanimity.
ai-sn35:130.2.10_0: Neutral feeling arises dependent on a contact to be experienced as neutral.
ai-sn35:130.2.11_0: That’s how diversity of elements gives rise to diversity of contacts.
ai-sn35:130.2.11_1: diversity of contacts gives rise to diversity of feelings.”
ai-sn35:131.1.1_0: At one time the Buddha was staying in the land of the Bhaggas on Crocodile Hill, in the deer park at Bhesakaḷā’s Wood.
ai-sn35:131.1.2_0: Then the householder Nakula’s father went up to the Buddha ...
ai-sn35:131.1.2_1: Nakula’s father said to the Buddha,
ai-sn35:131.1.3_0: “What is the cause, sir, what is the reason why some sentient beings aren’t fully extinguished in the present life?
ai-sn35:131.1.4_0: What is the cause, sir, what is the reason why some sentient beings are fully extinguished in the present life?”
ai-sn35:131.1.5_0: “Householder, there are sights known by the eye that are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.
ai-sn35:131.1.6_0: If a mendicant approves, welcomes, and keep clinging to them,
ai-sn35:131.1.7_0: their consciousness relies on that and grasps it.
ai-sn35:131.1.8_0: A mendicant with grasping does not become extinguished.
ai-sn35:131.1.9_0: There are sounds ... smells ... tastes ... touches ...
ai-sn35:131.1.10_0: thoughts known by the mind that are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.
ai-sn35:131.1.11_0: If a mendicant approves, welcomes, and keep clinging to them,
ai-sn35:131.1.12_0: their consciousness relies on that and grasps it.
ai-sn35:131.1.13_0: A mendicant with grasping does not become extinguished.
ai-sn35:131.1.14_0: That’s the cause, that’s the reason why some sentient beings aren’t fully extinguished in the present life.
ai-sn35:131.2.1_0: There are sights known by the eye that are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.
ai-sn35:131.2.2_0: If a mendicant doesn’t approve, welcome, and keep clinging to them, they’re called a mendicant who hasn’t swallowed Māra’s hook.
ai-sn35:131.2.3_0: So their consciousness doesn’t rely on that and grasp it.
ai-sn35:131.2.5_0: There are sounds ... smells ... tastes ... touches ...
ai-sn35:131.2.6_0: thoughts known by the mind that are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.
ai-sn35:131.2.7_0: If a mendicant doesn’t approve, welcome, and keep clinging to them, they’re called a mendicant who hasn’t swallowed Māra’s hook.
ai-sn35:131.2.8_0: So their consciousness doesn’t rely on that and grasp it.
ai-sn35:131.2.9_0: A mendicant free of grasping becomes extinguished.
ai-sn35:131.2.10_0: That’s the cause, that’s the reason why some sentient beings are fully extinguished in the present life.”
ai-sn35:132.1.1_0: At one time Venerable Mahākaccāna was staying in the land of the Avantis in a wilderness hut near Makkarakaṭa.
ai-sn35:132.1.2_0: Then Lohicca went up to Mahākaccāna in a wilderness hut and made the whole forest hut.
ai-sn35:132.1.2_1: and after going, they making a dreadful rackets made a dreadful racket, saying:
ai-sn35:132.1.3_0: “These shavelings, fake ascetics, riffraff, black spawn from the feet of our Kinsman, the Lord! They’re honored, respected, esteemed, revered, and venerated by those who pretend to inherit Vedic culture.”
ai-sn35:132.1.4_0: And then Mahākaccāna left his dwelling and said to those brahmin students,
ai-sn35:132.1.6_0: I will speak to you on the teaching.”
ai-sn35:132.1.7_0: When he said this, those students kept silent.
ai-sn35:132.1.8_0: Then Mahākaccāna recited these verses for them.
ai-sn35:132.2.1_0: “The brahmins of old excelled in ethics,
ai-sn35:132.2.3_0: Their sense doors were guarded, well protected,
ai-sn35:132.4.1_0: But these have lost their way. Claiming to recite,
ai-sn35:132.4.2_0: they live out of balance, judging everyone by their clan.
ai-sn35:132.4.3_0: Mastered by anger, they take up many arms,
ai-sn35:132.4.4_0: attacking both the strong and the weak.
ai-sn35:132.5.1_0: All is vain for someone who doesn’t guard the sense doors,
ai-sn35:132.5.2_0: like the wealth a person finds in a dream.
ai-sn35:132.5.4_0: bathing at dawn, the three Vedas,
ai-sn35:132.6.2_0: hymns, precepts and observances, and self-mortification,
ai-sn35:132.7.4_0: that’s the path to attainment of Brahmā!”
ai-sn35:132.8.1_0: Then those students, offended and upset, went to the brahmin Lohicca.
ai-sn35:132.8.1_1: and after approaching, they said this to the brahmin Lohicca:
ai-sn35:132.8.2_0: “Please, master, you should know this. The ascetic Mahākaccāna condemns and rejects outright the hymns of the brahmins!”
ai-sn35:132.8.3_0: When he said this, Lohicca was angry and upset.
ai-sn35:132.8.5_0: “But it wouldn’t be appropriate for me to abuse or insult the ascetic Mahākaccāna solely because of what I’ve heard from these students.
ai-sn35:132.8.6_0: Why don’t I go and ask him about this?”
ai-sn35:132.9.1_0: Then Lohicca went to Mahākaccāna together with those students.
ai-sn35:132.9.1_1: and after going, he exchanged greetings with him.
ai-sn35:132.9.2_0: and after exchanging courteous talk and greetings, he sat down on one side.
ai-sn35:132.9.2_1: He bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him,
ai-sn35:132.9.3_0: “Master Kaccāna, did several young students of mine come by here collecting firewood?”
ai-sn35:132.9.4_0: “While did several young students of mine come by here collecting firewood?”
ai-sn35:132.9.5_0: “And did you have some discussion with them?”
ai-sn35:132.9.6_0: “Brahmin, did you have some discussion with him?”
ai-sn35:132.9.7_0: “But what kind of discussion did you have with them?”
ai-sn35:132.9.8_0: “This is the discussion I had with these students.”
ai-sn35:132.10.5_0: that’s the path to attainment of Brahmā!’
ai-sn35:132.11.1_0: That’s how I had some discussion with these students.”
ai-sn35:132.12.1_0: “Master Kaccāna spoke of someone who doesn’t guard the sense doors.
ai-sn35:132.12.2_0: How do you define someone who doesn’t guard the sense doors?”
ai-sn35:132.12.3_0: “Brahmin, take someone who sees a sight with their eyes. If it’s pleasant they hold on to it, but if it’s unpleasant they dislike it. They live with mindfulness of the body unestablished and their heart restricted.
ai-sn35:132.12.5_0: When you hear a sound with your ears ...
ai-sn35:132.12.6_0: When they smell an odor with their nose ...
ai-sn35:132.12.7_0: Tasting a flavor with the tongue ...
ai-sn35:132.12.8_0: Feeling a touch with the body ...
ai-sn35:132.12.9_0: know a thought with the mind. If it’s pleasant they hold on to it, but if it’s unpleasant they dislike it. They live with mindfulness of the body unestablished and a limited heart.
ai-sn35:132.12.11_0: That’s how someone doesn’t guard the sense doors.”
ai-sn35:132.12.13_0: How accurately you’ve explained someone whose sense doors are unguarded!
ai-sn35:132.13.2_0: How do you define someone who does guard the sense doors?”
ai-sn35:132.13.3_0: “Brahmin, it’s when a mendicant sees a sight with their eyes. If it’s pleasant they don’t hold on to it, and if it’s unpleasant they don’t dislike it. They live with mindfulness of the body established and a limitless heart.
ai-sn35:132.13.4_0: And they do understand where those arisen bad, unskillful qualities cease without anything left over.
ai-sn35:132.13.5_0: When you hear a sound with your ears ...
ai-sn35:132.13.6_0: When they smell an odor with their nose ...
ai-sn35:132.13.7_0: Tasting a flavor with the tongue ...
ai-sn35:132.13.8_0: Feeling a touch with the body ...
ai-sn35:132.13.9_0: know a thought with the mind. If it’s pleasant they don’t hold on to it, and if it’s unpleasant they don’t dislike it. They live with mindfulness of the body established and a limitless heart.
ai-sn35:132.13.10_0: And they do understand where those arisen bad, unskillful qualities cease without anything left over.
ai-sn35:132.13.11_0: That’s how someone guards the sense doors.”
ai-sn35:132.14.2_0: How accurately you’ve explained someone whose sense doors are guarded!
ai-sn35:132.14.4_0: Just as one might set upright what had been overturned, or reveal what was hidden, or show the way to one who was lost, or bring a lamp into the darkness so that
ai-sn35:132.14.4_1: so that one with eyes might see what’s there—
ai-sn35:132.14.4_2: just so has the Dhamma been explained by the dear Kaccāna in many ways.
ai-sn35:132.14.5_0: I go for refuge to the Buddha, to the teaching, and to the mendicant Saṅgha.
ai-sn35:132.14.6_0: From this day forth, may Master Kaccāna remember me as a lay follower who has gone for refuge for life.
ai-sn35:132.14.7_0: Please come to my family just as you go to the families of the lay followers in Makkarakaṭa.
ai-sn35:132.14.8_0: The brahmin boys and girls there will bow to you, rise in your presence, and give you a seat and water. That will be for their lasting welfare and happiness.”
ai-sn35:133.1.1_0: At one time Venerable Udāyī was staying near Kāmaṇḍā in the brahmin Todeyya’s mango grove.
ai-sn35:133.1.2_0: Then a boy who was a student of the brahmin lady of the Verahaccāni clan went up to Udāyī and Udāyī.
ai-sn35:133.1.2_1: and after approaching he exchanged greetings with him.
ai-sn35:133.1.3_0: and after exchanging courteous talk and greetings, he sat down on one side.
ai-sn35:133.1.4_0: Udāyī educated, encouraged, fired up, and inspired that student with a Dhamma talk.
ai-sn35:133.1.5_0: Then that student went to the brahmin lady of the Verahaccāni clan.
ai-sn35:133.1.5_1: and after approaching he said this to the brahmin lady:
ai-sn35:133.1.7_0: The ascetic Udāyī teaches Dhamma that’s good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, meaningful and well-phrased. And he reveals a spiritual practice that’s entirely full and pure.”
ai-sn35:133.2.1_0: “Then, student, invite him in my name for tomorrow’s meal.”
ai-sn35:133.2.2_1: and after going, he said this to venerable Udāyī:
ai-sn35:133.2.3_0: “Sir, may Master Udāyī please accept an offering of tomorrow’s meal from my teacher’s wife, the brahmin lady of the Verahaccāni clan.”
ai-sn35:133.2.5_0: Then when the night had passed, Udāyī robed up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, went to the brahmin lady’s home.
ai-sn35:133.2.5_1: and after going, he sat down on the prepared seat.
ai-sn35:133.2.6_0: Then the brahmin lady served and satisfied Udāyī with her own hands with a variety of delicious foods.
ai-sn35:133.2.7_0: When Udāyī had eaten and washed his hand and bowl, she put on a pair of shoes, sat on a high seat, covered her head, and said to him,
ai-sn35:133.2.9_0: “There will be an occasion for that, sister,” he replied, then got up from his seat and left.
ai-sn35:133.3.1_0: For a second time that student went to Udāyī
ai-sn35:133.3.1_1: and after approaching he exchanged greetings with him.
ai-sn35:133.3.2_0: and after exchanging courteous talk and greetings, he sat down on one side.
ai-sn35:133.3.3_0: Udāyī educated, encouraged, fired up, and inspired that student with a Dhamma talk.
ai-sn35:133.3.4_0: And for a second time that student went to the brahmin lady of the Verahaccāni clan ...
ai-sn35:133.3.4_1: and after approaching he said this to the brahmin lady:
ai-sn35:133.3.6_0: The ascetic Udāyī teaches Dhamma that’s good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, meaningful and well-phrased. And he reveals a spiritual practice that’s entirely full and pure.”
ai-sn35:133.4.1_0: She said to him, “You keep praising the ascetic Udāyī like this.
ai-sn35:133.4.2_0: But when I asked him to preach the Dhamma he just said that there would be an occasion for that, and then he got up and left.”
ai-sn35:133.4.5_0: For the masters respect the teaching.”
ai-sn35:133.4.6_0: “Then, student, invite him in my name for tomorrow’s meal.”
ai-sn35:133.4.7_1: and after going, he said this to venerable Udāyī:
ai-sn35:133.4.8_0: “Sir, may Master Udāyī please accept an offering of tomorrow’s meal from my teacher’s wife, the brahmin lady of the Verahaccāni clan.”
ai-sn35:133.5.1_0: Then when the night had passed, Udāyī robed up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, went to the brahmin lady’s home.
ai-sn35:133.5.1_1: and after going, he sat down on the prepared seat.
ai-sn35:133.5.2_0: Then the brahmin lady served and satisfied Udāyī with her own hands with a variety of delicious foods.
ai-sn35:133.5.3_0: When Udāyī had eaten and washed his hand and bowl, she took off her shoes, sat on a low seat, uncovered her head, and said to him,
ai-sn35:133.5.4_0: “Sir, when what exists do the perfected ones declare that there is pleasure and pain? When what doesn’t exist do the perfected ones not declare that there is pleasure and pain?”
ai-sn35:133.6.1_0: “Sister, when there’s an eye, the perfected ones declare that there is pleasure and pain. When there’s no eye, the perfected ones don’t declare that there is pleasure and pain.
ai-sn35:133.6.2_0: When there’s an ear ... nose ... tongue ... body ...
ai-sn35:133.6.3_0: mind, the perfected ones declare that there is pleasure and pain. When there’s no mind, the perfected ones don’t declare that there is pleasure and pain.”
ai-sn35:133.7.1_0: When he said this, the brahmin lady said to Udāyī,
ai-sn35:133.7.3_0: Just as one might set upright what had been overturned, or reveal what was hidden, or show the way to one who was lost, or bring a lamp into the darkness so that
ai-sn35:133.7.3_1: so that one with eyes might see what’s there—
ai-sn35:133.7.3_2: even so has the Dhamma been explained in many ways.
ai-sn35:133.7.4_0: I go for refuge to the Buddha, to the teaching, and to the mendicant Saṅgha.
ai-sn35:133.7.5_0: From this day forth, may Venerable Udāyī remember me as a lay follower who has gone for refuge for life.”
ai-sn35:133.7.7_0: The third sub-chapter on householders is finished.
ai-sn35:134.1.1_0: At one time the Buddha was staying in the land of the Sakyans, near the Sakyan town named Devadaha.
ai-sn35:134.1.3_0: “When it comes to the six fields of contact, mendicants, I don’t say that all mendicants have work to do with diligence, nor do I say that none of them have work to do with diligence.
ai-sn35:134.1.4_0: I say that, when it comes to the six fields of contact, mendicants don’t have work to do with diligence if they are perfected, with defilements ended, having completed the spiritual journey, done what had to be done, laid down the burden, achieved their own goal, utterly ended the fetters of rebirth, and become rightly freed through enlightenment.
ai-sn35:134.1.6_0: They’ve done their work with diligence, and are incapable of negligence.
ai-sn35:134.1.7_0: I say that, when it comes to the six fields of contact, mendicants do have work to do with diligence if they are trainees, who haven’t achieved their heart’s desire, but live aspiring to the supreme sanctuary.
ai-sn35:134.1.9_0: There are sights known by the eye that are pleasant and also those that are unpleasant.
ai-sn35:134.1.10_0: Though experiencing them again and again they don’t occupy the mind.
ai-sn35:134.1.11_0: Their energy is roused up and unflagging, their mindfulness is established and lucid, their body is tranquil and undisturbed, and their mind is immersed in samādhi.
ai-sn35:134.1.12_0: Seeing this fruit of diligence, I say that those mendicants have work to do with diligence when it comes to the six fields of contact. ...
ai-sn35:134.1.13_0: There are thoughts known by the mind that are pleasant and also those that are unpleasant.
ai-sn35:134.1.14_0: Though experiencing them again and again they don’t occupy the mind.
ai-sn35:134.1.15_0: Their energy is roused up and unflagging, their mindfulness is established and lucid, their body is tranquil and undisturbed, and their mind is immersed in samādhi.
ai-sn35:134.1.16_0: Seeing this fruit of diligence, I say that those mendicants have work to do with diligence when it comes to the six fields of contact.”
ai-sn35:135.1.1_0: “You’re so fortunate, mendicants, so very fortunate,
ai-sn35:135.1.2_0: to have the opportunity to lead the spiritual life.
ai-sn35:135.1.3_0: I’ve seen the hell called ‘the six fields of contact’.
ai-sn35:135.1.4_0: There, whatever sight you see with your eye is unlikable, not likable;
ai-sn35:135.1.4_1: (They see) do they not see (them), but are not appropriate.
ai-sn35:135.1.5_0: Whatever sound you hear ... Whatever odor you smell ... Whatever flavor you taste ...
ai-sn35:135.1.9_0: Whatever thought you know with your mind is unlikable, not likable;
ai-sn35:135.1.9_1: one knows nothing but is not appropriate,
ai-sn35:135.1.10_0: You’re fortunate, mendicants, so very fortunate,
ai-sn35:135.1.11_0: to have the opportunity to lead the spiritual life.
ai-sn35:135.1.12_0: I’ve seen the heaven called ‘the six fields of contact’.
ai-sn35:135.1.13_0: There, whatever sight you see with your eye is likable, not unlikable.
ai-sn35:135.1.13_1: One who sees only as formless, not unself.
ai-sn35:135.1.15_0: Whatever thought you know with your mind is likable, not unlikable.
ai-sn35:135.1.15_1: He knows nothing but is not appropriate,
ai-sn35:135.1.16_0: You’re fortunate, mendicants, so very fortunate,
ai-sn35:135.1.17_0: to have the opportunity to lead the spiritual life.”
ai-sn35:136.1.1_0: “Mendicants, sights, sounds, smells, tastes, and touches.
ai-sn35:136.1.2_0: But when sights perish, fade away, and cease, gods and humans live in suffering. ...
ai-sn35:136.1.3_0: Because sounds, they hear the sounds and smells.
ai-sn35:136.1.8_0: thoughts, they love them and enjoy them.
ai-sn35:136.1.9_0: But when thoughts perish, fade away, and cease, gods and humans live in suffering.
ai-sn35:136.1.10_0: The Realized One has truly understood the origin, ending, gratification, drawback, and escape of sights, so he doesn’t like, love, or enjoy them.
ai-sn35:136.1.11_0: When sights perish, fade away, and cease, the Realized One lives happily. ...”
ai-sn35:136.1.12_0: The Realized One has truly understood the origin, ending, gratification, drawback, and escape of sounds ...
ai-sn35:136.1.16_0: thoughts, so he doesn’t like, love, or enjoy them.
ai-sn35:136.1.17_0: When thoughts perish, fade away, and cease, the Realized One lives happily.”
ai-sn35:136.1.18_0: That is what the Buddha said.
ai-sn35:136.1.19_0: Then the Holy One, the Teacher, went on to say:
ai-sn35:136.2.2_0: touches and thoughts, the lot of them—
ai-sn35:136.2.4_0: as long as you can say that they exist.
ai-sn35:136.3.1_0: in all the world with its gods,
ai-sn35:136.4.1_0: The noble ones have seen that happiness
ai-sn35:136.5.2_0: the noble ones say is suffering.
ai-sn35:136.5.4_0: the noble ones say is happiness.
ai-sn35:136.6.1_0: See, this teaching is hard to understand,
ai-sn35:136.6.4_0: for them, all is blind darkness.
ai-sn35:136.7.1_0: But those who see are open;
ai-sn35:136.7.2_0: for the good, it is light.
ai-sn35:136.7.3_0: Though it’s right there, the unskilled fools
ai-sn35:136.8.2_0: flowing along the stream of lives,
ai-sn35:136.8.4_0: by those mired in greed and hate.
ai-sn35:136.9.1_0: Who else, except a dead person?
ai-sn35:136.9.2_0: is qualified to understand this state?

ai-sn35:140.1.2_0: The cause and condition that gives rise to the eye is also impermanent.
ai-sn35:140.1.3_0: Since the eye is produced by what is impermanent, how could it be permanent?
ai-sn35:140.1.5_0: The cause and condition that gives rise to the ear ... nose ... tongue ... body ...
ai-sn35:140.1.6_0: Since the ear ... nose ... tongue ... body ...
ai-sn35:140.1.8_0: The cause and condition that gives rise to the mind is also impermanent.
ai-sn35:140.1.9_0: Since the mind is produced by what is impermanent, how could it be permanent?
ai-sn35:140.1.10_1: They are repelled by the ear ... nose ... tongue ... body ...
ai-sn35:140.1.11_0: Being disillusioned, desire fades away. When desire fades away they’re freed. When they’re freed, they know they’re freed.
ai-sn35:140.1.12_0: They understand: ‘Rebirth is ended, the spiritual journey has been completed, what had to be done has been done, there is no return to any state of existence.’”
ai-sn35:141.1.2_0: The cause and condition that gives rise to the eye is also suffering.
ai-sn35:141.1.3_0: Since the eye is produced by what is suffering, how could it be happiness?
ai-sn35:141.1.5_0: The cause and condition that gives rise to the tongue is also suffering.
ai-sn35:141.1.6_0: Since the ear ... nose ... tongue ... body ...
ai-sn35:141.1.8_0: The cause and condition that gives rise to the mind is also suffering.
ai-sn35:141.1.9_0: Since the mind is produced by what is suffering, how could it be happiness?
ai-sn35:141.1.11_0: They understand: ‘... there is no return to any state of existence.’”
ai-sn35:142.1.2_0: The cause and condition that gives rise to the eye is also not-self.
ai-sn35:142.1.3_0: Since the eye is produced by what is not-self, how could it be self?
ai-sn35:142.1.5_0: The cause and condition that gives rise to the tongue is also not-self.
ai-sn35:142.1.6_0: Since the ear ... nose ... tongue ... body ...
ai-sn35:142.1.8_0: The cause and condition that gives rise to the mind is also not-self.
ai-sn35:142.1.9_0: Since the mind is produced by what is not-self, how could it be self?
ai-sn35:142.1.11_0: They understand: ‘... there is no return to any state of existence.’”
ai-sn35:143.1.2_0: The cause and condition that gives rise to sights is also impermanent.
ai-sn35:143.1.3_0: Since sights are produced by what is impermanent, how could they be permanent?
ai-sn35:143.1.9_0: The cause and condition that gives rise to thoughts is also impermanent.
ai-sn35:143.1.10_0: Since thoughts are produced by what is impermanent, how could they be permanent?
ai-sn35:143.1.12_0: They understand: ‘... there is no return to any state of existence.’”
ai-sn35:144.1.2_0: The cause and condition that gives rise to sights is also suffering.
ai-sn35:144.1.3_0: Since sights are produced by what is suffering, how could they be happiness?
ai-sn35:144.1.9_0: The cause and condition that gives rise to thoughts is also suffering.
ai-sn35:144.1.10_0: Since thoughts are produced by what is suffering, how could they be happiness?
ai-sn35:144.1.12_0: They understand: ‘... there is no return to any state of existence.’”
ai-sn35:145.1.2_0: The cause and condition that gives rise to sights is also not-self.
ai-sn35:145.1.3_0: Since sights are produced by what is not-self, how could they be self?
ai-sn35:145.1.9_0: The cause and condition that gives rise to thoughts is also not-self.
ai-sn35:145.1.10_0: Since thoughts are produced by what is not-self, how could they be self?
ai-sn35:145.1.12_0: Being disillusioned, desire fades away. When desire fades away they’re freed. When they’re freed, they know they’re freed.
ai-sn35:145.1.13_0: They understand: ‘Rebirth is ended, the spiritual journey has been completed, what had to be done has been done, there is no return to any state of existence.’”
ai-sn35:145.1.15_0: The fourth sub-chapter on Devadatta is finished.
ai-sn35:146.1.1_0: “Mendicants, I will teach you old action, new action, the cessation of action, and the practice that leads to the cessation of action.
ai-sn35:146.1.2_0: Listen and pay close attention, I will speak.
ai-sn35:146.1.4_0: The eye is old action. It should be seen as produced by choices and intentions, as something to be felt.
ai-sn35:146.1.6_0: old age and death should be seen as produced by choices and intentions, as something to be felt.
ai-sn35:146.1.9_0: The deeds you currently perform by way of body, speech, and mind.
ai-sn35:146.1.11_0: And what is the cessation of deeds?
ai-sn35:146.1.12_0: It’s when someone does bad deeds by way of body, speech, and mind.
ai-sn35:146.1.13_0: This is called the cessation of action.
ai-sn35:146.1.14_0: And what is the practice that leads to the cessation of deeds?
ai-sn35:146.1.16_0: right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right immersion.
ai-sn35:146.1.17_0: This is called the practice that leads to the cessation of deeds.
ai-sn35:146.1.18_0: So, mendicants, I’ve taught you old action, new action, the cessation of action, and the practice that leads to the cessation of action.
ai-sn35:146.1.19_0: Out of compassion, I’ve done what a teacher should do who wants what’s best for their disciples.
ai-sn35:146.1.20_0: Here are these roots of trees, and here are these empty huts.
ai-sn35:146.1.20_1: Practice absorption, mendicants, don’t be negligent!
ai-sn35:146.1.20_3: This is my instruction to you.”
ai-sn35:147.1.1_0: “Mendicants, I will teach you a practice that’s conducive to extinguishment.
ai-sn35:147.1.2_0: Listen and pay close attention, I will speak. ...
ai-sn35:147.1.3_0: And what is that practice that’s conducive to extinguishment?
ai-sn35:147.1.4_0: It’s when a mendicant sees that the eye, sights, eye consciousness, and eye contact are impermanent.
ai-sn35:147.1.4_1: And they see that the painful, pleasant, or neutral feeling that arises conditioned by eye contact is also impermanent.
ai-sn35:147.1.5_0: They see that the ear ... nose ... tongue ... body ...
ai-sn35:147.1.6_0: mind, thoughts, mind-consciousness, and mind contact are impermanent. And they see that the painful, pleasant, or neutral feeling that arises conditioned by mind contact is also impermanent.
ai-sn35:147.1.7_0: This is that practice that’s conducive to extinguishment.”
ai-sn35:148.1.1_0: “Mendicants, I will teach you a practice that’s conducive to extinguishment.
ai-sn35:148.1.2_0: Listen and pay close attention, I will speak. ...
ai-sn35:148.1.3_0: And what is that practice that’s conducive to extinguishment?
ai-sn35:148.1.4_0: It’s when someone sees that the eye, sights, eye consciousness, and eye contact are suffering. And they see that the painful, pleasant, or neutral feeling that arises conditioned by eye contact is also suffering.
ai-sn35:148.1.5_0: They see that the ear ... nose ... tongue ... body ...
ai-sn35:148.1.6_0: mind, thoughts, mind-consciousness, and mind contact are suffering. And they see that the painful, pleasant, or neutral feeling that arises conditioned by mind contact is also suffering.
ai-sn35:148.1.7_0: This is that practice that’s conducive to extinguishment.”
ai-sn35:149.1.1_0: “Mendicants, I will teach you a practice that’s conducive to extinguishment.
ai-sn35:149.1.2_0: Listen and pay close attention, I will speak. ...
ai-sn35:149.1.3_0: And what is that practice that’s conducive to extinguishment?
ai-sn35:149.1.4_0: It’s when a mendicant sees that the eye, sights, eye consciousness, and eye contact are not-self. And they see that the painful, pleasant, or neutral feeling that arises conditioned by eye contact is also not-self.
ai-sn35:149.1.5_0: mind, thoughts, mind-consciousness, and mind contact are not-self. And they see that the painful, pleasant, or neutral feeling that arises conditioned by mind contact is also not-self.
ai-sn35:149.1.6_0: This is that practice that’s conducive to extinguishment.”
ai-sn35:150.1.1_0: “Mendicants, I will teach you a practice that’s conducive to extinguishment.
ai-sn35:150.1.2_0: Listen and pay close attention, I will speak. ...
ai-sn35:150.1.3_0: And what is that practice that’s conducive to extinguishment?
ai-sn35:150.1.5_0: Is the eye permanent or impermanent?”
ai-sn35:150.3.1_0: “But if they're impermanent, are they suffering or happiness?”
ai-sn35:150.5.1_0: “But if they're impermanent, suffering, and perishable, are they fit to be regarded thus:
ai-sn35:150.5.2_0: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self’?”
ai-sn35:150.9.3_0: The pleasant, painful, or neutral feeling that arises conditioned by mind contact: is that permanent or impermanent?”
ai-sn35:150.11.1_0: “But if they're impermanent, are they suffering or happiness?”
ai-sn35:150.13.1_0: “But if they're impermanent, suffering, and perishable, are they fit to be regarded thus:
ai-sn35:150.13.2_0: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self’?”
ai-sn35:150.15.1_0: Seeing this, a learned noble disciple grows disillusioned with the eye, sights, eye consciousness, and eye contact. And they grow disillusioned with the painful, pleasant, or neutral feeling that arises conditioned by eye contact.
ai-sn35:150.15.2_0: They grow disillusioned with the painful, pleasant, or neutral feeling that arises conditioned by mind contact.
ai-sn35:150.15.3_0: Being disillusioned, desire fades away. When desire fades away they’re freed. ...
ai-sn35:150.15.4_0: They understand: ‘... there is no return to any state of existence.’
ai-sn35:150.15.5_0: This is that practice that’s conducive to extinguishment.”
ai-sn35:151.1.1_0: “Mendicants, this spiritual life is lived without a resident student and without a teaching master.
ai-sn35:151.1.2_0: There’s a mendicant who lives with a resident student and a teaching master lives in suffering and discomfort.
ai-sn35:151.1.3_0: A mendicant who lives without a resident student and a teaching master lives in happiness and comfort.
ai-sn35:151.1.4_0: And how does a mendicant who lives with a resident student and a teaching master live in suffering and discomfort?
ai-sn35:151.1.5_0: When a mendicant sees a sight with the eye, bad, unskillful phenomena arise: memories and thoughts prone to fetters.
ai-sn35:151.1.6_0: Those qualities reside within. Since they have bad unskillful qualities residing within,
ai-sn35:151.1.7_0: they’re said to be one who lives in a resident monk.
ai-sn35:151.1.8_0: Those qualities master them. Since they’re mastered by bad unskillful qualities,
ai-sn35:151.1.9_0: they’re said to have a teaching master.
ai-sn35:151.2.1_0: Furthermore, when a mendicant hears ... smells ... tastes ... touches ...
ai-sn35:151.2.2_0: Those qualities reside within. Since they have bad unskillful qualities residing within,
ai-sn35:151.2.3_0: they’re said to be one who lives in a resident monk.
ai-sn35:151.3.1_0: knows a thought with the mind, bad, unskillful phenomena arise: memories and thoughts prone to fetters.
ai-sn35:151.3.2_0: Those qualities reside within. Since they have bad unskillful qualities residing within,
ai-sn35:151.3.3_0: they’re said to be one who lives in a resident monk.
ai-sn35:151.3.4_0: Those qualities master them. Since they’re mastered by bad unskillful qualities,
ai-sn35:151.3.5_0: they’re said to have a teaching master.
ai-sn35:151.3.6_0: That’s how a mendicant who lives with a resident student and a teaching master lives in suffering and discomfort.
ai-sn35:151.4.1_0: And how does a mendicant who lives without a resident student and a teaching master live happily?
ai-sn35:151.4.2_0: When a mendicant sees a sight with the eye, bad, unskillful phenomena don’t arise: memories and thoughts prone to fetters.
ai-sn35:151.4.3_0: Those qualities don’t reside within. Since they don’t have bad unskillful qualities residing within,
ai-sn35:151.4.4_0: they’re said to not have a resident student.
ai-sn35:151.4.5_0: Those qualities don’t master them. Since they’re not mastered by bad unskillful qualities,
ai-sn35:151.4.6_0: they’re said to not have a teaching master.
ai-sn35:151.5.1_0: Furthermore, when a mendicant hears ... smells ... tastes ... touches ...
ai-sn35:151.5.2_0: Those qualities don’t reside within. Since they don’t have bad unskillful qualities residing within,
ai-sn35:151.5.3_0: they’re said to not have a resident student.
ai-sn35:151.5.4_0: Those qualities don’t master them. Since they’re not mastered by bad unskillful qualities,
ai-sn35:151.5.4_1: they’re said to not have a teaching master.
ai-sn35:151.6.1_0: knows a thought with the mind, bad, unskillful phenomena don’t arise: memories and thoughts prone to fetters.
ai-sn35:151.6.2_0: Those qualities don’t reside within. Since they don’t have bad unskillful qualities residing within,
ai-sn35:151.6.3_0: they’re said to not have a resident student.
ai-sn35:151.6.4_0: Those qualities don’t master them. Since they’re not mastered by bad unskillful qualities,
ai-sn35:151.6.5_0: they’re said to not have a teaching master.
ai-sn35:151.6.6_0: That’s how a mendicant who lives without a resident student and a teaching master lives in happiness and comfort.
ai-sn35:151.6.7_0: This spiritual life is lived without a resident student and without a teaching master.
ai-sn35:151.6.8_0: A mendicant who lives with a resident student and a teaching master lives in suffering and discomfort.
ai-sn35:151.6.9_0: A mendicant who lives without a resident student and a teaching master lives in happiness and comfort.”
ai-sn35:151.6.10_0: The sixth offering to an individual.
ai-sn35:152.1.1_0: “Mendicants, if wanderers who follow another path were to ask you:
ai-sn35:152.1.2_0: ‘Reverends, what’s the purpose of leading the spiritual life under the ascetic Gotama?’
ai-sn35:152.1.4_0: ‘The purpose of leading the spiritual life under the Buddha is to completely understand suffering.’
ai-sn35:152.1.5_0: If wanderers who follow other paths were to ask you:
ai-sn35:152.2.2_0: The purpose of leading the spiritual life under the Buddha is to completely understand this.
ai-sn35:152.2.4_0: The purpose of leading the spiritual life under the Buddha is to completely understand this.
ai-sn35:152.2.6_0: The purpose of leading the spiritual life under the Buddha is to completely understand this.
ai-sn35:152.2.8_0: The purpose of leading the spiritual life under the Buddha is to completely understand this.
ai-sn35:152.2.9_0: The pleasant, painful, or neutral feeling that arises conditioned by eye contact is also suffering.
ai-sn35:152.2.10_0: The purpose of leading the spiritual life under the Buddha is to completely understand this.
ai-sn35:152.2.13_0: The purpose of leading the spiritual life under the Buddha is to completely understand this.
ai-sn35:152.2.14_0: The pleasant, painful, or neutral feeling that arises conditioned by mind contact is also suffering.
ai-sn35:152.2.15_0: The purpose of leading the spiritual life under the Buddha is to completely understand this.
ai-sn35:152.2.17_0: The purpose of leading the spiritual life under the Buddha is to completely understand this.’
ai-sn35:152.2.18_0: When questioned by wanderers who follow other paths, that’s how you should answer them.”
ai-sn35:153.1.1_0: “Mendicants, is there a method—apart from faith, preference, oral tradition, reasoned contemplation, or acceptance of a view after consideration—that a mendicant can rely on to declare their enlightenment? That is:
ai-sn35:153.1.2_0: ‘I understand: “Rebirth is ended, the spiritual journey has been completed, what had to be done has been done, there is no return to any state of existence”’?”
ai-sn35:153.1.3_0: “Our teachings are rooted in the Buddha.
ai-sn35:153.1.3_1: He is our guide and our refuge.
ai-sn35:153.1.3_2: The mendicants will listen and remember it.”
ai-sn35:153.1.4_0: “Well then, mendicants, listen and pay close attention, I will speak.”
ai-sn35:153.1.7_0: “There is a method—apart from faith, preference, oral tradition, reasoned contemplation, or acceptance of a view after consideration—that a mendicant can rely on to declare their enlightenment. That is:
ai-sn35:153.1.8_0: ‘I understand: “Rebirth is ended, the spiritual journey has been completed, what had to be done has been done, there is no return to any state of existence.”’”
ai-sn35:153.2.1_0: And what’s the way in which a mendicant can rely on faith?
ai-sn35:153.2.1_2: ‘I understand: “Rebirth is ended, the spiritual journey has been completed, what had to be done has been done, there is no return to any state of existence.”’
ai-sn35:153.2.2_0: It’s when a mendicant sees a sight with their eyes, greed, hate, and delusion.
ai-sn35:153.2.3_0: or, not having greed, hate, and delusion he knows:
ai-sn35:153.2.4_1: or, not having greed, hate, and delusion he knows:
ai-sn35:153.2.4_2: Is these things should be understood as faith, preference, oral tradition, reasoned contemplation, or acceptance of a view after consideration?”
ai-sn35:153.2.6_0: “Aren’t they understood by seeing them with wisdom?”
ai-sn35:153.2.8_0: “This is a method—apart from faith, preference, oral tradition, reasoned contemplation, or acceptance of a view after consideration—that a mendicant can rely on to declare their enlightenment. That is:
ai-sn35:153.2.9_0: ‘I understand: “Rebirth is ended, the spiritual journey has been completed, what had to be done has been done, there is no return to any state of existence.” ...
ai-sn35:153.3.1_0: Furthermore, a mendicant hears a sound ... smells ... tastes ... touches ...
ai-sn35:153.3.1_1: They understand greed, hate, and delusion.
ai-sn35:153.3.1_2: or, not having greed, hate, and delusion he knows:
ai-sn35:153.3.2_1: or, not having greed, hate, and delusion he knows:
ai-sn35:153.3.2_2: Is these things should be understood as faith, preference, oral tradition, reasoned contemplation, or acceptance of a view after consideration?”
ai-sn35:153.3.4_0: “Aren’t they understood by seeing them with wisdom?”
ai-sn35:153.3.6_0: “This is a method—apart from faith, preference, oral tradition, reasoned contemplation, or acceptance of a view after consideration—that a mendicant can rely on to declare their enlightenment. That is:
ai-sn35:153.3.6_1: ‘I understand: “Rebirth is ended, the spiritual journey has been completed, what had to be done has been done, there is no return to any state of existence.” ...
ai-sn35:153.4.1_0: Furthermore, a mendicant knows a thought with their mind, and they understand that they’re greedy and hate.
ai-sn35:153.4.2_0: or, not having greed, hate, and delusion he knows:

ai-sn35:153.4.3_2: Is these things should be understood as faith, preference, oral tradition, reasoned contemplation, or acceptance of a view after consideration?”
ai-sn35:153.4.5_0: “Aren’t they understood by seeing them with wisdom?”
ai-sn35:153.4.7_0: “This is a method—apart from faith, preference, oral tradition, reasoned contemplation, or acceptance of a view after consideration—that a mendicant can rely on to declare their enlightenment. That is:
ai-sn35:153.4.8_0: ‘I understand: “Rebirth is ended, the spiritual journey has been completed, what had to be done has been done, there is no return to any state of existence.”’”
ai-sn35:154.1.1_0: Then a mendicant went up to the Buddha
ai-sn35:154.1.2_0: “Sir, they speak of this thing called ‘the faculties’.
ai-sn35:154.1.3_0: How is someone accomplished regarding the faculties defined?”
ai-sn35:154.2.1_0: “If a mendicant meditates observing rise and fall in the eye faculty, they grow disillusioned with the eye faculty, ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind faculty. ...
ai-sn35:154.2.2_0: If they meditate observing rise and fall in the ear faculty ... nose faculty ... tongue faculty ... body faculty ...
ai-sn35:154.2.3_0: mind faculty, they grow disillusioned with the mind faculty.
ai-sn35:154.2.4_0: Being disillusioned, desire fades away. ... When they’re freed, they know they’re freed.
ai-sn35:154.2.5_0: He understands: ‘Rebirth is ended, the spiritual journey has been completed, what had to be done has been done, there is no return to any state of existence.’
ai-sn35:154.2.6_0: That’s how a mendicant is accomplished in the faculties.”
ai-sn35:155.1.1_0: Then a mendicant went up to the Buddha
ai-sn35:155.1.3_0: How is a Dhamma speaker defined?”
ai-sn35:155.2.1_0: “If a mendicant teaches Dhamma for disillusionment, dispassion, and cessation regarding the eye, they’re qualified to be called a ‘mendicant who speaks on Dhamma’.
ai-sn35:155.2.2_0: If they practice for disillusionment, dispassion, and cessation regarding the eye, they’re qualified to be called a ‘mendicant who practices in line with the teaching’.
ai-sn35:155.2.3_0: If they’re freed by not grasping by disillusionment, dispassion, and cessation regarding the eye, they’re qualified to be called a ‘mendicant who has attained extinguishment in this very life’.
ai-sn35:155.2.4_0: If a mendicant teaches Dhamma for disillusionment with the ear ... nose ... tongue ... body ...
ai-sn35:155.2.5_0: mind, for its fading away and cessation, they’re qualified to be called a ‘mendicant who speaks on Dhamma’.
ai-sn35:155.2.6_0: If they practice for disillusionment, dispassion, and cessation regarding the mind, they’re qualified to be called a ‘mendicant who practices in line with the teaching’.
ai-sn35:155.2.7_0: If they’re freed by not grasping, by disillusionment, dispassion, and cessation regarding the mind, they’re qualified to be called a ‘mendicant who has attained extinguishment in this very life’.”
ai-sn35:155.2.9_0: The fifth sub-chapter on lying down is finished.

ai-sn35:161.1.10_0: And it also becomes truly clear that the painful, pleasant, or neutral feeling that arises conditioned by mind contact is impermanent.

ai-sn35:165.1.1_0: Then a mendicant went up to the Buddha
ai-sn35:165.1.3_0: “Sir, how does one know and see so that wrong view is given up?”
ai-sn35:165.2.1_0: “Mendicant, knowing and seeing the eye, sights, eye consciousness, and eye contact as impermanent, wrong view is given up. ...
ai-sn35:165.2.2_0: Knowing and seeing form as impermanent, wrong view is given up.
ai-sn35:165.2.3_0: Knowing and seeing eye consciousness as impermanent, wrong view is given up.
ai-sn35:165.2.4_0: Knowing and seeing eye contact as impermanent, wrong view is given up. ...
ai-sn35:165.2.5_0: And also knowing and seeing the pleasant, painful, or neutral feeling that arises conditioned by mind contact as impermanent, wrong view is given up.
ai-sn35:165.2.6_0: This is how to know and see so that wrong view is given up.”
ai-sn35:166.1.1_0: Then a mendicant went up to the Buddha ...
ai-sn35:166.1.3_0: “Sir, how does one know and see so that identity view is given up?”
ai-sn35:166.1.4_0: “Mendicant, knowing and seeing the eye, sights, eye consciousness, and eye contact as suffering, identity view is given up. ...
ai-sn35:166.1.5_0: Knowing and seeing form as suffering, identity view is given up. ...
ai-sn35:166.1.6_0: Knowing and seeing eye consciousness, identity view is given up. ...
ai-sn35:166.1.7_0: Knowing and seeing eye contact as suffering, identity view is given up. ...
ai-sn35:166.1.8_0: And also knowing and seeing the pleasant, painful, or neutral feeling that arises conditioned by mind contact as suffering, identity view is given up.
ai-sn35:166.1.9_0: This is how to know and see so that identity view is given up.”
ai-sn35:167.1.1_0: Then a mendicant went up to the Buddha ...
ai-sn35:167.1.3_0: “Sir, how does one know and see so that the self is given up?”
ai-sn35:167.1.4_0: “Mendicant, knowing and seeing the eye, sights, eye consciousness, and eye contact as not-self, view of self is given up. ...
ai-sn35:167.1.5_0: Knowing and seeing form as not-self, view of self is given up. ...
ai-sn35:167.1.7_0: Knowing and seeing eye contact as not-self, view of self is given up. ...
ai-sn35:167.1.8_0: And also knowing and seeing the pleasant, painful, or neutral feeling that arises conditioned by eye contact as not-self, view of self is given up. ...
ai-sn35:167.1.9_0: When you know and see the ear ... nose ... tongue ... body ...
ai-sn35:167.1.10_0: Knowing and seeing the mind, thoughts, mind consciousness, and mind contact as not-self, view of self is given up.
ai-sn35:167.1.11_0: By directly knowing and completely understanding thoughts ...
ai-sn35:167.1.14_0: And also knowing and seeing the pleasant, painful, or neutral feeling that arises conditioned by mind contact as not-self, view of self is given up.”

ai-sn35:228.1.1_0: “Mendicants, an uneducated ordinary person speaks of the ocean.
ai-sn35:228.1.2_0: But that’s not the ocean in the training of the Noble One.
ai-sn35:228.1.3_0: That’s just a large body of water.
ai-sn35:228.1.4_0: For a person, the eye is an ocean,
ai-sn35:228.1.5_0: and its currents are made of sights.
ai-sn35:228.2.1_0: Someone who can withstand those sights is said to have crossed over the ocean of the eye, with its waves and whirlpools, its sharks and monsters.
ai-sn35:228.2.2_0: Crossed over, the brahmin stands on the far shore.
ai-sn35:228.2.3_0: For a person, the ear ... nose ... tongue ... body ...
ai-sn35:228.2.4_0: and its currents are made of pleasure.
ai-sn35:228.2.5_0: Someone who can withstand those currents is said to have crossed over the ocean of the tongue.
ai-sn35:228.2.6_0: Crossed over, the brahmin stands on the far shore.
ai-sn35:228.2.8_0: and its currents are made of thoughts.
ai-sn35:228.2.9_0: Someone who can withstand those currents is said to have crossed over the ocean of the mind, with its waves and whirlpools, its sharks and monsters.
ai-sn35:228.2.10_0: Crossed over, the brahmin stands on the far shore.”

ai-sn35:228.3.4_0: they’re called ‘one who has gone beyond’.”

ai-sn35:229.1.6_0: And it’s here that this world—with its gods, Māras and Brahmās, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, gods and humans—is for the most part sunk. ai-sn35:229.3.3_0: have crossed the ocean so hard to cross,
ai-sn35:229.3.4_0: with its sharks and monsters, its waves and dangers.
ai-sn35:229.4.1_0: They’ve escaped their chains, given up death, and have no attachments.
